verse.text: [note]1[/note]Then Jehovah [xref]a[/xref]called to Moses and [note]2[/note]spoke to him out of the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]Tent of Meeting, saying,
verse.note: The divine revelation in the Bible is progressive, advancing continually from Genesis to Revelation. Genesis reveals God's creation and man's fall, and Exodus reveals God's salvation and the building of God's habitation. As a further advancement of the divine revelation, Leviticus unveils the worship and living of God's redeemed people. While Israel remained with God at Sinai for approximately eleven months ([link]Exo. 19:1[/link]; cf. [link]Num. 10:11[/link]), God trained them to worship and partake of Him for their enjoyment and to live a holy, clean, and rejoicing life. This book shows that through the tabernacle, with the offerings, and by the priests, God's redeemed are able to fellowship with God, serve God, and be God's holy people living a holy life, which expresses God. Christ is everything in the fellowship, service, and life of God's people. The worship portrayed in Leviticus is a matter of contacting God by enjoying Christ as the common portion with God and with one another (cf. [link]John 4:24[/link] and notes). The issue of enjoying Christ with God is the holy living of God's people.

The first and last verses of Leviticus indicate that the entire book is a record of God's speaking. The speaking that began here took place not in the heavens nor on Mount Sinai but in the tabernacle, the Tent of Meeting. In type this signifies that God speaks in the church as His tabernacle (cf. [link]1 Cor. 3:16[/link]; [link]14:23-31[/link]). The church as the Tent of Meeting is the unique oracle, the unique place of God's speaking.

The tabernacle was God's dwelling place ([link]Exo. 40:34-35[/link]), and the Tent of Meeting was the place where God and His redeemed people met (cf. [link]Exo. 25:22[/link]; [link]33:7[/link]). Both refer to the church, which is God's dwelling place on earth ([link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]) and also a meeting place for the saved ones to meet with the saving God (cf. [link]1 Cor. 14:23-25[/link]).

verse.text: Speak to the children of Israel and say to them, When any one of you presents an [note]1[/note]offering to Jehovah, you shall present your offering from the [note]2[/note]cattle, of the herd or of the flock.
verse.note: Heb. [i]qorban,[/i] meaning [i]a present,[/i] or [i]a gift.[/i] Strictly, the offerings are not sacrifices but presents given to God by the appreciators of Christ. Sacrifices are for redemption, for propitiation, whereas presents are gifts for intimate fellowship between us and God. The children of Israel were to labor on the good land and then offer to God as presents the produce they enjoyed and appreciated. Likewise, we should endeavor to experience and enjoy Christ and then offer Christ to God as a present with much appreciation. The tabernacle is for God to dwell in, and the offerings are for God to enjoy with us through our appreciation and presentation.[br][br]Exodus ends with the erecting of the tabernacle ([link]Exo. 40[/link]), and Leviticus begins with the offerings ([link]chs. 1-7[/link]), implying a direct continuation between the two books. Both the tabernacle and the offerings are types of Christ. Through incarnation Christ came to be the tabernacle ([link]John 1:14[/link]). This same Christ is also the Lamb of God ([link]John 1:29[/link]), the totality, the aggregate, of all the offerings ([link]Heb. 10:5-10[/link]). Christ came in incarnation to bring God to us ([link]John 1:1-13:38[/link]), and He passed through crucifixion and resurrection to bring us to God ([link]John 14:1-21:25[/link]), making God one with us and us one with God. The tabernacle signifies that God is in Christ that we may contact, experience, enter into, and join to God. The offerings signify God in Christ for us to enjoy and even to eat, digest, and assimilate ([link]John 6:53-58[/link]) that we may be mingled with God. The way to enjoy Christ as the reality of all the offerings is to contact Him and take Him in as the Spirit of reality ([link]John 6:63[/link]; [link]14:16-18[/link], [link]20[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]).[br][br]According to Leviticus, there are five main kinds of offerings: the burnt offering ([link]1:1-17[/link]), the meal offering ([link]2:1-16[/link]), the peace offering ([link]3:1-17[/link]), the sin offering ([link]4:1-35[/link]), and the trespass offering ([link]5:1-6:7[/link]). The functions of these offerings were (1) as sacrifices for sin, to make expiation for God's people by appeasing the situation between God and His people, (2) as gifts to please God, and (3) as food for God and for His serving ones, the priests.

All the kinds of cattle used in burnt offerings in this chapter were living animals that move and act according to their will. Christ was such a living one, with a strong will but with His will subdued to be subject to God. He never became blemished ([link]v. 3[/link]) because His will was always subdued to be subject to God's will ([link]John 5:30[/link]; [link]6:38[/link]). As the burnt offering Christ went to the cross in order to do the will of God ([link]Heb. 10:5-10[/link] and note [link]7[sup]2[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: If his offering is a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]burnt offering from the herd, he shall present it, a [note]2[/note]male [xref]b[/xref]without [note]2[/note]blemish; he shall present it at the [note]3[/note]entrance of the Tent of Meeting, that he may be accepted before Jehovah.
verse.note: The Hebrew word literally means [i]that which goes up[/i] and denotes something that ascends to God. The burnt offering typifies Christ not mainly in His redeeming man from sin but in His living a life that is perfect and absolutely for God and for God's satisfaction ([link]v. 9[/link]; [link]John 5:19[/link], [link]30[/link]; [link]6:38[/link]; [link]7:18[/link]; [link]8:29[/link]; [link]14:24[/link]) and in His being the life that enables God's people to have such a living ([link]2 Cor. 5:15[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:19-20[/link]). It is God's food that God may enjoy it and be satisfied ([link]Num. 28:2[/link]). This offering was to be offered daily, in the morning and in the evening ([link]Exo. 29:38-42[/link]; [link]Lev. 6:8-13[/link]; [link]Num. 28:3-4[/link]).
As the burnt offering Christ is full of strength (a male) and freshness (young — [link]v. 5[/link]), and He is without defects and faults ([link]1 Pet. 1:19[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:14[/link]).

The burnt offering was offered at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, i.e., in the outer court of the tabernacle. The outer court signifies the earth (cf. note [link]9[sup]2[/sup] in Rev. 6[/link]), and the altar signifies the cross. The cross on which Christ offered Himself was on earth, but His offering of Himself was before God, and He was accepted by God and before God.

verse.text: And he shall [xref]a[/xref]lay his [note]1[/note]hand on the head of the burnt offering, and it shall be accepted for him, to make [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]expiation for him.
verse.note: The laying on of hands signifies not substitution but identification, union ([link]Acts 13:3[/link] and note 2). By laying our hands on Christ as our offering, we are joined to Him, and He and we become one. In such a union all our weaknesses, defects, and faults are taken on by Him, and all His virtues become ours. This requires us to exercise our spirit through the proper prayer so that we may be one with Him in an experiential way (cf. [link]1 Cor. 6:17[/link] and notes). When we lay our hands on Christ through prayer, the life-giving Spirit, who is the very Christ on whom we lay our hands ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:6[/link], [link]17[/link]), will immediately move and work within us to live in us a life that is a repetition of the life that Christ lived on earth, the life of the burnt offering.

Although the burnt offering is not for redemption, it nevertheless makes expiation for the offerer (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 16[/link]). For this reason, the burnt offering must be a life that has blood to shed for expiation ([link]Heb. 9:22[/link]). Because we are not absolutely for God, we need Christ as our burnt offering to appease our situation with God that we may have peace with Him. Because the burnt offering is for expiation, it can be eaten only by God ([link]v. 9[/link]; [link]6:30[/link]). We are not qualified to eat it.

verse.text: And he shall [note]1[/note]slaughter the young bull before Jehovah; and Aaron's sons the [note]2[/note]priests shall present the [note]3[/note]blood and [xref]a[/xref]sprinkle the blood on and around the altar that is at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting.
verse.note: As the burnt offering Christ was slaughtered by men ([link]Isa. 53:7[/link]; [link]Matt. 27:31[/link]; [link]Acts 2:23[/link]; [link]Phil. 2:8[/link]).

God trained His elect to worship and partake of Him through the priests ([link]1:5-8[/link]; [link]2:2[/link]; [link]3:2[/link]; [link]4:5[/link], [link]10[/link]; [link]5:8[/link]). The priests typify Christ as God's Priest ([link]Heb. 5:5-6[/link]), who offered Himself to God for us ([link]Heb. 9:14[/link], [link]26[/link]; [link]10:10[/link]). Christ is both the offerings and the Priest. He is the unique way for God's people to worship and enjoy God.
The sprinkling of the blood was for expiation ([link]v. 4[/link]).

verse.text: And he shall [note]1[/note]skin the burnt offering and [note]2[/note]cut it into its pieces.
verse.note: The skin of the burnt offering is the outward expression of its beauty. Hence, to skin the offering is to strip it of its outward expression. As the burnt offering, Christ was "skinned," stripped of the outward appearance of His human virtues ([link]Matt. 11:19[/link]; [link]Mark 3:22[/link]; [link]John 8:48[/link]; [link]Matt. 26:65[/link]; [link]27:28[/link]; cf. [link]Psa. 22:18[/link]).

The cutting of the offering into pieces signifies that Christ was willing to let His entire being be broken without any reservation. In His living as the burnt offering, Christ's whole being and His entire life were cut into pieces ([link]Mark 15:29-32[/link]; [link]Luke 23:35-39[/link]; cf. [link]Psa. 22:16-17[/link]). The cutting of the offering into pieces by the offerer indicates that his experience, apprehension, realization, and appreciation of Christ are deep and detailed.

chapter.verse: And the sons of Aaron the priest shall put fire on the altar and arrange the wood in order on the fire.

verse.text: Then Aaron's sons the priests shall arrange the pieces, the [note]1[/note]head, and the fat in order on the wood that is on the fire which is on the altar;
verse.note: The head of the burnt offering typifies Christ's wisdom; the fat signifies His being a delight to God ([link]Matt. 3:17[/link]; [link]12:18[/link]; [link]17:5[/link]); the inward parts ([link]v. 9[/link]) denote Christ's inward parts, including His mind, emotion, will, and heart with all their functions; and the legs ([link]v. 9[/link]) signify Christ's walk.

verse.text: But its inward parts and its legs he shall [note]1[/note]wash with water. Then the priest shall [note]2[/note]burn the whole on the altar, as a burnt offering, an offering by [note]3[/note]fire, a satisfying [note]4[/note][xref]a[/xref]fragrance to Jehovah.
verse.note: The washing of the inward parts and the legs of the burnt offering does not imply that Christ was dirty; rather, it indicates that Christ's inward parts and His daily walk were continually being washed by the Holy Spirit, signified by the water ([link]John 7:38-39[/link]), to keep Him from becoming defiled by His contact with earthly things.[br][br]In order to offer Christ to God as our burnt offering, we need to experience Him in His experiences and offer Him to God according to our experiences of Him ([link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link]; [link]Heb. 13:15[/link]). In particular, we need to experience Him in His being slaughtered ([link]Rom. 8:36[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 4:11[/link]), skinned ([link]Matt. 5:11[/link]; [link]Acts 24:5-6[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 6:8[/link]; [link]12:16-18[/link]), and cut into pieces ([link]1 Cor. 4:13[/link]). We also need to experience Him in His wisdom ([link]1 Cor. 1:24[/link], [link]30[/link]; [link]2:7[/link]; [link]Col. 1:26-27[/link]), in His being a delight to God ([link]2 Cor. 5:9[/link]; [link]Gal. 1:10[/link]; [link]Rom. 14:18[/link]), in His inward parts ([link]Phil. 2:5[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 2:16b[/link]; [link]16:24[/link]; [link]Phil. 1:8[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 11:10[/link]), in His walk ([link]Matt. 11:29[/link]; [link]Eph. 4:20[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 11:1[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:21[/link]), and in His being kept by the Holy Spirit from defilement ([link]1 Cor. 6:11[/link]; [link]Titus 3:5[/link]). Experiencing Christ in His experiences is not a matter of imitating Christ outwardly but a matter of living Him in our daily life ([link]Gal. 2:20[/link]; [link]Phil. 1:21[/link]). The way in which we offer Christ as the burnt offering is actually a display and review of our daily experience of Christ. See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup][/link].
Lit., cause to rise in smoke. This word is used for the burning (offering) of burnt offerings and incense.

The fire signifies the holy God ([link]Heb. 12:29[/link]). With the burnt offering, the fire was not for judgment but for acceptance by God. This fire was to burn continually day and night ([link]6:9[/link], [link]12-13[/link]).

As the burnt offering Christ lived a life that was absolutely for God's satisfaction ([link]John 5:30[/link]; [link]6:38[/link]; [link]8:29[/link]), a life that was pure and holy, with no element of the fall, no defect, and no sin ([link]John 14:30[/link]; [link]Luke 23:14[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link]; [link]Heb. 4:15[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:19[/link]; [link]2:22[/link]). Such a living was a satisfying fragrance, a sweet savor ascending to God for His pleasure and satisfaction.

chapter.verse: And if his offering is from the flock, of the sheep or of the goats, for a burnt offering, he shall present it, a male without blemish.
And he shall slaughter it on the side of the altar northward before Jehovah, and Aaron's sons the priests shall sprinkle its blood on and around the altar.

verse.text: And he shall [note]1[/note]cut it into its pieces with its head and its fat, and the priest shall arrange them in order on the wood that is on the fire which is on the altar;
verse.note: With this category of burnt offering there is no skinning, indicating that the offerer has not experienced Christ's being stripped of the outward expression of His human virtues (see note [link]6[sup]1[/sup][/link] and note [link]9[sup]1[/sup][/link], par. 2).

chapter.verse: But the inward parts and the legs he shall wash with water. Then the priest shall present the whole and burn it on the altar; it is a burnt offering, an offering by fire, a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah.

verse.text: And if his offering to Jehovah is a burnt offering of [note]1[/note]birds, then he shall present his offering of [xref]a[/xref]turtledoves or of young pigeons.
verse.note: Offering the burnt offering at the Tent of Meeting typifies the offering of Christ to God in the church meetings. The various kinds of burnt offerings ([link]vv. 3-9[/link], [link]10-13[/link], [link]14-17[/link]) differed both in size and in the way they were offered. The different sizes of burnt offerings signify not that Christ in Himself varies but that the offerers' experience, apprehension, realization, and appreciation of Christ differ in degree. The first two categories of burnt offerings — the bull and the sheep or goat — were offered in the same way: the preparing of the offering was done by the offerer; the priest's function was only to sprinkle the blood on and around the altar and arrange the pieces of the offering on the fire. However, with the offerings in the third category, the offerer simply brought the offering to the Tent of Meeting; the priest did everything else. Those who offered a bull or a sheep or a goat signify the mature believers who experience and appreciate Christ in a deep and detailed way and have the spiritual ability to offer Christ in a processed way. Those who offered a turtledove or a pigeon signify believers who are young in spiritual age and who have limited experience and appreciation of Christ.

chapter.verse: And the priest shall present it at the altar and wring off its head and burn [i]it[/i] on the altar; and its blood shall be drained out on the side of the altar.

verse.text: And he shall take away its crop with its feathers and cast it beside the altar toward the east, in the [xref]a[/xref]place of the [note]1[/note]ashes.
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].

verse.text: Then he shall tear it open by its wings [xref]a[/xref]without dividing [i]it,[/i] and the priest shall burn it on the altar on the wood that is on the fire; it is a burnt offering, an offering by fire, a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah.

And when anyone presents an offering of a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]meal offering to Jehovah, his offering shall be of [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]fine flour; and he shall pour [note]3[/note]oil on it and put [note]4[/note]frankincense on it.
verse.note: The meal offering typifies Christ in His human living. The emphasis of the burnt offering ([link]ch. 1[/link]) is on Christ's living for God, being obedient to God even unto death ([link]Phil. 2:8[/link]), implying His living but emphasizing His death. The emphasis of the meal offering is on Christ's human living and daily walk, implying His death but emphasizing His living (see note [link]13[sup]1[/sup][/link]). The burnt offering emphasizes that Christ is the righteousness of God ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]; cf. [link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link]), whereas the meal offering emphasizes that Christ is righteous before God ([link]1 John 2:1[/link]).

Fine flour, the main element of the meal offering, signifies Christ's humanity, which is fine, perfect, tender, balanced, and right in every way, with no excess and no deficiency. This signifies the beauty and excellence of Christ's human living and daily walk. The fine flour of the meal offering was produced out of wheat that had passed through many processes, which signify the various sufferings of Christ that made Him "a man of sorrows" ([link]Isa. 53:3[/link]).[br][br]In contrast to the burnt offering, nothing of the animal life, but only the vegetable life, is seen in the meal offering. As a type of Christ, the vegetable life indicates the produce, the propagation, and the increase for the supplying of life to people.

The oil of the meal offering signifies the Spirit of God as the divine element of Christ (see note [link]18[sup]3[/sup] in 1 Pet. 3[/link]). In the meal offering the oil was mingled with the fine flour ([link]vv. 4-5[/link]) and poured upon it ([link]vv. 1[/link], [link]6[/link], [link]15[/link]) to anoint it ([link]v. 4[/link]), signifying that the Spirit of God as Christ's divinity was mingled with His humanity ([link]Matt. 1:18[/link], [link]20[/link]; [link]Luke 1:35[/link]) and that the Spirit was poured upon Him ([link]Matt. 3:16[/link]; [link]John 1:32[/link]) to anoint Him ([link]Luke 4:18[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:9[/link]). This is a picture of the two aspects of Christ's experience of the Spirit of God.

The frankincense in the meal offering signifies the fragrance of Christ in His resurrection. That the frankincense was put on the fine flour signifies that Christ's humanity bears the aroma of His resurrection (cf. [link]Matt. 11:20-30[/link]; [link]Luke 10:21[/link]). As portrayed in the four Gospels, Christ lived a life in His humanity mingled with His divinity and expressing resurrection out from His sufferings (cf. [link]John 18:4-8[/link]; [link]19:26-27a[/link]). Christ was always filled with the Spirit and saturated with resurrection ([link]Luke 4:1[/link]; [link]John 11:25[/link]).

verse.text: Then he shall bring it to Aaron's sons the priests, and [xref]a[/xref]he shall take from it his handful of its fine flour and of its oil with all its frankincense. And the priest shall burn [i]it as[/i] its [note]1[/note]memorial portion on the altar, an offering by [note]2[/note]fire, a satisfying [xref]b[/xref]fragrance to Jehovah.
verse.note: Part of the flour and oil and all of the frankincense of the meal offering were God's food ([link]vv. 9[/link], [link]16[/link]). This signifies that a considerable portion of Christ's excellent, perfect, Spirit-filled, and resurrection-saturated living is offered to God as food for His enjoyment. This portion is so satisfying to God that it becomes a memorial. The remainder of the offering, consisting of fine flour and oil but no frankincense, was food for the serving priests ([link]vv. 3[/link], [link]10[/link]).[br][br]Whereas the burnt offering is God's food for His satisfaction ([link]Num. 28:2[/link]), the meal offering is our food for our satisfaction, a portion also being shared with God. Proper worship is a matter of satisfying God with Christ as the burnt offering and of being satisfied with Christ as the meal offering and sharing this satisfaction with God (cf. [link]John 4:24[/link] and note 4).

All meal offerings were offered by fire on the altar ([link]vv. 4-9[/link]), signifying that Christ in His humanity offered to God as food has gone through the testing fire ([link]Rev. 1:15[/link]). The fire in [link]Lev. 2[/link] signifies the consuming God ([link]Heb. 12:29[/link]), not for judgment but for acceptance. The consuming of the meal offering by fire signifies that God has accepted Christ as His satisfying food.

chapter.verse: And what is left of the meal offering shall be Aaron's and his sons'; it is [i]a thing[/i] most holy of Jehovah's offerings by fire.

verse.text: And when you present an offering of a meal offering baked in the [note]1[/note]oven, [i]it shall be[/i] of fine flour, [xref]a[/xref]unleavened [note]2[/note]cakes [note]3[/note]mingled with oil or unleavened [note]4[/note]wafers anointed with oil.
verse.note: The preparing of the meal offering in an oven, in a pan, or in a pot ([link]vv. 4-5[/link], [link]7[/link]) signifies different kinds of sufferings experienced by Christ in His humanity.

A perforated cake, related to the verb [i]to pierce.[/i] The perforating, or piercing, of the cakes signifies one kind of Christ's sufferings in His humanity ([link]John 19:34[/link], [link]37[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:7[/link]).

The mingling of fine flour with oil in the meal offering ([link]vv. 4-5[/link]) signifies that Christ's humanity is mingled with the Holy Spirit ([link]Matt. 1:18b[/link]) and His human nature is mingled with God's divine nature, making Him a God-man. Christ is both the complete God and the perfect man, possessing the divine nature and the human nature distinctly, without a third nature being produced. Through the divine mingling Christ's humanity has been uplifted to the highest standard. In His divinity Christ has the divine attributes, and these divine attributes are expressed through, with, and in His human virtues. This is the excellence of Jesus Christ.[br][br]In the meal offering the oil and the fine flour are mingled and cannot be separated. Hence, to eat the fine flour is to eat the oil. The picture in [link]Lev. 2[/link] indicates strongly that the way for us to be nourished with Christ's humanity, and thus to experience His human living, is by the Spirit ([link]John 6:51[/link], [link]57[/link], [link]63[/link]).

The cakes of fine flour are the largest kind of meal offering and signify the stronger experience of Christ in His humanity by the mature believers. Wafers are hollow and easy to eat. They signify Christ in His humanity experienced and enjoyed by the younger believers. Christ as the meal offering is available as food to God's people of all ages.

verse.text: And if your offering is a meal offering [i]baked[/i] on a flat plate, it shall be of [note]1[/note]fine flour mingled with oil, unleavened.
verse.note: The meal offering could be in the form of flour mingled with oil ([link]vv. 1-2[/link]) or in the form of a cake ([link]v. 4[/link]). The former signifies the individual Christ and also the individual Christian. The latter signifies the corporate Christ, Christ with His Body, the church. The individual Christ has become the corporate Christ ([link]1 Cor. 12:12[/link]), signified by the cake ([link]1 Cor. 10:17[/link]). This indicates that eventually Christ's life and our individual Christian life issue in a totality — the church life as a corporate meal offering. Such a life is a life of humanity mingled with the Holy Spirit and which has the Holy Spirit poured upon it, a life with salt and frankincense but with no leaven or honey (see notes [link]1[sup]4[/sup][/link], [link]11[sup]1[/sup][/link], [link]11[sup]2[/sup][/link], and [link]13[sup]1[/sup][/link]). Both forms of the meal offering — the individual Christ and the corporate Christ, the church life — are food for God's satisfaction and our nourishment.

verse.text: You shall [note]1[/note]break it in pieces and pour oil on it; it is a meal offering.
verse.note: That the meal offering was broken into pieces signifies that Christ's humanity is perfect but is never kept whole; it is always broken. This breaking signifies another kind of suffering that Christ passed through in His humanity. Cf. note [link]6[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

chapter.verse: And if your offering is a meal offering made in a pot, it shall be [i]made[/i] of fine flour with oil.
And you shall bring to Jehovah the meal offering that is made of these things and present it to the priest, and he shall bring it to the altar.
And the priest shall take up from the meal offering its memorial portion and shall burn [i]it[/i] on the altar, an offering by fire, a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah.
And that which is left of the meal offering shall be Aaron's and his sons'; it is [i]a thing[/i] most holy of Jehovah's offerings by fire.

verse.text: No meal offering that you present to Jehovah shall be made with [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]leaven, for you shall not burn any leaven or any [note]2[/note]honey as an offering by fire to Jehovah.
verse.note: That the meal offering was without leaven ([link]vv. 4-5[/link]) signifies that in Christ there is no sin or any negative thing ([link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link]; [link]Heb. 4:15[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:22[/link]; [link]Luke 23:14[/link]; cf. [link]1 Cor. 5:6-8[/link]).
That the meal offering was without honey signifies that in Christ there is no natural affection or natural goodness ([link]Matt. 12:46-50[/link]; [link]Mark 10:18[/link]).

chapter.verse: You may present them to Jehovah, as an offering of firstfruits, but they shall not be offered up for a satisfying fragrance on the altar.

verse.text: And every offering of your meal offering you shall season with [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]salt, and you shall not omit the salt of the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]covenant of your God from your meal offering; with all your offerings you shall present salt.
verse.note: Salt functions to season, kill germs, and preserve. In typology salt signifies the death, or the cross, of Christ. The Lord Jesus always lived a life of being salted, a life under the cross ([link]Mark 10:38[/link]; [link]John 12:24[/link]). Even before He was actually crucified, Christ daily lived a crucified life, denying Himself and His natural life and living the Father's life in resurrection ([link]John 6:38[/link]; [link]7:6[/link], [link]16-18[/link]; cf. [link]Gal. 2:20[/link]).

The basic factor of God's covenant is the cross, the crucifixion of Christ, signified by salt. It is by the cross that God's covenant is preserved to be an everlasting covenant (cf. [link]Heb. 13:20[/link] and note 2, par. 2).

verse.text: And if you present a meal offering of firstfruits to Jehovah, you shall present for the meal offering of your [note]1[/note]firstfruits new grain roasted with fire, crushed grain of the fresh ear.
verse.note: The meal offering of the firstfruits of new grain signifies the fresh enjoyment of Christ in His resurrection ([link]John 12:24[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:20[/link]). The crushing of the grains signifies being dealt with by the cross of Christ.

chapter.verse: And you shall put oil on it and place frankincense on it; it is a meal offering.
And the priest shall burn [i]as[/i] its memorial portion some of its crushed grain and some of its oil, with all its frankincense, as an offering by fire to Jehovah.

verse.text: And if his offering is a sacrifice of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]peace offerings, if he presents it from the [note]2[/note]herd, whether male or female, he shall present [i]it[/i] [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]without blemish before Jehovah.
verse.note: The peace offering signifies Christ as our peace with God that we may enjoy Him with God and with man in fellowship and joy ([link]Num. 10:10[/link]; [link]Deut. 27:7[/link]). It is fulfilled primarily in our enjoying Christ at the Lord's table in the breaking of bread for the remembrance of Him and in the offering of Christ to the Father for the worship of the Father ([link]Matt. 26:26-30[/link]). The peace offering, which implies fellowship with the Triune God and includes the enjoyment of the Triune God, is illustrated in [link]Luke 15:23-24[/link] by the fattened calf as the peaceful enjoyment between the receiving father (God) and the returned prodigal (a sinner).[br][br]The peace offering is the Old Testament type of the Lord's table. At the Lord's table the believers enjoy Christ as their peace offering for their fellowship with God and with one another. This enjoyment of the peace offering issues from the burnt offering, the meal offering, the sin offering, and the trespass offering ([link]v. 5[/link] and note). Our enjoyment of Christ as these four offerings has an issue, a result — the enjoyment of Christ as our peace offering for us to have fellowship with God and with our fellow believers. See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup][/link].

The peace offering could be of different animals from the herd or from the flock, and it could be either male or female. The different kinds of peace offerings signify the different conditions of the offerers' enjoyment of Christ. Here the male signifies that the offerer's enjoyment of Christ is stronger, whereas the female signifies that the offerer's enjoyment of Christ is weaker (cf. [link]1 Pet. 3:7[/link]). Cf. note [link]7[sup]1[/sup][/link].
As our peace offering, Christ is without blemish, without sins and transgressions ([link]Heb. 9:14[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:19[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link]; [link]Heb. 4:15[/link]).

verse.text: And he shall [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]lay his hand on the head of his offering and slaughter it at the [note]2[/note]entrance of the Tent of Meeting, and Aaron's sons the priests shall [xref]b[/xref]sprinkle the [note]3[/note]blood on and around the altar.
verse.note: See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]. So also for [link]vv. 8[/link] and [link]13[/link].
See note [link]3[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

The sprinkling of the blood of the peace offering on and around the altar ([link]vv. 2[/link], [link]8[/link], [link]13[/link]), where the offerer was standing, indicates that the blood is for peace in the offerer's conscience, giving him the assurance that his sins have been washed away ([link]Heb. 9:14b[/link]).

verse.text: And from the sacrifice of peace offerings he shall present an offering by fire to [note]1[/note]Jehovah, the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]fat that covers the [note]2[/note]inward parts and all the fat that is on the inward parts;
verse.note: Christ as the peace offering is for the fellowship and enjoyment of five parties: God, the serving priest, all the priests (the priesthood), the offerer, and the congregation of cleansed people. The fat and the inward parts of the offering were God's portion ([link]vv. 3-5[/link]); the four kinds of cakes and the right thigh as a heave offering were the portion of the serving priest ([link]7:14[/link], [link]32-34[/link]); the breast as a wave offering was for all the priests ([link]7:30-31[/link], [link]34[/link]); the flesh, the meat, of the offering was the portion of the offerer ([link]7:15-18[/link]); and the remaining flesh of the cattle, under the condition of cleanness, was for all the congregation ([link]7:19-21[/link]). In the New Testament there are no clergy and no laity (see note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in Rev. 2[/link]). Thus, all the believers in Christ should be the serving priests, the priestly body, the offerers, and the congregation.

The fat signifies the inward riches of Christ as the abundance of life for God's satisfaction according to His glory, and the inward parts signify the tenderness, smallness, and preciousness of what Christ is in His inward being toward God (cf. [link]Phil. 1:8[/link]; [link]John 7:3-18[/link] and notes) for God's satisfaction, which can be apprehended and appreciated only by God ([link]Matt. 11:27a[/link]). The burning of the fat and the inward parts of the peace offering as an offering by fire to Jehovah ([link]vv. 3-5[/link], [link]9-11[/link], [link]14-16[/link]) signifies that God should be the first Enjoyer, enjoying the first, the best, part of the peace offering.

chapter.verse: And the two kidneys and the fat that is on them, which is on the loins; and the appendage on the liver, which he shall remove with the kidneys.

verse.text: And Aaron's sons shall burn it on the [xref]a[/xref]altar upon the [note]1[/note]burnt offering, which is on the wood that is on the fire; it is an offering by fire, a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah.
verse.note: The peace offering is based on God's satisfaction in the burnt offering ([link]6:12[/link]). According to the sequence of the offerings presented in [link]1:1-6:7[/link], it is also the issue of the enjoyment of God and man in the meal offering. If we would enjoy Christ as peace in a practical, daily way, we must first take Him as our burnt offering to satisfy God, and then we must feed on Him as the meal offering, enjoying Him as our food.[br][br]According to the sequence of the offerings in [link]6:8-7:38[/link], the peace offering is also based on the sin offering and the trespass offering. When the problem of our sin and trespasses is solved by Christ as the sin offering and trespass offering, and when God and we are satisfied with Christ as the burnt offering and the meal offering, we can offer Christ to God as the peace offering for our mutual enjoyment in peace. See [link]7:37[/link] and note 2.

chapter.verse: And if his offering for a sacrifice of peace offerings to Jehovah is from the flock, he shall present it, male or female, without blemish.

verse.text: If he presents a [note]1[/note]lamb for his offering, then he shall present it before Jehovah.
verse.note: A lamb signifies that the offerer enjoys Christ in His perfection and beauty, whereas a goat ([link]v. 12[/link]) signifies that the offerer enjoys Christ not much in His perfection and beauty but in His being made sin on our behalf ([link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link]).

chapter.verse: And he shall lay his hand on the head of his offering and slaughter it before the Tent of Meeting, and Aaron's sons shall sprinkle its blood on and around the altar.

verse.text: And from the sacrifice of peace offerings he shall present an offering by fire to Jehovah, its [xref]a[/xref]fat, the entire fat tail which he shall remove close to the backbone, and the fat that covers the inward parts and all the fat that is on the inward parts;

chapter.verse: And the two kidneys and the fat that is on them, which is on the loins; and the appendage on the liver, which he shall remove with the kidneys.

verse.text: And the priest shall [note]1[/note]burn it on the altar; it is the [xref]a[/xref]food of the offering by fire to Jehovah.
verse.note: This signifies that the peace offering is a kind of burnt offering ([link]1:9[/link], [link]13[/link], [link]17[/link]) as food to God for His satisfaction and enjoyment.

chapter.verse: And if his offering is a goat, then he shall present it before Jehovah.
And he shall lay his hand on its head and slaughter it before the Tent of Meeting, and Aaron's sons shall sprinkle its blood on and around the altar.
And from it he shall present his offering, as an offering by fire to Jehovah, the fat that covers the inward parts and all the fat that is on the inward parts;
And the two kidneys and the fat that is on them, which is on the loins; and the appendage on the liver, which he shall remove with the kidneys.
And the priest shall burn them on the altar; it is the food of the offering by fire for a satisfying fragrance; all the fat is Jehovah's.

verse.text: It shall be a perpetual statute throughout your generations in all your dwelling places that you shall not eat any [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fat or any [xref]b[/xref]blood.
verse.note: Not eating the fat signifies that the best part of Christ is for God's satisfaction. Not eating the blood signifies that Christ's blood shed for our redemption fully satisfies the requirements of God's righteousness, holiness, and glory (see note [link]24[sup]1[/sup] in Gen. 3[/link]). Thus, in the universe only Jesus' blood is edible to His believers ([link]John 6:53-56[/link] and note [link]54[sup]2[/sup][/link]). To eat any other blood would make Christ's blood common (cf. [link]Heb. 10:29[/link] and note 3).

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Speak to the children of Israel, saying, If anyone [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sins without intent, in any of the things which Jehovah has commanded not to be done, and does any one of them,
verse.note: Or, errs, makes a mistake. The sinning without intent here signifies the sin in our fallen nature, the indwelling sin that came through Adam into mankind from Satan ([link]Rom. 5:12[/link]), which causes us to sin unintentionally ([link]Rom. 7:19-20[/link]). This sin, personified in [link]Rom. 7[/link] (see note [link book="Rom." chapter="7"]8[sup]1[/sup][/link] there), is the evil nature of Satan, even Satan himself, who dwells in our fallen flesh ([link]Rom. 7:17-18a[/link], [link]20[/link], [link]23[/link] and note [link]18[sup]2[/sup][/link]). Since our flesh is one with sin ([link]Rom. 8:3[/link]), whatever we do out of our flesh, whether good or evil, is sin. Moreover, since the flesh denotes a fallen person ([link]Gen. 6:3[/link]; [link]Rom. 3:20[/link]), every fallen person is sin ([link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link] and note 2).

verse.text: If the [xref]a[/xref]anointed priest sins so as to bring guilt on the people, then let him present a [note]1[/note]bull of the herd [xref]b[/xref]without [note]2[/note]blemish to Jehovah [note]3[/note]for a [note]4[/note][xref]c[/xref]sin offering for his sin that he committed.
verse.note: The sin offering could be a young bull, a male goat, a female goat, or a female lamb ([link]vv. 3[/link], [link]14[/link], [link]23[/link], [link]28[/link], [link]32[/link]). This signifies that the realization, presentation, and application of Christ as the sin offering may differ in degree. Cf. note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].
See note [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 3[/link]. So for [link book="Lev." chapter="4"]vv. 23[/link], [link]28[/link], and [link]32[/link].
Or, concerning sin. So throughout the book (cf. [link]Rom. 8:3[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link]).

The sin offering signifies Christ as the offering for the sin of God's people. In the Bible [i]sin[/i] refers to the indwelling sin in our nature, whereas [i]sins[/i] refers to the sinful deeds, the fruit of the indwelling sin. Our sin was dealt with by Christ as our sin offering ([link]Lev. 4[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:3[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:26[/link]), and our sins, our trespasses, were borne by Christ as our trespass offering ([link]Lev. 5[/link]; [link]Isa. 53:5a[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:3[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:24[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:28[/link]). As the Lamb of God, Christ took away sin in its totality — the inward sin and the outward sins ([link]Isa. 53:10[/link]; [link]John 1:29[/link]). See notes [link]18[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Pet. 3[/link] and [link]7[sup]6[/sup] in 1 John 1[/link].[br][br]Through incarnation the Word, who is God, became flesh, in the likeness of the flesh of sin, i.e., the likeness of a fallen man ([link]John 1:1[/link], [link]14[/link] and note [link]14[sup]2[/sup][/link], par. 1; [link]Rom. 8:3[/link] and note 3). Christ was crucified in the flesh and died in the flesh ([link]1 Pet. 3:18b[/link]). Although Christ was a fallen man only in likeness, when He was on the cross, God counted that likeness as real. Since sin, the old man, Satan, the world, and the ruler of the world are all one with the flesh, when Christ died in the flesh, sin was condemned ([link]Rom. 8:3[/link]), the old man was crucified ([link]Rom. 6:6[/link]), Satan was destroyed ([link]Heb. 2:14[/link]), the world was judged, and the ruler of the world was cast out ([link]John 12:31[/link]). Hence, through Christ's death in the flesh all negative things were dealt with. This is the efficacy of the sin offering.[br][br]The sequence of the five offerings in [link]1:1-6:7[/link] is a picture of the sequence in [link]1 John 1[/link]. The burnt offering, the meal offering, and the peace offering bring us into fellowship with God ([link]1 John 1:3[/link]). Through our fellowship with God, who is light ([link]1 John 1:5[/link]), we discover that we are sinful, that we have sin inwardly and sins outwardly. Hence, after our regeneration we still need to take Christ as our sin offering, as indicated in [link]1 John 1:8[/link], and as our trespass offering, as indicated in [link]1 John 1:9[/link]. See note [link]7[sup]3[/sup] in 1 John 1[/link].

verse.text: And he shall bring the bull to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting before Jehovah, and he shall [note]1[/note]lay his hand on the head of the bull and slaughter the bull [note]2[/note]before Jehovah.
verse.note: The laying of hands on the sin offering ([link]vv. 4[/link], [link]15[/link], [link]24[/link], [link]29[/link], [link]33[/link]) signifies the union of the offerer with the offering ([link]2 Cor. 5:14[/link]). See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].
That the sin offering was slaughtered before Jehovah signifies that Christ as the sin offering was slaughtered before God, that He as the sin offering was recognized by God.

verse.text: And the anointed priest shall take some of the [note]1[/note]blood of the bull and bring it [xref]a[/xref]into the Tent of Meeting,
verse.note: The blood of the sin offering had four kinds of effects: (1) Some of the blood was brought into the Tent of Meeting and sprinkled seven times before Jehovah in front of the veil of the Holy of Holies ([link]vv. 5-6[/link], [link]16-17[/link]), signifying that the blood of Christ has been brought into the Holy of Holies in the heavens for our redemption ([link]Heb. 9:12[/link]). (2) Some of the blood was put on the horns of the incense altar ([link]vv. 7a[/link], [link]18a[/link]), signifying that the redemption by Christ's blood is effective for us to contact God in prayer ([link]Heb. 10:19[/link]). (3) Some of the blood was put on the horns of the altar of burnt offering ([link]vv. 25a[/link], [link]30a[/link], [link]34a[/link]), signifying that the blood of Christ is effective for our redemption ([link]Eph. 1:7[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:18-19[/link]). (4) The rest of the blood was poured out at the base of the altar of burnt offering ([link]vv. 7b[/link], [link]18b[/link], [link]25b[/link], [link]30b[/link], [link]34b[/link]), signifying that the blood of Christ was poured out at the cross for the peace in our conscience, assuring us that we are redeemed and accepted by God ([link]Heb. 9:14[/link]).

verse.text: And the priest shall dip his finger in the blood and [xref]a[/xref]sprinkle some of the blood seven times before Jehovah in front of the veil of the sanctuary.

And the priest shall [xref]a[/xref]put some of the blood on the horns of the altar of fragrant incense before Jehovah, which is in the Tent of Meeting; and all [i]the rest of[/i] the blood of the bull he shall pour out at the [xref]b[/xref]base of the altar of burnt offering, which is at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting.
And all the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fat of the bull of the sin offering he shall take off from it: the fat that covers the inward parts and all the fat that is upon the inward parts,
verse.note: The burning of the fat and some of the inward parts of the sin offering on the altar of burnt offering ([link]vv. 8-10[/link], [link]19[/link], [link]26[/link], [link]31[/link], [link]35[/link]) signifies that the inward parts of Christ as the tender and sweet part are offered to God for His satisfaction that He may be willing to forgive us. It signifies further that God's acceptance of the sin offering is based on the burnt offering. Christ's absoluteness for God as the burnt offering qualified Him to be the sin offering. See [link]6:25[/link] and note 1.

chapter.verse: And the two kidneys and the fat that is on them, which is on the loins, and the appendage upon the liver, which he shall remove with the kidneys,

verse.text: As it is taken off from the ox of the sacrifice of peace offerings; and the priest shall [note]1[/note]burn them on the altar of burnt offering.
verse.note: For the two kinds of burning mentioned in [link]vv. 10[/link] and [link]12[/link], see note [link]13[sup]2[/sup] in Exo. 29[/link].

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]skin of the bull and all its flesh with its head and with its legs, and [i]the rest of[/i] its inward parts and its dung,
verse.note: The burning of the rest of the sin offering outside the camp ([link]vv. 11-12[/link], [link]21[/link]) signifies that Christ as the sin offering suffered reproach outside the Jewish religion as a human organization ([link]Heb. 13:11-13[/link]). The clean place where the sin offering was burned ([link]v. 12[/link]) signifies the place where Christ as the sin offering was rejected by man and where man's sin is cleared.

verse.text: That is, all [i]the rest of[/i] the bull he shall bring out to a clean place [xref]a[/xref]outside the camp, where the [note]1[/note]ashes are poured out, and burn it on wood with fire; where the ashes are poured out it shall be burned.
verse.note: I.e., of the burnt offering ([link]v. 10[/link]). The ashes of the burnt offering signify God's recognition and acceptance of the offerings. The ashes are also for the offerers' assurance and peace in their hearts concerning God's redemption accomplished for their sin.

chapter.verse: Now if the whole assembly of Israel errs, and the matter escapes the notice of the congregation, and they have done any of the things which Jehovah commanded not to be done and become guilty,

verse.text: And when the sin which they have committed becomes known, the congregation shall present a bull of the herd for a [xref]a[/xref]sin offering and bring it before the Tent of Meeting.
And the [note]1[/note]elders of the assembly shall lay their hands on the head of the bull before Jehovah, and one shall slaughter the bull before Jehovah.
verse.note: This signifies that the elders of the church may represent the church to offer Christ as its sin offering.

chapter.verse: And the anointed priest shall bring some of the blood of the bull to the Tent of Meeting,
And the priest shall dip his finger in the blood and sprinkle [i]it[/i] seven times before Jehovah in front of the veil.

And some of the blood he shall put upon the horns of the altar which is before Jehovah, that is, in the Tent of Meeting; and all [i]the rest of[/i] the blood he shall pour out at the base of the altar of burnt offering, which is at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting.
And all its fat he shall take off from it and burn [i]it[/i] on the altar.

verse.text: Thus shall he do with the bull; just as he did with the bull of the sin offering, so shall he do with this. And the priest shall make [xref]a[/xref]expiation for them, and they will be [xref]b[/xref]forgiven.

chapter.verse: And he shall bring the bull outside the camp and burn it as he burned the first bull; it is the sin offering for the congregation.

verse.text: When a ruler [xref]a[/xref]sins and does without intent any one of all the things which Jehovah his God has commanded not to be done and becomes guilty,
If his sin in which he has sinned is made known to him, he shall bring for his offering a [xref]a[/xref]male goat, without blemish.

chapter.verse: And he shall lay his hand on the head of the goat and slaughter it in the place where they slaughter the burnt offering before Jehovah; it is a sin offering.

And the priest shall take some of the blood of the sin offering with his finger and put [i]it[/i] on the horns of the altar of burnt offering; and [i]the rest of[/i] its blood he shall pour out at the base of the altar of burnt offering.

verse.text: And all its fat he shall burn on the altar, like the fat of the sacrifice of peace offerings. And the priest shall make expiation for him on account of his sin, and he will be [xref]a[/xref]forgiven.
And if any one of the common people [xref]a[/xref]sins without intent by doing any one of the things which Jehovah has commanded not to be done and becomes guilty,
If his sin which he has committed is made known to him, he shall bring for his offering a [xref]a[/xref]female goat, without blemish, for his sin which he has committed.

chapter.verse: And he shall lay his hand on the head of the sin offering and slaughter the sin offering in the place of the burnt offering.

And the priest shall take some of its blood with his finger and put [i]it[/i] on the horns of the altar of burnt offering, and all [i]the rest of[/i] its blood he shall pour out at the base of the altar.

And all its fat he shall remove, just as the fat is removed from the sacrifice of peace offerings; and the priest shall burn it on the altar for a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah. And the priest shall make expiation for him, and he will be forgiven.

verse.text: And if he brings a [xref]a[/xref]lamb as his offering for a sin offering, he shall bring it, a female without blemish.

chapter.verse: And he shall lay his hand on the head of the sin offering and slaughter it for a sin offering in the place where they slaughter the burnt offering.

And the priest shall take some of the blood of the sin offering with his finger and put [i]it[/i] on the horns of the altar of burnt offering, and all [i]the rest of[/i] its blood he shall pour out at the base of the altar.

verse.text: And all its fat he shall remove, just as the fat of the lamb is removed from the sacrifice of peace offerings; and the priest shall burn them on the altar upon Jehovah's offerings by fire. And the priest shall make expiation for him concerning his sin that he has committed, and he will be [xref]a[/xref]forgiven.

And if anyone [note]1[/note]sins when he hears the voice of [xref]a[/xref]adjuration and he is a witness, either seeing or knowing [i]about a matter,[/i] if he [note]2[/note]does not speak up, then he shall bear his iniquity.
verse.note: See note [link]3[sup]4[/sup], par. 1, in ch. 4[/link].

Not to testify the truth concerning what we know exposes the fact that we are not absolute for God. To fail in this matter is to be dishonest and unfaithful, unlike our God, who is faithful and honest. This verse actually deals with lying, which involves Satan, the father of lies ([link]John 8:44[/link]).

verse.text: Or if anyone touches any [xref]a[/xref]unclean thing, whether the [note]1[/note]carcass of an unclean animal or the carcass of unclean cattle or the carcass of unclean [note]2[/note]swarming things, and it escapes his [i]notice,[/i] and he is unclean, then he will be guilty.
verse.note: The word [i]carcass[/i] here signifies death. The different kinds of animals in this verse typify different kinds of people ([link]11:1-30[/link] and notes), and the carcasses of these animals signify that different kinds of spiritual death may spread among God's people in the church life. Regardless of its kind, death is unclean, filthy and defiling. Death is the most hateful thing in the eyes of God (cf. [link]1 Cor. 15:26[/link]). According to the typology in the Old Testament, death is more defiling than sin. See note [link]31[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 11[/link].
Or, creeping, crawling.

verse.text: Or if he touches the uncleanness of [note]1[/note]man, whatever his uncleanness is with which he becomes unclean, and it escapes his [i]notice,[/i] when he comes to know [i]it,[/i] then he will be guilty.
verse.note: The uncleanness of man here signifies the uncleanness of the natural man, the natural life. Everything that is discharged from the natural man and the natural life, whether good or evil, is unclean (cf. [link]Matt. 15:17-20[/link]; [link]16:21-25[/link]). See notes [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link] and [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 15[/link].

verse.text: Or if anyone [xref]a[/xref]swears [note]1[/note]rashly with his lips to do evil or to do good, whatever it is that a man utters rashly with an oath, and it escapes his [i]notice,[/i] when he comes to know [i]it,[/i] then he shall be guilty in one of these things.
verse.note: To speak rashly before God, expressing our opinion in a hasty, careless, and reckless way, indicates that we do not live for God and do not fear God (cf. [link]Matt. 17:24-27[/link]).

verse.text: And when he is guilty in one of these things, he shall [xref]a[/xref]confess that in which he has sinned;

And he shall bring his [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]trespass offering to Jehovah for his sin which he has committed, a [note]2[/note]female from the flock, a sheep or a goat, as a [note]3[/note]sin offering; and the priest shall make expiation for him on account of his sin.
verse.note: The trespass offering signifies Christ as the offering that resolves the problem of sins in our conduct. The experience of the trespass offering is the result of our enjoyment of Christ as the burnt offering, the meal offering, the peace offering, and the sin offering in our fellowship with the Triune God and in the divine light ([link]1 John 1:3-9[/link]). See note [link]3[sup]4[/sup], pars. 1 and 2, in ch. 4[/link]. Christ's being the meal offering in His perfect humanity qualifies Him to be the trespass offering (see note [link]37[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 12[/link]).

The trespass offering could be a female from the flock, a sheep or a goat, two turtledoves or two young pigeons, or the tenth part of an ephah of fine flour ([link]vv. 5-7[/link], [link]11[/link]). This signifies that the trespass offering for our outward sins, for which even a little fine flour is sufficient, is lighter than the sin offering, which needs a bull, or at least a lamb ([link]4:4[/link], [link]32[/link]).

The trespass offering here eventually becomes the sin offering ([link]vv. 6-8[/link], [link]11-12[/link]). This reminds us that our sins issue from the sin that dwells in us. Christ's redemption accomplished for our sin resolves the problem of sin in its two aspects — sin in our inward nature and sins in our outward conduct. See note [link]3[sup]4[/sup], par. 1, in ch. 4[/link].

verse.text: And if he cannot afford a lamb, then he shall bring [i]as[/i] his trespass offering to Jehovah for that in which he has sinned [xref]a[/xref]two turtledoves or two young pigeons, one for a [note]1[/note]sin offering and the other for a [note]1[/note]burnt offering.
verse.note: Two turtledoves or two young pigeons, one for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering, form a trespass offering. This signifies that the source of every trespass is the inward sin in our flesh, and the reason for a trespass is our not living absolutely for God. Thus, in dealing with our trespasses, we need to deal also with the source of our sins and the reason for our sins.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And he shall bring them to the priest, who shall present first that which is for the sin offering; and the [note]1[/note]priest shall wring off its head at the front of its neck but shall not sever [i]it;[/i]
verse.note: Lit., he.

verse.text: And he shall sprinkle some of the [note]1[/note]blood of the sin offering upon the side of the altar, and the rest of the blood shall be drained out at the [xref]a[/xref]base of the altar; it is a sin offering.
verse.note: The sprinkling of some of the blood of the trespass offering on the side of the altar ([link]v. 9a[/link]; [link]7:2[/link]) signifies the sprinkling of Christ's blood upon sinners ([link]1 Pet. 1:2[/link]). The rest of the blood being drained out at the base of the altar signifies that the blood of Christ is the base of God's forgiveness of sinners ([link]Matt. 26:28[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:7[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:22[/link]).

verse.text: And he shall offer the second as a burnt offering according to the ordinance. And the priest shall make expiation for him on account of his sin which he has committed, and he will be [xref]a[/xref]forgiven.

But if he cannot afford two turtledoves or two young pigeons, then he shall bring [i]as[/i] his offering for that which he has sinned, the [xref]a[/xref]tenth of an ephah of [note]1[/note]fine flour for a sin offering; he shall put no [note]2[/note]oil upon it nor put any [note]2[/note]frankincense upon it, for it is a sin offering.
verse.note: The fine flour here typifies the humanity of Jesus. This indicates that we commit sins not only because we have sin in our nature and not only because we are not absolute for God (see note [link]7[sup]1[/sup][/link]) but also because we do not have the humanity of Jesus. In His humanity Jesus has no sin in Him and is absolutely for God. The tenth part of an ephah of fine flour offered for a sin offering signifies that only a small portion of the humanity of Jesus is needed to kill the negative things within us and to supply our need.

Putting no oil or frankincense on the sin offering signifies that the Holy Spirit and the fragrance of Christ's resurrection are not involved with sin. Cf. notes [link chapter="2"]1[sup]3[/sup][/link] and [link]1[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: And he shall bring it to the priest, and the priest shall take [note]1[/note]a handful of it as its memorial portion and [note]2[/note]burn it on the altar, upon Jehovah's offerings by fire; it is a sin offering.
verse.note: Lit., his handful.

A handful of fine flour being burned on the altar upon Jehovah's offerings by fire indicates that the fine flour of the trespass offering for the forgiveness of our sins is based on the shedding of blood on the altar ([link]Heb. 9:22[/link]), and it signifies that the perfect Christ is our trespass offering based on the shedding of His blood on the cross ([link]Col. 1:20[/link]).

verse.text: And the priest shall make expiation for him concerning his sin that he has committed in any one of these things, and he will be forgiven. And [i]the [note]1[/note]rest[/i] shall be the priest's, like the meal offering.
verse.note: That the remainder of the fine flour for the trespass offering was the priest's signifies that the redeeming Christ is the serving one's food.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: If anyone acts unfaithfully and sins without intent in the holy things of Jehovah, then he shall bring his trespass offering to Jehovah, a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]ram without blemish out of the flock according to your valuation in silver by [xref]b[/xref]shekels, according to the shekel of the sanctuary, for a trespass offering.
verse.note: A ram without blemish out of the flock, according to the valuation by the shekel of the sanctuary, for a trespass offering ([link]vv. 15[/link], [link]18[/link]; [link]6:6[/link]) signifies that the Christ who is without sin and who measures up to the divine scale is qualified to be the trespass offering for our sins committed against the holy things of God, or against God, or against man in the trespasses listed in [link]vv. 15[/link], [link]17[/link], and [link]6:2-5[/link].

verse.text: And he shall make [note]1[/note]restitution for the holy thing in which he has sinned, and he shall add to it a [xref]a[/xref]fifth part of it and give it to the priest. And the priest shall make expiation for him with the ram of the trespass offering, and he will be forgiven.
verse.note: Making restitution and adding to it one-fifth more, here and in [link]6:4-5[/link], signifies that the one who offers the trespass offering should be righteous in material things according to the divine scale, standard, and measurement (cf. [link]Luke 19:8[/link]).

verse.text: And if anyone sins and does any one of the things which Jehovah has commanded not to be done, though he did not [xref]a[/xref]know, he is still guilty and shall bear his iniquity.

And he shall bring to the priest a [xref]a[/xref]ram without blemish out of the flock according to your valuation for a trespass offering. And the priest shall make expiation for him concerning the matter in which he erred without intent and did not know, and he will be forgiven.

chapter.verse: It is a trespass offering; he is certainly guilty before Jehovah.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: If anyone sins and [xref]a[/xref]acts unfaithfully against Jehovah and deceives his associate in regard to a [xref]b[/xref]deposit or a security, or by robbery, or has extorted from his associate,
Or has [xref]a[/xref]found a lost item and lied about it, if he has sworn falsely in any one of all these things a man may do, and sins thereby;

Then if he has sinned and is guilty, he shall [note]1[/note]restore that which he took by robbery, or the thing which he got by extortion, or the deposit which was entrusted to him, or the lost item which he found,
verse.note: See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: Or anything about which he has sworn falsely; he shall even restore it in full, and shall add to it a [xref]a[/xref]fifth part of it. He shall give it to the one to whom it belongs, on the day [note]1[/note]he is found guilty.
verse.note: Or, he presents his trespass offering.

verse.text: And he shall bring to Jehovah his trespass offering, a [xref]a[/xref]ram without blemish out of the flock according to your valuation for a trespass offering; to the priest [i]he shall bring it.[/i]
And the priest shall make expiation for him before Jehovah, and he will be [xref]a[/xref]forgiven for any of the things which he may have done so as to be guilty.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Command Aaron and his sons, saying, This is the [note]1[/note]law of the [xref]a[/xref]burnt offering: The burnt offering shall be on the [note]2[/note]hearth on the altar [note]3[/note]all night until the morning, and the fire of the altar shall be [note]4[/note]kept burning on it.
verse.note: The laws of the offerings are the ordinances and regulations regarding the offerings, i.e., regarding the enjoyment of Christ as the offerings. Since the reality of the offerings is Christ, the laws of the offerings correspond to the law of the life of Christ, which is the law of the Spirit of life ([link]Rom. 8:2[/link]). These laws indicate that even in the enjoyment of Christ we should not be lawless but should be regulated by the law of life (cf. [link]1 Cor. 9:26-27[/link]; [link]11:17[/link], [link]27-29[/link]; [link]Gal. 6:15-16[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:13-16[/link]).

The burnt offering being on the hearth signifies that anything offered as a burnt offering must be put on the place of offering to be burned. Those who offer themselves to God as a burnt offering must be on the place of burning and must be willing to become a heap of ashes.

[i]All night until the morning[/i] signifies that a burnt offering should remain in the place of burning through the dark night of this age until the morning, until the Lord Jesus comes again ([link]2 Pet. 1:19[/link]; [link]Mal. 4:2[/link]).

The continual burning of the fire on the altar ([link]vv. 9b[/link], [link]12a[/link], [link]13[/link]) signifies that God as the holy fire in the universe ([link]Heb. 12:29[/link]) is always ready to receive (burn) what is offered to Him as food, and that God's desire to accept what is offered to Him never ceases.

verse.text: And the priest shall put on his [xref]a[/xref]linen garment, and his linen trousers he shall put on his flesh; and he shall take up the [note]1[/note]ashes to which the fire has consumed the burnt offering on the altar, and he shall put them beside the altar.
verse.note: The ashes, the result of the burnt offering, are a sign of God's acceptance of the offering. The priest's putting on linen garments ([link]v. 10[/link]) signifies that fineness, purity, and cleanness are needed in handling the ashes. His putting on other garments to carry the ashes outside the camp ([link]v. 11[/link]) signifies that the handling of the ashes of the burnt offering was done in a stately manner.[br][br]Ashes indicate the result of Christ's death, which brings us to an end, i.e., to ashes ([link]Gal. 2:20a[/link]). The putting of the ashes beside the altar toward the east ([link]1:16[/link]), the side of the sunrise, is an allusion to resurrection. In relation to the burnt offering, the ashes are not the end, for Christ's death brings in resurrection ([link]Rom. 6:3-5[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 4:10-12[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:10-11[/link]). God has a high regard for these ashes, for eventually the ashes will become the New Jerusalem. Our being reduced to ashes brings us into the transformation of the Triune God ([link]Rom. 12:2[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:18[/link]). In resurrection we as ashes are transformed to become precious materials — gold, pearl, and precious stones — for the building of the New Jerusalem ([link]Rev. 21:18-21[/link]).

verse.text: Then he shall take off his garments and put on other garments and carry the ashes [xref]a[/xref]outside the camp to a clean place.

And the fire on the altar shall be kept burning on it; it must not go out. And the priest shall burn wood on it every [note]1[/note]morning, and he shall lay the [note]2[/note]burnt offering in order upon it and shall burn the [xref]a[/xref]fat of the [note]2[/note]peace offerings on it.
verse.note: The priest's burning wood on the altar every morning signifies the need of the serving one's cooperation with God's desire (see note [link]9[sup]4[/sup][/link]) by adding more fuel to the holy fire to strengthen the burning for the receiving of the burnt offering as God's food (cf. [link]Rom. 12:11[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 1:6[/link]). The morning signifies a new start for the burning.

See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link]. The burning of the burnt offering laid a foundation for the sweetness of the peace offering. This indicates that our offering ourselves to God as a continual burnt offering (cf. [link]Rom. 12:1[/link]) should be laid as a foundation for our sweet fellowship with God, signified by the burning of the fat of the peace offering. The burning of both the burnt offering and the peace offering signifies that both our absoluteness for God and our enjoyment of the Triune God should be a matter of burning.

chapter.verse: Fire shall be kept burning on the altar continually; it shall not go out.

verse.text: And this is the law of the [xref]a[/xref]meal offering: The sons of Aaron shall present it [note]1[/note]before Jehovah before the altar.
verse.note: [i]Before Jehovah[/i] signifies that the meal offering is offered to God in His presence, and [i]before the altar[/i] signifies that the meal offering is offered in relation to the redemption of Christ on the cross, the altar being a type of the cross ([link]Heb. 13:10[/link] and note).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And one shall take up from it his handful of the fine flour of the meal offering and of its oil and all the frankincense which is on the meal offering, and he shall burn [i]it[/i] on the altar for a satisfying fragrance as its memorial portion to Jehovah.
verse.note: For [link]v. 15[/link], see notes on [link]2:2[/link].

verse.text: And what is [xref]a[/xref]left of it [note]1[/note]Aaron and his sons may [xref]b[/xref]eat; it shall be eaten [note]2[/note]without leaven in a holy place; in the [note]2[/note]court of the Tent of Meeting they shall eat it.
verse.note: The meal offering is not common food. It is food only for the priests, i.e., only for those believers in the church life who are actual and practical priests, serving God in the priesthood of the gospel ([link]Rom. 1:9[/link]; [link]15:16[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:9[/link]).

Eating the priests' portion of the meal offering without leaven in a holy place signifies that we enjoy Christ as the life supply for our service without sin (leaven) in a separated, sanctified realm. Since the Tent of Meeting typifies the church (see note [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]), eating the meal offering in the court of the Tent of Meeting signifies that Christ should be enjoyed as our life supply in the sphere of the church life.

verse.text: It shall not be baked with [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]leaven. I have given it as their portion of My offerings by fire; it is most holy, like the [note]2[/note]sin offering and like the [note]2[/note]trespass offering.
verse.note: Not baking the meal offering with leaven signifies that our laboring on Christ to partake of Him as our life supply must be without sin.

The law of the meal offering refers us here to the sin offering and the trespass offering, signifying that if we would enjoy Christ as our life supply, we need to deal with the sin in our fallen nature and with the sins (trespasses) in our conduct. See note [link]3[sup]4[/sup], par. 1, in ch. 4[/link].

verse.text: Every [note]1[/note]male among the children of Aaron shall eat of it; it shall be a perpetual statute throughout your generations from Jehovah's offerings by fire; whoever touches them shall be holy.
verse.note: Those who partake of Christ as the life supply should be strong in the divine life (males) and also should be God's serving ones, God's priests (sons of Aaron).

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: This is the offering of Aaron and of his sons, which they shall present to Jehovah in the [note]1[/note]day when he is anointed: the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]tenth of an ephah of fine flour for a continual meal offering, half of it in the morning and half of it in the evening.
verse.note: The offering of a meal offering by Aaron and his sons on the day when Aaron was anointed signifies that the enjoyment of Christ as the life supply is related to the priestly service. Cf. note [link]35[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 7[/link].

The tenth of an ephah of fine flour for a continual meal offering, half in the morning and half in the evening, signifies that the top portion, the tenth part, of the enjoyment of Christ should be for God, and that this kind of enjoyment of Christ should continue in our priestly service.

verse.text: On a flat plate it shall be prepared with oil; when it is mixed, you shall bring it; as a meal offering of baked pieces you shall present [i]it[/i] as a satisfying [xref]a[/xref]fragrance to Jehovah.

chapter.verse: And the priest anointed to be in his place from among his sons shall prepare it. It shall be a perpetual statute; it shall be wholly burned to Jehovah.
And every meal offering of the priest shall be wholly burned; it must not be eaten.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Speak to Aaron and to his sons, saying, This is the law of the [xref]a[/xref]sin offering: In the [xref]b[/xref]place where the [note]1[/note]burnt offering is slaughtered the sin offering shall be slaughtered before Jehovah; it is [note]2[/note]most holy.
verse.note: The slaughtering of the sin offering before Jehovah in the place where the burnt offering was slaughtered signifies (1) that Christ as our sin offering was slain before God and (2) that Christ is the sin offering for us based on His being the burnt offering. Christ must be the burnt offering for God's satisfaction that He might be qualified to be our sin offering, and we must enjoy Christ as our burnt offering, as the One who is absolutely for God, before we can realize how sinful we are, i.e., how much we are for ourselves and not for God.
The sin offering being most holy signifies that Christ as our sin offering was most holy in that He dealt with sin in our nature intrinsically and entirely.

verse.text: The [note]1[/note]priest who offers it for sin shall [xref]a[/xref]eat it. In a holy place it shall be eaten, in the court of the Tent of Meeting.
verse.note: That the priest who offered the sin offering ate it in a holy place, in the court of the Tent of Meeting, signifies that the one who serves sinners with Christ as their sin offering enjoys Christ as the sin offering in a separated, sanctified realm, in the sphere of the church (cf. note [link]16[sup]2[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: Whatever touches its flesh shall be [note]1[/note]holy. And when any of its blood splashes on a garment, you shall [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]wash whatever was splashed in a holy place.
verse.note: This signifies that whoever touches Christ as the sin offering is separated and sanctified (holy) and will forsake sin and have his flesh dealt with, for Christ as the sin offering has dealt with sin and our sinful flesh on the cross ([link]Rom. 8:3[/link]).

This signifies that the daily walk (signified by the garment — [link]Isa. 64:6a[/link]) of the one who has received redemption through the blood of Christ as the sin offering should be dealt with in a separated, sanctified realm (cf. [link]Eph. 4:22-24[/link]). We should have regard for the blood of Christ and should never consider it common (cf. [link]Heb. 10:29[/link]).

verse.text: But the [xref]a[/xref]earthen vessel in which it is boiled shall be [note]1[/note]broken; and if it is boiled in a bronze vessel, it shall be [note]2[/note]scoured and rinsed in water.
verse.note: This signifies that the natural life of the one who, as an earthen vessel (cf. [link]2 Cor. 4:7[/link]), has a relationship with Christ as the sin offering should be broken.

This signifies that the one who has been enlightened and judged by the Spirit (likened to a bronze mirror — cf. note [link]18[sup]2[/sup] in Exo. 30[/link]) to be regenerated needs not to be broken but to be dealt with by being scoured and rinsed ([link]1 Cor. 6:11[/link]; [link]Titus 3:5[/link]).

verse.text: Every [note]1[/note]male among the priests may eat of it; it is most holy.
verse.note: This signifies that all the stronger ones (males) can enjoy Christ as the most holy sin offering in ministering Christ as the sin offering to sinners.

verse.text: And any sin offering of which some of the blood is brought into the Tent of Meeting to make [note]1[/note]expiation in the Holy Place shall not be eaten; it shall be burned with fire.
verse.note: The expiation mentioned here was made in the Holy of Holies ([link]16:27[/link]), where God was. This verse signifies that Christ as the sin offering that dealt with our sin and with our sinful nature on the cross to accomplish God's redemption for us is wholly for God's enjoyment, and we have no share in it. However, in our ministering Christ as the sin offering to sinners, we can share in Him ([link]v. 26[/link]). Concerning Christ as the sin offering, both God and the serving priests have a portion, the best portion being for God's enjoyment.

verse.text: And this is the law of the [xref]a[/xref]trespass offering; it is most [note]1[/note]holy;
verse.note: That the trespass offering (like the meal offering and the sin offering — [link]6:17[/link], [link]25[/link]) was most holy signifies that Christ as our trespass offering is most holy in dealing with the sins in our conduct. Since the trespass offering refers us to the sin offering, reminding us that sin is in our flesh ([link]1 John 1:7-8[/link]), and to the burnt offering, reminding us that we commit sins because we are not absolute for God (see note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link]), we must not take it in a light way; rather, we must apply Christ as our trespass offering in a holy way.

verse.text: In the [note]1[/note]place where they slaughter the [xref]a[/xref]burnt offering they shall slaughter the trespass offering, and its [note]2[/note]blood he shall sprinkle on and around the altar.
verse.note: The trespass offering being slaughtered where the burnt offering was slaughtered indicates that the trespass offering is based on the burnt offering, and it signifies that Christ is the trespass offering for us based on His being the burnt offering. Christ's being absolute for God is the base for His being both our sin offering ([link]6:25[/link]) and our trespass offering. This reminds us and strengthens us, when we take Christ as our trespass offering, to take Him also as our burnt offering so that in Him, with Him, and through Him we may be absolute for God.
Cf. note [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: And he shall present from it all its [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fat: the fat tail, and the fat that covers the inward parts,
verse.note: See note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 4[/link]. Cf. [link]v. 7a[/link].

verse.text: And the two [xref]a[/xref]kidneys and the fat that is on them, which is on the loins, and the appendage upon the liver, which he shall remove with the kidneys.

chapter.verse: And the priest shall burn them on the altar as an offering by fire to Jehovah; it is a trespass offering.

verse.text: Every [note]1[/note]male among the priests may [xref]a[/xref]eat of it; it shall be eaten in a [note]1[/note]holy place; it is most holy.
verse.note: Cf. [link]v. 7[/link] and notes [link chapter="6"]26[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]29[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].

verse.text: The trespass offering is like the sin offering; there is [note]1[/note]one law for them: The [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]priest who makes expiation with it shall have it.
verse.note: This signifies that sin and trespasses (sins) are of the same category. All are sin in its totality. See note [link]3[sup]4[/sup], par. 1, in ch. 4[/link].
Cf. [link]6:26[/link] and note.

verse.text: And the priest who presents anyone's burnt offering, that priest shall have for himself the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]skin of the burnt offering which he has presented.
verse.note: This signifies that Christ's outward expression of beauty (the skin) is ascribed to the serving one who offers Christ as the burnt offering. It signifies further that the one who ministers Christ as the burnt offering shares and enjoys Christ's covering, protection, and preserving power.

verse.text: And every meal offering that is baked in an oven and everything that is made in a pot or on a flat plate shall belong to the [note]1[/note]priest who presents it.
verse.note: This signifies that the one who ministers Christ as the suffering One partakes of and enjoys such a Christ. See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 2[/link].

chapter.verse: And every other meal offering, mingled with oil or dry, shall be for all the sons of Aaron, to each alike.

verse.text: Now this is the law of the sacrifice of [xref]a[/xref]peace offerings that one shall present to [note]1[/note]Jehovah:
verse.note: See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].
