verse.text: If he presents it for a thanksgiving, then he shall present with the [note]1[/note]sacrifice of thanksgiving [xref]a[/xref]unleavened cakes mingled with oil and unleavened wafers anointed with oil and saturated cakes of fine flour mingled with oil.
verse.note: The presenting of the different kinds of meal offerings with the peace offering for thanksgiving signifies that the Christ who is the meal offering in our enjoyment of Him in His conduct is our peace offering, crucified with the shedding of His blood on the cross ([link]Col. 1:20[/link]), in our thanksgiving to God. For the significance of the items of the meal offering, see notes on [link]ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: With cakes of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]leavened bread he shall present his offering with the sacrifice of his peace offerings for thanksgiving.
verse.note: The offering of the peace offering for thanksgiving with leavened bread signifies that the offerer, although he enjoys Christ as the One who is without sin, still has sin and is therefore in a weak condition. For this reason, the peace offering for thanksgiving is the weakest kind of peace offering.

verse.text: And from [note]1[/note]it he shall present one out of each offering as a [xref]a[/xref]heave offering to Jehovah; it shall belong to the priest who sprinkles the blood of the peace offerings.
verse.note: I.e., from the meal offering. This signifies (1) that Christ as the meal offering in all His aspects is offered to God as the One in ascension (a heave offering) and (2) that such a Christ is partaken of and enjoyed as food by the one who ministers Christ as the peace offering.

verse.text: And the flesh of the [xref]a[/xref]sacrifice of his peace offerings for thanksgiving shall be eaten on the day of his offering; he shall [note]1[/note]not leave any of it until the morning.
verse.note: This signifies that the maintaining power of the peace offering for thanksgiving is rather small, that it has to be fully enjoyed on the day it is offered, and that our experience and enjoyment of Christ in this aspect should be fresh daily. The peace offering for a vow or a freewill offering ([link]v. 16[/link]) signifies a stronger enjoyment of Christ that can last longer.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]But if the sacrifice of his offering is a vow or a freewill offering, it shall be eaten on the day that he presents his sacrifice, and on the next day what remains of it shall be eaten;

chapter.verse: But what remains of the flesh of the sacrifice on the third day shall be burned with fire.

verse.text: And if any of the flesh of the sacrifice of his peace offerings is eaten at all on the third day, it will not be accepted, neither will it be reckoned to the one who presents it; it will be an [note]1[/note]abomination, and the person who eats of it shall bear his own [note]1[/note]iniquity.
verse.note: This signifies that our enjoyment of Christ in its oldness is abhorrent to God and is not right with Him.

verse.text: And flesh that touches any [note]1[/note]unclean thing shall not be eaten; it shall be burned with fire. And as for [i]other[/i] flesh, anyone who is [note]1[/note]clean may eat [i]such[/i] flesh.
verse.note: This signifies that the enjoyment of Christ as our peace should be kept from all uncleanness and also that Christ as the peace offering should be eaten by a clean person ([link]1 Cor. 11:28[/link]).

verse.text: But the person who eats of the flesh of the sacrifice of peace offerings, which belong to Jehovah, with his uncleanness upon him, that person shall be [note]1[/note]cut off from his people.
verse.note: The word in [link]vv. 20-21[/link] signifies that the unclean person who partakes of Christ as His peace, as at the Lord's table ([link]1 Cor. 10:16-17[/link]), shall be put aside from the fellowship of the enjoyment of Christ. Such a sinful person should be removed from the fellowship at the Lord's table (cf. [link]1 Cor. 5:13b[/link]).

chapter.verse: And when anyone touches any unclean thing, the uncleanness of man or an unclean beast or any unclean abomination, and eats of the flesh of the sacrifice of peace offerings, which belong to Jehovah, that person shall be cut off from his people.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Speak to the children of Israel, saying, You shall not eat any [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fat of an ox or of a sheep or of a goat.
verse.note: This signifies that when we practice our priestly service, we should be concerned about God's food and should not eat the fat, which is God's portion ([link]3:3-5[/link]). See note [link]25[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And the fat of [i]an animal[/i] that dies and the fat of [i]an animal[/i] which is torn by [i]beasts[/i] may be put to any [i]other[/i] use, but [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]you shall by no means eat it.
verse.note: This signifies that the dirtiness of death spoils the significance of God's enjoyment of Christ. God hates death and does not want to look upon anything related to it.

verse.text: For whoever eats the [note]1[/note]fat of a beast from which someone presents an offering by fire to Jehovah, indeed the person who eats it shall be cut off from his people.
verse.note: This signifies that we who enjoy Christ as our peace offering should keep the excellent part of the person of Christ (the fat) for God that we might not be put aside from the fellowship of the enjoyment of Christ (at the Lord's table).

verse.text: And you shall not eat any [note]1[/note]blood, either of bird or of beast, in any of your dwelling places.
verse.note: See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link]. Anyone who regards the blood of Jesus as a common thing will be put aside from the fellowship of the enjoyment of Christ ([link]v. 27[/link]).

verse.text: Any person who eats any [xref]a[/xref]blood, that person shall be cut off from his people.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Speak to the children of Israel, saying, He who presents the sacrifice of his peace offerings to Jehovah shall bring his offering to Jehovah out of the sacrifice of his peace offerings.
verse.note: The word in [link]vv. 29-34[/link] signifies that we who take Christ as our peace offering should offer the excellent part of Christ (the fat) to God for His satisfaction, the loving part of Christ in His resurrection (the breast as a wave offering) and the strong part of Christ in His ascension (the right thigh as a heave offering) being for the serving ones' enjoyment. In our enjoyment of Christ as the peace offering, God has allotted the loving capacity and the strengthening power of Christ to us, the New Testament priests ([link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link], [link]9[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:5-6[/link]; [link]5:10[/link]), as our eternal portion for our enjoyment in serving God. See notes [link book="Exo." chapter="29"]26[sup]1[/sup][/link] through [link]28[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 29[/link].

verse.text: His own hands shall bring Jehovah's offerings by fire; the fat with the breast he shall bring, that the breast may be waved as a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]wave offering before Jehovah.
verse.note: See note [link]24[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 29[/link].

verse.text: And the priest shall burn the fat on the altar, but the [xref]a[/xref]breast shall be for Aaron and for his sons.

chapter.verse: And the right thigh you shall give to the priest for a heave offering out of the sacrifices of your peace offerings.
The one among the sons of Aaron who presents the blood of the peace offerings and the fat shall have the right thigh as [i]his[/i] portion.

For the breast of the wave offering and the thigh of the heave offering I have taken from the children of Israel out of the sacrifices of their peace offerings and have given them to Aaron the priest and to his sons for a perpetual statute [i]to be observed[/i] by the children of Israel.

verse.text: This is the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]anointing [i]portion[/i] of Aaron and the anointing [i]portion[/i] of his sons, from Jehovah's offerings by fire, in the day when he presented them to serve Jehovah as priests,
verse.note: This signifies that God's allotting of Christ's loving capacity and strengthening power to us is related to God's anointing us for our priesthood. By such an allotment we can love God and stand to serve Him as priests.

chapter.verse: Which Jehovah commanded to be given them from the children of Israel in the day that He anointed them. It shall be a perpetual statute throughout their generations.

verse.text: This is the [xref]a[/xref]law of the burnt offering [i]and[/i] of the meal offering and of the sin offering and of the trespass offering and of the [note]1[/note]consecration and of the sacrifice of [note]2[/note]peace offerings,
verse.note: Lit., filling (of hands). So also throughout the book, unless otherwise noted. The consecration here is not a sixth offering; rather, the five offerings are for the consecration of Aaron and his sons to serve God as priests (cf. [link]Exo. 29[/link] and notes). At the time of consecration God assigned these offerings, in different aspects, for the priests' enjoyment. The word in [link]vv. 37-38[/link] signifies that our consecration for the priesthood must be with the all-inclusive Christ as all the five offerings and according to their regulations.

The sequence of the five offerings in [link]1:1-6:7[/link] is according to our practical experience (see notes [link chapter="3"]1[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link] and note [link]3[sup]4[/sup], par. 3, in ch. 4[/link]), whereas the sequence in [link]6:8-7:38[/link] is according to the total picture of God's economy. In God's heart and in His desire God would have Christ to be four kinds of offerings to us — the burnt offering, the meal offering, the sin offering, and the trespass offering — that we may enjoy Christ as peace with God in every way. Christ's being these four offerings consummates in peace between God and God's people, and this peace is simply Christ Himself ([link]Eph. 2:14[/link]). Eventually, the enjoyment of Christ as all the offerings, issuing in the peace offering, will consummate in the New Jerusalem as the ultimate peace offering ([i]Jerusalem[/i] means the [i]foundation of peace[/i]), in which we will enjoy the Triune God as peace ([link]Phil. 4:7[/link], [link]9[/link]) for eternity. Thus, the ordinances concerning the offerings are a record of the totality of God's economy.

chapter.verse: Which Jehovah commanded Moses on Mount Sinai, on the day that He commanded the children of Israel to present their offerings to Jehovah in the wilderness of Sinai.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Take [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Aaron and his sons with him, and the [xref]b[/xref]garments and the [xref]c[/xref]anointing oil and the bull of the sin offering and the two rams and the basket of unleavened bread;
verse.note: The record in this chapter of the consecration of Aaron and his sons indicates that the offerings in [link]chs. 1-7[/link] are for the consecration, or ordination, of the priests. Whatever Christ is to us and does for us, as typified by the offerings, is to constitute us priests ([link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link], [link]9[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:6[/link]; [link]5:10[/link]). This constitution of Christ in us through our enjoyment of Him as the offerings is the divine ordination. Cf. [link]Exo. 29[/link] and notes.

verse.text: And gather all the assembly at the [note]1[/note]entrance of the Tent of Meeting.
verse.note: The consecration of Aaron and his sons at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting signifies that our consecration for the priesthood is not only before God but also for the church.

chapter.verse: And Moses did just as Jehovah had commanded him, and the assembly was gathered at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting.
And Moses said to the assembly, This is what Jehovah has commanded to be done.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And Moses brought Aaron and his sons near and [note]1[/note]washed them with water.
verse.note: This signifies that for our consecration for the priesthood, we need to be washed by the Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 6:11[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And he [note]1[/note]put the [xref]b[/xref]tunic upon him and girded him with the girding sash and clothed him with the robe and put the ephod upon him, and he girded him with the skillfully woven band of the ephod, and with it he bound [i]it[/i] to him.
verse.note: The clothing of Aaron with the high priest's garments ([link]vv. 7-9[/link]) signifies that Christ as our High Priest is adorned with all the excellencies of His divine attributes and human virtues. See notes on [link]Exo. 28[/link].

verse.text: And he placed the breastplate upon him, and in the breastplate he put the [xref]a[/xref]Urim and the Thummim.
And he placed the turban on his head, and on the turban, on its front, he placed the [xref]a[/xref]golden plate, the holy crown, just as Jehovah had commanded Moses.
And Moses took the anointing oil and [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]anointed the tabernacle and all that was in it, and [note]2[/note]sanctified them.
verse.note: Moses' anointing of the tabernacle, the altar, and the laver, with all their utensils, to sanctify them ([link]vv. 10-11[/link]) signifies that Christ and the church (the tabernacle), the cross (the altar), and the washing of the Spirit (the laver) are related to the New Testament priesthood for the priests' sanctification. See notes [link]9[sup]2[/sup] in Exo. 25[/link], [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 27[/link], and [link]18[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 30[/link].[br][br]The anointing brings the Triune God compounded with Christ's humanity, human living, death, resurrection, and ascension to the priests and to the church life. This indicates strongly that the anointing of the priesthood is to make God one with us, for the anointing signifies that whatever God is, is doing, and will do are ours (see notes [link book="Exo." chapter="30"]25[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 30[/link]). In the consecration of the priests the sin offering and the burnt offering immediately followed the anointing ([link]vv. 14-21[/link]). These offerings remind us of who and what we are, and of what we should be and yet are not. See notes [link]14[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]18[sup]1[/sup][/link].
God's ordaining us to be priests is a matter of sanctification, a matter of being separated, of being made holy ([link]Exo. 29:1[/link] and note 1).

chapter.verse: And he sprinkled some of it on the altar seven times, and anointed the altar and all its vessels, and the laver and its base, to sanctify them.

verse.text: And he poured some of the [xref]a[/xref]anointing oil on [note]1[/note]Aaron's head and anointed him, to sanctify him.
verse.note: This signifies that Christ as our High Priest, typified here by Aaron, was anointed by God for His sanctification ([link]Luke 4:18[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:9[/link]; cf. [link]Psa. 133:2[/link]).

verse.text: And Moses [xref]a[/xref]brought Aaron's sons near, and [note]1[/note]clothed them with tunics and girded them with girding sashes and bound high hats on them, just as Jehovah had commanded Moses.
verse.note: Moses' clothing the sons of Aaron with priestly garments signifies that the believers as New Testament priests are adorned with Christ's divine attributes mingled with His human virtues ([link]Exo. 28:2[/link] and notes). Our outward expression should be Christ's divine attributes expressed in human virtues. See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in John 13[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And he brought the [note]1[/note]bull of the [note]2[/note]sin offering, and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on the head of the bull of the sin offering.
verse.note: The bull of the sin offering signifies the stronger and richer Christ as our sin offering to deal with the flesh, the old man, indwelling sin, Satan, the world, and the ruler of the world, for the assuming of our New Testament priesthood (see note [link]3[sup]4[/sup], par. 3, in ch. 4[/link]). This reminds us that in ourselves we are a constitution of all the aforementioned negative things and need to offer Christ daily as our sin offering for our priesthood (see note [link]36[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 29[/link]).
For the details of the offering of the sin offering in [link]vv. 14-17[/link], see notes on [link]4:4-12[/link].

chapter.verse: And he slaughtered [i]it;[/i] and Moses took the blood and put [i]some of it[/i] on and around the horns of the altar with his finger, and purified the altar, and poured out [i]the rest of[/i] the blood at the base of the altar and sanctified it, to make expiation for it.
And he took all the fat that was on the inward parts and the appendage of the liver and the two kidneys and their fat, and Moses burned [i]them[/i] on the altar.

verse.text: But the bull and its skin and its flesh and its dung he burned with fire [xref]a[/xref]outside the camp, just as Jehovah had commanded Moses.
[xref]a[/xref]And he presented the [note]1[/note]ram of the [note]2[/note]burnt offering, and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on the head of the ram.
verse.note: The ram of the burnt offering signifies the strong Christ as our burnt offering for the assuming of our New Testament priesthood. This offering reminds us that as serving ones we must be absolute for God, yet we are not. Thus, we need to take Christ daily as our burnt offering for our priestly service ([link]6:12[/link]).
For the details concerning the offering of the burnt offering in [link]vv. 18-21[/link], see notes on [link]1:4-9[/link].

chapter.verse: And he slaughtered [i]it,[/i] and Moses sprinkled the blood on and around the altar.
And he cut the ram into its pieces, and Moses burned the head and the pieces and the fat.

And the inward parts and the legs he washed with water, and Moses burned the whole ram on the altar. It was a burnt offering for a satisfying fragrance; it was an offering by fire to Jehovah, just as Jehovah had commanded Moses.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And he presented the other ram, the [note]1[/note]ram of consecration, and Aaron and his sons laid their hands on the head of the ram.
verse.note: This ram signifies the strong Christ for our consecration in the assuming of our priesthood. For details concerning the offering of the ram of consecration in [link]vv. 22-32[/link], see [link]Exo. 29:19-34[/link] and notes.

verse.text: And he slaughtered [i]it,[/i] and Moses took some of its blood and put [i]it[/i] on the [xref]a[/xref]lobe of Aaron's right [note]1[/note]ear and on the thumb of his right [note]1[/note]hand and on the big toe of his right [note]1[/note]foot.
verse.note: See note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 29[/link].

chapter.verse: And he brought Aaron's sons near, and Moses put some of the blood on the lobe of their right ear and on the thumb of their right hand and on the big toe of their right foot; and Moses sprinkled [i]the rest of[/i] the blood on and around the altar.
And he took the fat and the fat tail and all the fat that was on the inward parts, and the appendage of the liver, and the two kidneys and their fat, and the right thigh;

And from the basket of unleavened bread that was before Jehovah, he took one unleavened cake and one cake of oiled bread and one wafer, and placed [i]them[/i] on the fat portions and on the right thigh.
And he put all [i]these[/i] in the palms of Aaron and in the palms of his sons, and he waved them as a wave offering before Jehovah.

And Moses took them from their palms and burned [i]them[/i] on the altar upon the burnt offering. They were an [i]offering[/i] of consecration for a satisfying fragrance; it was an offering by fire to Jehovah.
And Moses took the breast and waved it as a wave offering before Jehovah; it was Moses' portion of the ram of consecration, just as Jehovah had commanded Moses.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And Moses took some of the [note]1[/note]anointing oil and some of the blood that was on the altar and sprinkled [i]it[/i] on Aaron, on his garments, and on his sons and on his sons' garments with him; and he sanctified Aaron, his garments, and his sons and his sons' garments with him.
verse.note: See note [link]21[sup]1[/sup], par. 1, in Exo. 29[/link].

verse.text: And Moses said to Aaron and to his sons, [xref]a[/xref]Boil the flesh at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, and eat it there with the bread that is in the basket of consecration, just as I commanded, saying, Aaron and his sons shall eat it.

chapter.verse: And what is left of the flesh and of the bread you shall burn with fire.

verse.text: And you shall not go out from the entrance of the Tent of Meeting for [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]seven days, until the days of your [xref]b[/xref]consecration are fulfilled, for it will take [note]2[/note]seven days to consecrate you.
verse.note: The consecrating priests remaining at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting for seven days for their expiation ([link]vv. 33-36[/link]) signifies that our assuming of the New Testament priesthood should be thorough and complete (signified by the seven days) for our propitiation (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 16[/link]) at our entering the church life.
The process of consecrating Aaron and his sons was repeated for seven days, signifying that we need to remember all the things involved in our consecration and ordination as New Testament priests.

chapter.verse: As has been done this day, so Jehovah has commanded to do, to make expiation for you.

verse.text: And at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting you shall stay day and night seven days, and keep the charge of Jehovah, that you may not [note]1[/note]die; for so I have been commanded.
verse.note: The solemnity of the consecration and ordination of the priests is indicated here. This warns us that we should not enter into the New Testament priesthood and into the enjoyment of Christ in a careless way (cf. [link]1 Cor. 11:27-29[/link]).

chapter.verse: And Aaron and his sons did all the things which Jehovah had commanded through Moses.

verse.text: Now on the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]eighth day Moses called Aaron and his sons and the elders of Israel;
verse.note: The eighth day, the first day of a new week, signifies resurrection ([link]Mark 16:9a[/link]). That Moses initiated the priestly service on the eighth day indicates that all the priestly service must be in resurrection, i.e., in Christ as the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45b[/link]), who is the reality of resurrection ([link]John 11:25[/link]).

verse.text: And he said to Aaron, Take for [note]1[/note]yourself a calf of the herd for a [xref]a[/xref]sin offering and a ram for a burnt offering, without blemish, and present [i]them[/i] before Jehovah.
verse.note: Aaron's offering the sin offering and the burnt offering to make expiation for himself first ([link]v. 7[/link]) signifies that he, as a sinful person, needed to take Christ as his sin offering and burnt offering so that his situation with God might be appeased and he might serve God as a priest. See notes [link chapter="8"]14[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]18[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link].[br][br]Aaron's preparing the sin offering and the burnt offering also typifies Christ's offering Himself as a sin offering for the redemption of God's people and as a burnt offering for God's people to be God's satisfaction ([link]Heb. 9:14[/link]; [link]10:5-10[/link]). Moreover, it signifies that whatever Christ as our High Priest did, He did for us, that we might be redeemed from sin and made God's satisfaction. By our being one with Christ in His death, we are redeemed in Him ([link]Eph. 1:7[/link]), and by Christ's being one with us in His resurrection, He lives in us that we may live Him for God's satisfaction ([link]Gal. 2:20[/link]; [link]Phil. 1:20-21a[/link]).

verse.text: Then to the children of Israel you shall speak, saying, Take a [xref]a[/xref]male goat for a sin offering; and a calf and a lamb, both a year old without blemish, for a burnt offering;
And an ox and a ram for peace offerings, to sacrifice before Jehovah; and a [xref]a[/xref]meal offering mingled with oil; for today Jehovah will [xref]b[/xref]appear to you.

chapter.verse: So they brought what Moses had commanded before the Tent of Meeting, and all the assembly came near and stood before Jehovah.
And Moses said, This is what Jehovah has commanded you to do, and the glory of Jehovah shall appear to you.

verse.text: Then Moses said to Aaron, Come near to the altar and offer your [xref]a[/xref]sin offering and your burnt offering, and make expiation for [xref]b[/xref]yourself and for the people; and make the offering of the people and make expiation for them, just as Jehovah has commanded.

chapter.verse: So Aaron came near to the altar and slaughtered the calf of the sin offering, which was for himself.

verse.text: And the sons of Aaron presented the blood to him, and he dipped his finger in the blood and put [i]it[/i] on the [xref]a[/xref]horns of the altar, and [i]the rest of[/i] the blood he poured out at the base of the altar.
But the [xref]a[/xref]fat and the kidneys and the appendage of the liver of the sin offering he burned on the altar, just as Jehovah had commanded Moses.
And the [xref]a[/xref]flesh and the skin he burned with fire [xref]b[/xref]outside the camp.
[xref]a[/xref]Then he slaughtered the burnt offering; and Aaron's sons handed the blood to him, and he sprinkled it on and around the altar.

chapter.verse: And they handed the burnt offering to him, piece by piece, and the head, and he burned [i]them[/i] on the altar.
And he washed the inward parts and the legs and burned [i]them[/i] upon the burnt offering on the altar.

verse.text: Then he presented the [note]1[/note]people's offering, and took the goat of the sin offering which was for the people and slaughtered it and [xref]a[/xref]offered it for sin, like the first.
verse.note: Aaron's offering of the sin offering, the burnt offering, and the meal offering for the people ([link]vv. 15-17[/link]) signifies that Christ offered Himself as our sin offering to deal with our sin, as our burnt offering to satisfy God, and as our meal offering to be God's food and also our food.

chapter.verse: And he presented the burnt offering and offered it according to the ordinance.

verse.text: Then he presented the [xref]a[/xref]meal offering and filled his hand with some of it and burned [i]it[/i] on the altar, besides the burnt offering of the morning.

Then he slaughtered the ox and the ram, the sacrifice of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]peace offerings which was for the people; and Aaron's sons handed the blood to him, which he sprinkled on and around the altar.
verse.note: Aaron's offering of the peace offering for the people ([link]vv. 18-21[/link]) signifies that Christ offered Himself as our peace offering that we and God may enjoy Him as peace. When we apply Christ as our sin offering (including the trespass offering), burnt offering, and meal offering ([link]vv. 15-17[/link]), we enter into peace, which is Christ Himself ([link]Eph. 2:14[/link]). We enjoy this peace primarily at the Lord's table (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link]).

chapter.verse: And the fat portions of the ox and of the ram, the fat tail, and [i]the fat[/i] which covers [i]the inward parts[/i] and the kidneys and the appendage of the liver —
These fat portions they then put on the breasts; and he burned the fat portions on the altar.

verse.text: And the breasts and the right thigh Aaron waved for a [xref]a[/xref]wave offering before Jehovah, just as Moses had commanded.
And Aaron lifted up his hands toward the people and [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]blessed them, and he came down from offering the sin offering and the burnt offering and the peace offerings.
verse.note: Aaron's blessing of the people and then coming down from offering the offerings signifies that Christ as our High Priest, after His crucifixion, blessed us in His resurrection ([link]Luke 24:50[/link]). The Lord's presence with us in His resurrection is His blessing ([link]Matt. 28:20[/link]). This blessing comes to us through our applying Him as all the offerings.

verse.text: And Moses and Aaron went into the Tent of Meeting. And they came out and [note]1[/note]blessed the people; and the glory of Jehovah [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]appeared to all the people.
verse.note: Moses and Aaron's entering into the Tent of Meeting and coming out to bless the people signifies that Christ as our Prince (Moses) and High Priest (Aaron) entered into the heavens to be our kingly Priest ([link]Acts 5:31[/link]; [link]Heb. 4:14[/link]; [link]7:1[/link]) and will come out of heaven to bless us. For the Jews, the blessing of Moses and Aaron is still in effect and will continue until the entire house of Israel repents and turns to the Savior at His second coming ([link]Zech. 12:10[/link]; [link]Rom. 11:26[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:7[/link]).

The appearing of God (God's presence) and of God's glory (God's expression) ([link]vv. 4b[/link], [link]6b[/link]) is the issue of our priestly service in the enjoyment of Christ as all the offerings with God according to God's regulations.

verse.text: Then [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fire came forth from before Jehovah and consumed the burnt offering and the fat portions on the altar. And when all the people saw [i]it,[/i] they gave a ringing shout and fell on their faces.
verse.note: The fire signifies that God's holiness as a consuming fire ([link]Heb. 12:29[/link]) accepts our offerings by burning. The consuming fire of suffering always follows God's blessing ([link]v. 23[/link]), as a sign that God has accepted what we have offered to Him in Christ and with Christ (cf. [link]Acts 7:55-59[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:6[/link]). Cf. [link]10:1-2[/link] and note [link]2[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]Nadab and Abihu, the sons of Aaron, each took his censer, and put fire in them and laid incense on it, and they presented [note]2[/note]strange [xref]a[/xref]fire before Jehovah, which He had not commanded them.
verse.note: The negative situation involving Nadab and Abihu, Aaron's sons, took place not long after, and probably at the end of, the day of glory and blessing described in [link]9:22-24[/link].

The strange fire offered by Nadab and Abihu was common fire, not holy fire. It was not fire from the altar ([link]16:12[/link]), which came forth from God, from heaven ([link]9:24[/link]), but fire from man, from the earth, with no base of expiation. Strange fire signifies man's natural enthusiasm, natural affection, natural strength, and natural ability offered to God. Nadab and Abihu did something for God, but they did it in a natural way. Hence, God judged this offering by consuming the two priests ([link]v. 2[/link]). This is a strong warning showing us that in touching the divine things we need to apply the cross to our natural life. Otherwise, our careless touching of the holy things of God will bring in spiritual deadness, and may even result in physical death ([link]Acts 5:1-11[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 11:27-32[/link]; [link]1 John 5:16[/link]), as a judgment from the holy God. See notes [link]7[sup]2[/sup] in 2 Sam. 6[/link] and [link]29[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 12[/link].

verse.text: And [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fire came out from before Jehovah and consumed them, and they died before Jehovah.
verse.note: This fire was the opposite of common fire. It was from God, not from man, and it was from the heavens, not from the earth. Furthermore, it was for judgment, not for acceptance (cf. [link]9:24[/link]).

verse.text: Then Moses said to Aaron, This is what Jehovah spoke, saying,[br/][xref]a[/xref]In those who come near to Me I will be [note]1[/note]sanctified, / And before all the people I will be [note]1[/note]glorified.[br/]And Aaron was silent.
verse.note: On God's side the fire of His judgment ([link]v. 2[/link]) also sanctifies Him in His serving ones who come near to Him and glorifies Him before His people.

verse.text: And Moses called Mishael and Elzaphan, the sons of Uzziel the uncle of Aaron, and said to them, Come near; carry your brothers from before the sanctuary to the [note]1[/note]outside of the camp.
verse.note: This signifies that the deadness of unholiness should be kept away from the sphere of God's holiness and also from the community, the fellowship, of God's people.

chapter.verse: So they came near and carried them in their tunics to the outside of the camp, just as Moses had said.

verse.text: Then Moses said to Aaron and to his sons Eleazar and Ithamar, Do not [note]1[/note]dishevel the hair of your heads, and do not [note]1[/note]tear your garments, that you may not die and that He may not be angry with all the assembly. But let your brothers, the whole house of Israel, [note]2[/note]weep for the burning which Jehovah has kindled.
verse.note: This signifies that even God's judgment of death upon the relatives should not be an excuse for His serving ones to be disorderly in their subjection to the headship of Christ (cf. [link]1 Cor. 11:10[/link], [link]15[/link]) and to break the perfection of their conduct (cf. notes [link book="Exo." chapter="28"]2[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in Exo. 28[/link]), that they might not suffer deadness in their spiritual life and cause God to be unhappy with His people.
This signifies that the whole body of God's people should grieve over the judgment of God upon the unholiness of His serving ones.

verse.text: And you shall not go out from the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, lest you die; for the [xref]a[/xref]anointing oil of Jehovah is upon you. And they did according to the word of Moses.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Aaron, saying,

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Drink no [xref]a[/xref]wine or strong drink, neither you nor your sons with you, when you come into the Tent of Meeting, that you may not die; it shall be a perpetual statute throughout your generations,
verse.note: This charge indicates that the reason Nadab and Abihu acted carelessly and without fear in offering strange fire to God might have been that they were drunk with wine or strong drink. The charge in [link]vv. 9-11[/link] signifies that God's serving ones, in coming into the church life, should not drink anything of the worldly enjoyment, of the fleshly interest, and of the natural excitement that they might not suffer spiritual deadness but be able to make a distinction between the holy and the common and between the unclean and the clean, and be able to teach God's people His regulations.

chapter.verse: Both to make a distinction between the holy and the common, and between the unclean and the clean;
And to teach the children of Israel all the statutes which Jehovah has spoken to them through Moses.

verse.text: Then Moses spoke to Aaron and to Eleazar and to Ithamar, his sons who were left, Take the [note]1[/note]meal offering which [xref]a[/xref]remains of Jehovah's offerings by fire, and eat it unleavened beside the altar; for it is most holy.
verse.note: The eating of the remainder of the meal offering, as the priests' portion, unleavened in a holy place beside the altar ([link]vv. 12-13[/link]) signifies that after God has enjoyed His portion ([link]2:2[/link], [link]9[/link]), the remaining part of Christ in His humanity as our meal offering is for us, the New Testament priests, to enjoy as our portion without sin (unleavened), in a holy place (in God's presence), and beside the cross (the altar).[br][br]The judgment of God on Aaron's two sons did not terminate God's mercy on His people. The giving of the meal offering to Aaron and his two sons immediately after God's disciplinary judgment and correction in [link]vv. 1-11[/link] was a further expression of God's mercy and grace.

verse.text: And you shall eat it in a holy place, because it is [xref]a[/xref]your due and your sons' due of Jehovah's offerings by fire; for so I have been commanded.

And the [note]1[/note]breast of the wave offering and the [note]1[/note]thigh of the heave offering you shall eat in a clean place, you and your sons and your daughters with you; for they have been given as your due and your sons' due out of the sacrifices of the peace offerings of the children of Israel.
verse.note: See note [link]29[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 7[/link].

chapter.verse: The thigh of the heave offering and the breast of the wave offering they shall bring with the offerings by fire of the fat portions to wave as a wave offering before Jehovah, and it shall become a perpetual statute for you and for your sons with you, just as Jehovah has commanded.

verse.text: Then Moses diligently inquired about the [xref]a[/xref]goat of the sin offering, but it had already been burned. So he was angry with Eleazar and with Ithamar, the sons of Aaron who were left, saying,

Why have you not [xref]a[/xref]eaten the sin offering in the place of the sanctuary? For it is most holy, and He gave it to you to [note]1[/note]bear the iniquity of the assembly, to make [note]2[/note]expiation for them before Jehovah.
verse.note: The priests' partaking of the sin offering to bear the iniquity of the people signifies that we, the New Testament priests, partake of Christ as the believers' sin offering in the sense of participating in Christ's life, the life that bears others' sins, as our life supply that we may be able to bear the problems of God's people. The rich enjoyment of Christ as our sin offering in the church life enables us to minister Christ to the believers as the life that deals with sin, that they may deal with their sins to restore their broken fellowship with God (cf. [link]Gal. 6:1-2[/link]; [link]Eph. 4:2[/link]).
See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 16[/link].

verse.text: Now its [xref]a[/xref]blood was not brought inside, into the sanctuary; you should certainly have eaten it in the sanctuary, just as I commanded.

But Aaron spoke to Moses, See, today they have presented their sin offering and their burnt offering before Jehovah, and such things as these have befallen me! And if I had [note]1[/note]eaten the sin offering today, would it have been good in the sight of Jehovah?
verse.note: Due to their weakness concerning God's judgment on Nadab and Abihu, Aaron and his sons were not fit to eat the sin offering ([link]vv. 16-17[/link], [link]19-20[/link]). This signifies that if we are weak in accepting God's judgment on the serving ones who are intimate and close to us, we will not be able to partake of Christ as our sin offering in the way of taking His sinless life as our life supply so that we can minister Him to the believers as the life that deals with their sin.[br][br]On the one hand, Aaron and his sons were weak concerning God's judgment; on the other hand, Aaron had a proper consideration, for he and his sons were sorrowful and unhappy, and eating the sin offering under such circumstances would not have been pleasing to the Lord. Aaron's response pleased Moses, who represented God ([link]v. 20[/link]). Aaron and his sons had not followed the divine regulation in a legal way, not because of disobedience but because of a positive consideration of their circumstances. This incident indicates that with respect to keeping the regulations made by God, in God's mercy there is a margin for consideration. What Aaron and his sons did was seemingly against God's regulation, but actually it was something done in wisdom.

chapter.verse: And when Moses heard [i]that,[/i] it seemed good in his sight.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Then Jehovah spoke to Moses and to Aaron, saying to them,
verse.note: The section of this book from [link]chs. 11-27[/link] concerns the living of God's people, a living that is holy, clean, and full of rejoicing. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: Speak to the children of Israel, saying, These are the animals which you may [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]eat among all the beasts that are on the earth.
verse.note: To eat is to contact things outside of us and to receive them into us, with the result that they eventually become our inner constitution. In this chapter all the animals signify different kinds of people, and eating signifies our contacting of people (cf. [link]Acts 10:9b-14[/link], [link]27-29[/link]). For God's people to live a holy life as required by the holy God, they must be careful about the kind of people they contact (cf. [link]vv. 46-47[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:33[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 6:14-18[/link]).

verse.text: Whatever [note]1[/note]has a divided hoof, that is, has [i]its[/i] hoof split in two, [i]and[/i] chews the cud among the beasts, that you may eat.
verse.note: Lit., divides the hoof, that is, splits the split of [i]its[/i] hoofs (cf. [link]vv. 7[/link], [link]26[/link]). Animals that divide the hoof and chew the cud ([link]v. 3[/link]; cf. [link]vv. 4-8[/link], [link]26-28[/link]) signify persons who have discernment in their activities ([link]Phil. 1:9-10[/link]) and who receive the word of God with much reconsideration (see note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 119[/link]).

verse.text: However these you shall not eat: of those that [i]only[/i] chew the cud or of those that [i]only[/i] have a divided hoof: the [xref]a[/xref]camel, for though it chews the cud, it does not have a divided hoof; it is unclean to you.

chapter.verse: And the hyrax, for though it chews the cud, it does not have a divided hoof; it is unclean to you.
And the hare, for though it chews the cud, it does not have a divided hoof; it is unclean to you.

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]pig, for though it has a divided hoof, that is, it has [i]its[/i] hoof split in two, it does not chew the cud; it is unclean to you.

chapter.verse: You shall not eat of their flesh, nor shall you touch their carcasses; they are unclean to you.

verse.text: These you may eat of all that are in the water: anything in the water that has [note]1[/note]fins and scales, in the seas or in the rivers; these you may eat.
verse.note: In the Bible the sea signifies the fallen, corrupted world ([link]Dan. 7:3[/link], [link]17[/link]; [link]Rev. 17:15[/link]). Fins help fish to move, to act, in water according to their wishes, and scales protect the fish and keep those fish that live in the sea from being salted. Hence, aquatic animals that have fins and scales ([link]vv. 9-12[/link]) signify persons who can move and act freely in the world and at the same time resist its influence.

chapter.verse: But anything that does not have fins and scales in the seas and in the rivers, of anything that swarms in the waters and of any living animal which is in the waters, they are an abomination to you,
And they shall be an abomination to you; you shall not eat of their flesh, and their carcasses you shall regard as an abomination.
Anything in the water that does not have fins or scales is an abomination to you.

verse.text: And these you shall regard as an abomination among the [note]1[/note]birds; they shall not be eaten; they are an abomination: the great [xref]a[/xref]vulture and the bearded vulture and the black vulture
verse.note: Birds that have wings for flying and that eat seeds of life as their food supply signify persons who can live and move in a life that is away from and above the world and who take things of life as their life supply. The unclean birds mentioned in [link]vv. 13-19[/link], which do not feed on seeds but feed on carcasses, signify persons who feed on the things of death. See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Gen. 8[/link].

chapter.verse: And the kite and the falcon of every kind,

verse.text: Every [xref]a[/xref]raven of every kind,

chapter.verse: And the ostrich and the nighthawk and the sea gull and the hawk of every kind,
And the little owl and the cormorant and the great owl
And the white owl and the pelican and the carrion vulture
And the stork; the heron of every kind and the hoopoe and the bat;

verse.text: All [note]1[/note]flying insects that go on [i]all[/i] fours are an abomination to you.
verse.note: Lit., winged swarming things. So also in [link]vv. 21[/link] and [link]23[/link].

verse.text: Yet these you may eat of all flying insects that go on [i]all[/i] fours, which have [note]1[/note]legs above their feet with which to leap on the earth;
verse.note: Insects that have wings and have legs above their feet for leaping on the ground ([link]vv. 21-22[/link], cf. [link]vv. 23-25[/link]) signify persons who can live and move in a life that is above the world and who can keep themselves from the world.

verse.text: These of them you may eat: the swarming [xref]a[/xref]locust of every kind and the swallowing locust of every kind and the cricket of every kind and the grasshopper of every kind.

chapter.verse: But all [i]the other[/i] flying insects which have four feet are an abomination to you.
And by these you shall become unclean; whoever touches their carcass shall be unclean until the evening,

verse.text: And whoever carries any part of their carcass shall [note]1[/note]wash his clothes and be unclean until the evening.
verse.note: A person defiled by the carcass of an animal had to wash his clothes ([link]vv. 25[/link], [link]28a[/link], [link]40[/link]), signifying that our conduct in our daily life (signified by clothing — [link]Isa. 64:6a[/link]) should be washed from the defilement of death.

chapter.verse: For every beast which has a divided hoof but does not have [i]its hoof[/i] split in two or chew the cud is unclean to you; everyone who touches them shall be unclean.
And whatever goes on its paws, among all beasts that go on all fours, are unclean to you; whoever touches their carcass shall be unclean until the evening.
And the one who carries their carcass shall wash his clothes and be unclean until the evening; they are unclean to you.

verse.text: And these are unclean to you among the [note]1[/note]swarming things that swarm on the earth: the weasel and the mouse and the great lizard of every kind,
verse.note: Or, crawling things that crawl. So also in [link]vv. 41-43[/link] (cf. [link]vv. 31[/link], [link]44[/link], [link]46[/link]). All the creatures that crawl on the earth were unclean ([link]vv. 41-44[/link]). Creatures that go on their stomach or on all fours or have many feet ([link]v. 42[/link]) signify Satan with all the evil spirits and demons, persons who are filled with Satan, who contact evil spirits and demons, and persons who live in the world and cleave to the world, being unable to sever themselves from the world (cf. [link]Gen. 3:14[/link]; [link]Rev. 12:9[/link]; [link]Luke 10:19[/link] and note 2).

chapter.verse: And the gecko and the land crocodile and the lizard and the sand lizard and the chameleon.

verse.text: These are unclean to you among all the swarming things; whoever touches them when they are [note]1[/note]dead shall be unclean [note]2[/note]until the evening.
verse.note: In this chapter the word [i]carcass[/i] (or [i]carcasses[/i]) is used thirteen times, and [i]dead[/i] (or [i]dies[/i]) is used three times. All dead things are unclean ([link]vv. 8[/link], [link]11[/link], [link]24[/link], [link]27[/link], [link]31-40[/link]). Uncleanness, therefore, is synonymous with death. The mentioning of death in relation to diet indicates that our diet, our eating, is a matter of life and death. Life is of the tree of life, and death is of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil ([link]Gen. 2:9[/link], [link]17[/link] and notes). Death is abominable to God. Therefore, in order to live a holy life, we need to abstain from death, i.e., spiritual death.

According to the Bible, death is more defiling and abominable than sin. Through the trespass offering any sin could be forgiven immediately ([link]ch. 5[/link]), but a person who touched the carcass of any animal was unclean until the evening ([link]vv. 24-25[/link], [link]27b-28a[/link], [link]31b-32[/link], [link]39-40[/link]). Our sins are forgiven by the Lord immediately after we confess them to Him ([link]1 John 1:9[/link]), but a certain period of time must pass before we can be cleansed from the defilement of spiritual death. A person who touched the carcass of a man was unclean for seven days ([link]Num. 19:11[/link], [link]13[/link]), indicating that in the eyes of God, fallen human beings are the most defiling element (cf. [link]Matt. 15:17-20[/link]).

verse.text: And anything on which one of them may fall when they are dead shall be unclean, whether it is any article of wood or clothing or skin or sackcloth; any article which is used for any work must be put into [note]1[/note]water, and it shall be unclean until the evening; then it shall be clean.
verse.note: Anything upon which the carcass of any animal fell was unclean and had to be put into water, signifying that the defilement of death should be washed away by the cleansing of the Spirit of life (signified here by water — [link]John 7:38-39[/link]).

verse.text: And any earthen vessel into which any of them falls, whatever is in it shall be unclean, and the [note]1[/note]vessel you shall break.
verse.note: Lit., it. An earthen vessel signifies the natural, created man ([link]Rom. 9:21[/link], [link]23[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 4:7[/link]). The carcass of any animal falling into an earthen vessel or upon an oven or stove made it unclean, and that vessel or that oven or stove had to be broken ([link]vv. 33[/link], [link]35[/link]). This signifies that our natural man, our being, our self, that has been defiled in our daily life needs to be broken by the cross of Christ (cf. [link]Luke 9:23[/link]).

verse.text: Any [note]1[/note]food that could be eaten shall be unclean if water [i]from such a vessel[/i] comes upon it, and any [note]1[/note]liquid that may be drunk shall be unclean [i]if it was[/i] in any [i]such[/i] vessel.
verse.note: Any food upon which water came from a vessel that had been defiled by a carcass, and any drink in such a vessel, were unclean, signifying that a person (signified by the food or the drink) who is touched by the earthly (worldly) flow or mixed with it in his daily life is easily affected by the defilement of death.

chapter.verse: And everything on which part of their carcass falls shall be unclean — an oven or a stove shall be broken in pieces; they are unclean and shall continue to be unclean to you.

verse.text: Nevertheless a [note]1[/note]spring or a cistern collecting water shall be clean, but whatever touches their carcass shall be unclean.
verse.note: A spring or a cistern collecting water remained clean, signifying that anything that has the flow of living water, which washes away the defilement of death at any time, remains clean. The spring of living water signifies the Spirit ([link]John 4:14[/link]; [link]7:38-39[/link]), and the cistern of living water signifies Christ, who holds the living water ([link]John 4:10[/link]; [link]7:37[/link]). As long as we have the spring and the cistern, the Spirit and Christ, in our daily life, we shall remain clean.

verse.text: And if any part of their carcass falls on any [note]1[/note]seed for sowing, which is to be sown, it is clean.
verse.note: The seed for sowing remained clean, signifying that anything that is living and possesses life that has the strength to resist defilement remains clean. The seed here typifies Christ as the seed of life (see note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 4[/link]).

chapter.verse: But if water is put on the seed, and any part of their carcass fall on it, it is unclean to you.
And if any beast which you have for food dies, the one who touches its carcass shall be unclean until the evening.
And he who eats some of its carcass shall wash his clothes and be unclean until the evening; the one who carries its carcass shall also wash his clothes and be unclean until the evening.
Now every swarming thing that swarms upon the earth is an abomination; it shall not be eaten.

Whatever goes on [i]its[/i] stomach and whatever goes on all fours, or whatever has many feet, even all the swarming things that swarm on the earth, you shall not eat them, for they are an abomination.
You shall not make yourselves abominable with any swarming thing that swarms, nor shall you make yourselves unclean with them, and so become defiled by them.

verse.text: For I am Jehovah your God. Sanctify yourselves therefore, and [xref]a[/xref]be holy, for [xref]b[/xref]I am holy. And you shall not defile yourselves with any of the swarming things that move upon the earth.
For I am Jehovah, who brought you up out of the land of Egypt to be your God; [xref]a[/xref]you shall therefore be holy, for I am holy.

chapter.verse: This is the law of the beast and of the bird, and of every living animal that moves in the waters, and of every creature that swarms upon the earth;

verse.text: To make a distinction between the unclean and the [note]1[/note]clean, and between the animal that may be eaten and the animal that may not be eaten.
verse.note: The matter of eating involves cleanness, the reality of which is Christ, who is our content, life supply, and spiritual food ([link]John 6:35[/link], [link]57[/link]). All the clean living creatures are types of Christ. Only Christ is able to keep us holy, as God is holy ([link]v. 45b[/link]). Only Christ and that which is out of Christ are clean for our food supply. This only is what we should contact, eat, and receive.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Speak to the children of Israel, saying, If a [note]1[/note]woman conceives seed and bears a male child, then she shall be unclean [note]2[/note]seven days; as in the days of her menstruation, she shall be unclean.
verse.note: In figure the woman represents all mankind (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Gen. 3[/link]). Thus, the uncleanness within the woman signifies the uncleanness within all mankind. Since the source is unclean, whatever is born of the source must also be unclean. All mankind was born in uncleanness ([link]Psa. 51:5[/link]) and consequently lives in uncleanness ([link]Eph. 2:1-3[/link]; [link]4:17-19[/link]). In [link]ch. 11[/link] the uncleanness is outside of man, but in this chapter the uncleanness is within man (cf. [link]Matt. 15:17-20[/link]; [link]Rom. 5:19a[/link]).

The uncleanness of the male's birth is for seven days, but that of the female's is for two weeks ([link]vv. 2[/link], [link]5a[/link]), signifying that the male (representing the strong ones) is fully (signified by the seven days) unclean in spite of his strength, and that the female (representing the weak ones — [link]1 Pet. 3:7[/link]) is doubly (signified by the two weeks) unclean in her weakness.

verse.text: And on the [note]1[/note]eighth day the flesh of his foreskin shall be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]circumcised.
verse.note: [link]Verses 3[/link] and [link book="Lev." chapter="12"]6[/link] reveal the way to deal with the uncleanness in human birth. In this verse the eighth day, the beginning of a new week, refers to Christ's resurrection ([link]Matt. 28:1[/link]; [link]John 20:1[/link]), and circumcision, the cutting off of the flesh, refers to the terminating of the old man in Christ's crucifixion ([link]Rom. 6:6[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:20a[/link]). The circumcising of the male on the eighth day after his birth signifies that the flesh of the unclean person (i.e., the entire person — [link]Rom. 3:20[/link]) should be cut off, terminated, through the death of Christ that he might be brought into the resurrection of Christ not only to be cleansed but also to have a new beginning of life ([link]Col. 2:11-12[/link]). See notes [link book="Gen." chapter="17"]10[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]12[sup]1[/sup] in Gen. 17[/link].

verse.text: And she shall remain in the blood of [i]her[/i] purifying [note]1[/note]thirty-three days; she shall not touch any [note]2[/note]sanctified thing, nor come into the [note]2[/note]sanctuary, until the days of her purifying are fulfilled.
verse.note: After the birth of a male, the woman was to remain in the blood of her purifying thirty-three days, and after the birth of a female, sixty-six days ([link]v. 5b[/link]). In the case of the male the total number of days for purifying was forty (seven plus thirty-three), and in the case of the female the total number of days was eighty (fourteen plus sixty-six). In the Bible the number forty denotes a period of testing ([link]Deut. 9:9[/link]; [link]1 Kings 19:8[/link]). Because the birth of a human being is altogether unclean, it must be tested for cleanness. The uncleanness of a female's birth should be doubly tested for cleanness.

During the test of the uncleanness, the woman's not being allowed to touch any sanctified thing or to enter into the sanctuary signifies that man is not allowed to touch the things concerning God or go into the presence of God until his uncleanness is dealt with (see notes [link]3[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]6[sup]1[/sup][/link]).

chapter.verse: But if she bears a female, then she shall be unclean two weeks, as in her impurity; and she shall remain in the blood of [i]her[/i] purifying sixty-six days.

verse.text: And when the days of her [xref]a[/xref]purifying are fulfilled, for a son or for a daughter, she shall bring a year old [xref]b[/xref]lamb for a [note]1[/note]burnt offering, and a young pigeon or a turtledove for a [note]1[/note]sin offering to the priest to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting.
verse.note: After the completion of the test of the uncleanness, a burnt offering and a sin offering were to be offered ([link]vv. 6-8[/link]), signifying that after our uncleanness by birth is fully dealt with through Christ's death and resurrection ([link]v. 3[/link] and note), we need Christ further to be our burnt offering for our not being for God and to be our sin offering for our sin ([link]Heb. 10:5-7[/link]), that Christ may be our life and our living that is absolute for God and that He may deal with the sin that is still in our flesh as we live on earth ([link]1 John 1:7-2:2[/link]).

chapter.verse: And he shall present it before Jehovah and make expiation for her, and she shall be cleansed from the flow of her blood. This is the law for her who bears a child, whether male or female.

verse.text: And if she cannot afford a lamb, then she shall take [xref]a[/xref]two turtledoves or two young pigeons, one for a burnt offering and the other for a sin offering. And the priest shall make expiation for her, and she shall be clean.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses and to Aaron, saying,

verse.text: When a man has a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]swelling or an eruption or a bright spot on the skin of his [note]2[/note]body, and it becomes an infection of [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]leprosy on the skin of his body, then he shall be brought to [note]3[/note]Aaron the priest or to one of his sons the priests.
verse.note: Leprosy signifies the serious sin issuing from within man, such as willful sin, presumptuous sin, and opposing God with determination. As seen in the cases of Miriam ([link]Num. 12:1-10[/link]), Gehazi ([link]2 Kings 5:20-27[/link]), and Uzziah ([link]2 Chron. 26:16-21[/link]), leprosy issues from rebellion against God's authority, against God's deputy authority, against God's regulation, and against God's economy. In the biblical sense, sin is rebellion ([link]1 John 3:4[/link] and note 2). Thus, leprosy signifies sin. The first case of sin in the Bible was Satan's rebellion against God ([link]Ezek. 28:13-18[/link]; [link]Isa. 14:12-15[/link]). Hence, sin as rebellion was invented, inaugurated, by the rebellious archangel Lucifer. Eventually, this sin, this leprosy, entered into mankind through Adam ([link]Rom. 5:12[/link], [link]19a[/link]; [link]7:20[/link]), and having entered into man, it issues from within man as many kinds of sins, i.e., many manifestations of rebellion. Hence, a leper represents the fallen descendants of Adam, all of whom are lepers. See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 8[/link].[br][br]As signs of leprosy, a swelling, eruption, or a bright spot on the skin of one's flesh signifies man's outward expressions in unruliness, in friction with others, and in pride and self-exaltation.
Lit., flesh. So throughout this chapter.

Being brought to the priest, being examined by him, and being shut up (isolated) for seven days ([link]vv. 2c-28[/link]) signify being brought, on the one hand, to the Lord and, on the other hand, to one who serves God, being examined by them, and being kept from contact with others for a complete course of time.

verse.text: And the priest shall look at the infection in the skin of the body; and if the hair in the infection has turned [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]white and the appearance of the infection is [note]2[/note]deeper than the skin of his body, it is the infection of leprosy. When the priest has looked at him, he shall pronounce him unclean.
verse.note: The hair turning white signifies that the strength for behavior, the strength to live a normal life, is deteriorating. In contrast, black hair signifies that one is strong in the spirit to live a proper Christian life through one's submission to God ([link]S.S. 5:11[/link] and note; cf. [link]Rev. 1:14[/link] and note 1).

The infection being deeper than the skin signifies that one's wrong behavior is covered and is not confessed. The infection not being deeper than the skin and the hair in it not having turned white ([link]v. 4[/link]) signifies that one's wrong behavior is confessed, not covered, and that his strength for behavior has not deteriorated.

chapter.verse: And if the bright spot is white on the skin of his body, and its appearance is not deeper than the skin, and the hair on it has not turned white, then the priest shall isolate [i]the one who has[/i] the infection seven days.
And the priest shall look at him on the seventh day; and if in his eyes the infection remains, [i]and[/i] the infection has not spread in the skin, then the priest shall isolate him seven more days.

verse.text: And the priest shall look at him again on the seventh day; and if the infection has [note]1[/note]faded, and the infection has not spread in the skin, then the priest shall pronounce him clean; it is [i]only[/i] a scab. And he shall wash his clothes and be clean.
verse.note: The infection having faded and having not spread in the skin signifies that one's weakness has been swallowed up by life through Christ's recovery work in him with grace. Such a person has been healed, recovered.

chapter.verse: But if the scab spreads further on the skin after he has showed himself to the priest for his cleansing, he shall show himself again to the priest.
And the priest shall look; and if the scab has spread on the skin, then the priest shall pronounce him unclean; it is leprosy.
When the infection of leprosy is in a man, then he shall be brought to the priest;

verse.text: And the priest shall look; and if there is a white swelling in the skin, and it has turned the hair white, and there is living [note]1[/note]raw flesh in the swelling,
verse.note: The appearing of white hair and living raw flesh signifies that the old sin has come back again through the weakening of the strength for behavior.

chapter.verse: It is a chronic leprosy on the skin of his body; and the priest shall pronounce him unclean. He shall not isolate him, for he is unclean.

verse.text: And if the leprosy breaks out further on the skin, and the leprosy [note]1[/note]covers all the skin of [i]the one who has[/i] the infection, from his head even to his feet, as far as the priest can see,
verse.note: The condition in [link]vv. 12-13[/link] signifies that one who is full of sin and who is willing to confess all his sin before God is forgiven and cleansed ([link]1 John 1:9[/link]).

chapter.verse: Then the priest shall look; and if the leprosy has covered all his body, he shall pronounce [i]him who has[/i] the infection clean. It has all turned white; he is clean.

verse.text: But whenever [note]1[/note]raw flesh appears on him, he shall be unclean.
verse.note: This signifies that the old sin has come back again. However, the raw flesh turning white again and the leper being pronounced clean ([link]vv. 16-17[/link]) signifies that if the repeated sin is confessed, it will be forgiven and cleansed ([link]1 John 1:9[/link]).

chapter.verse: And the priest shall look at the raw flesh and pronounce him unclean. The raw flesh is unclean; it is leprosy.
But if the raw flesh again turns white, then he shall come to the priest.
And the priest shall look at him; and if the infection has turned white, then the priest shall pronounce [i]him who has[/i] the infection clean; he is clean.

verse.text: And when the body has a [note]1[/note]boil on its skin, and it has healed,
verse.note: Leprosy breaking out in a boil that has healed ([link]vv. 18-20[/link]) signifies that one becomes weak (the hair turning white) in his outward living after being saved and has new weak points manifested in his conduct.

chapter.verse: And in the place of the boil there is a white swelling or a reddish-white bright spot, then it shall be shown to the priest.

And the priest shall look; and if its appearance is below [i]the surface of[/i] the skin, and the hair on it has turned white, then the priest shall pronounce him unclean. It is the infection of leprosy; it has broken out in the boil.
But if the priest looks at it, and if there is no white hair in it, and it is not below [i]the surface of[/i] the skin, but it has faded, then the priest shall isolate him seven days.
And if it spreads further in the skin, then the priest shall pronounce him unclean; it is an infection.
But if the bright spot remains in its place and does not spread, it is only the scar of the boil; and the priest shall pronounce him clean.

verse.text: Or when the [note]1[/note]flesh has on its skin a burn by fire, and the raw [i]flesh[/i] of the burn becomes a bright spot, reddish-white or white,
verse.note: The condition in [link]vv. 24-25[/link] signifies that a saved person's acting by the flesh, e.g., his losing his temper, his justifying himself, and his not being willing to forgive others, is a sign of spiritual leprosy.

chapter.verse: Then the priest shall look at it; and if the hair in the bright spot has turned white, and its appearance is deeper than the skin, it is leprosy. It has broken out in the burn, and the priest shall pronounce him unclean; it is the infection of leprosy.
But if the priest looks at it, and if there is no white hair in the bright spot, and it is not below [i]the surface of[/i] the skin, but it has faded, then the priest shall isolate him seven days.
And the priest shall look at him on the seventh day. If it spreads further in the skin, then the priest shall pronounce him unclean; it is the infection of leprosy.

And if the bright spot remains in its place, and it has not spread in the skin, but it has faded, it is the swelling from the burn; and the priest shall pronounce him clean, for it is only the scar of the burning.

verse.text: And if a man or woman has an infection on the [note]1[/note]head or on the [note]1[/note]beard,
verse.note: In the Bible the head, especially the hair on the head, signifies man's glory ([link]1 Cor. 11:7[/link], [link]15[/link]), and a beard is related to dignity, to one's self-assumed honor. The fact that there can be an infection on the head and on the beard indicates that it is easy for leprosy, the sin of rebellion, to be hidden within human glory and dignity.[br][br]An infection on the head signifies something wrong in the subjection to authority and in the thinking of the mind (cf. [link]2 Cor. 10:5[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 3:8[/link]). An infection on the beard signifies being self-dignified, hunting for exaltation from others (cf. [link]Matt. 6:1-6[/link]; [link]Luke 11:43[/link]; [link]14:7-11[/link]).

verse.text: Then the priest shall look at the infection; and if its appearance is deeper than the skin, and there is in it [note]1[/note]thin yellowish hair, then the priest shall pronounce him unclean. It is a scale; it is leprosy of the head or of the beard.
verse.note: Thin yellowish hair signifies the deteriorating of the strength to live a normal Christian life because of one's disobedience to God's word. See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And if the priest looks at the infection of the scale, and if its appearance is [note]1[/note]not deeper than the skin, and there is [note]1[/note]no black hair in it, then the priest shall isolate [i]the one who has[/i] the infection of the scale seven days.
verse.note: The infection not being deeper than the skin signifies that the person does not cover his sin, and there being no black hair in it signifies that he does not have the strength to resist it.

chapter.verse: And on the seventh day the priest shall look at the infection; and if the scale has not spread, and there is no yellowish hair in it, and the appearance of the scale is not deeper than the skin,

verse.text: Then he shall [note]1[/note]shave himself, but the scale he shall not shave. And the priest shall isolate [i]the one who has[/i] the scale seven days more.
verse.note: Shaving the beard but not the hair signifies dealing with being self-dignified and seeking exaltation from others, but keeping the subjection to authority (cf. [link]1 Cor. 11:10[/link], [link]15[/link]).

verse.text: And on the seventh day the priest shall look at the scale; and if the scale has not spread in the skin, and its appearance is not deeper than the skin, then the priest shall pronounce him clean. And he shall [note]1[/note]wash his clothes and be clean.
verse.note: Clothes signify our conduct ([link]Isa. 64:6[/link]). Washing one's clothes signifies washing away the stains of weak points in conduct, offenses, defects, words of rebellion, and improper activities, first by the blood of Christ and then by the Spirit ([link]Rev. 7:14[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 6:11[/link]).

chapter.verse: But if the scale spreads further in the skin after his cleansing,
Then the priest shall look at him; and if the scale has spread in the skin, the priest need not seek for the yellowish hair; he is unclean.

verse.text: But if, in [note]1[/note]the priest's eyes, the scale has remained, and [note]2[/note]black hair has grown up in it, the scale is healed; he is clean. And the priest shall pronounce him clean.
verse.note: Lit., his.
The growing of black hair in the scale signifies that the spiritual strength for one to live a normal Christian life is increasing at the point of one's weakness.

verse.text: And when a man or a woman has bright spots on the skin of their body, [note]1[/note]white bright spots,
verse.note: White bright spots signify the disease of self-display (cf. [link]Matt. 6:1-6[/link]). The dull whiteness of the bright spots ([link]v. 39[/link]) signifies that one has humbled himself and has been recovered from the disease of self-display.

chapter.verse: Then the priest shall look; and if the bright spots on the skin of their body are a dull white, it is a rash that has broken out on the skin; he is clean.

verse.text: And if a man [note]1[/note]loses the hair of his head, he is bald; he is clean.
verse.note: The losing of the hair on the head or of the hair on the forehead and the temples ([link]v. 41[/link]) (baldness) signifies the losing of subjection to authority, yet without being in rebellion before men, i.e., without the sign of leprosy ([link]vv. 42-44[/link]).

chapter.verse: And if he loses hair from his forehead and his temples, he is bald on the forehead; he is clean.
But if on the bald head or the bald forehead there is a reddish-white infection, it is leprosy breaking out on his bald head or on his bald forehead.
Then the priest shall look at him; and if the swelling of the infection is reddish-white on his bald head or on his bald forehead, like the appearance of leprosy in the skin of the body,

verse.text: He is a [xref]a[/xref]leprous man; he is unclean. The priest shall surely pronounce him unclean; his infection is on his head.

And as for the leper in whom the infection is, his [note]1[/note]clothes shall be torn, and the [note]1[/note]hair of his head shall be let loose, and he shall [note]1[/note]cover his upper lip and cry, [note]1[/note]Unclean, unclean!
verse.note: The leper's open confession of his leprosy to others ([link]vv. 45-46[/link]) signifies that a sinner makes an open confession of his sin to others. Tearing one's clothes is a sign of admitting one's moral bankruptcy. Letting loose the hair signifies that one is utterly lacking in subjection to authority, being unruly and reckless. Covering the upper lip indicates that whatever issues out of a leper (a sinner) is filthy and contagious and that he should not be contacted. Crying "Unclean, unclean!" indicates self-condemnation without ceasing. Dwelling alone outside the camp ([link]v. 46[/link]) signifies that, until he clears up his sinfulness, the one who has sinned should stay outside the church and be isolated from the fellowship among God's people ([link]1 Cor. 5:13[/link]).

verse.text: He shall be unclean all the days during which the infection is in him; he is unclean. He shall live alone; his dwelling shall be [xref]a[/xref]outside the camp.
The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]garment also that the infection of leprosy is in, whether it is a [note]2[/note]woolen garment or a [note]2[/note]linen garment,
verse.note: Leprosy in a garment ([link]vv. 47-59[/link]) signifies the filthiness in one's outward living, conduct, contact with people, etc.

Since wool is soft, woolen garments signify one's conduct, contact with people, etc., in meekness. Linen is pure, plain, and simple; thus, linen garments signify one's conduct, contact with people, etc., in plainness. Clothing made from skins ([link]v. 48[/link]) is warm; hence, garments made of skins signify one's conduct, contact with people, etc., in warmness. As signified by these three kinds of garments, our conduct should be in meekness, in plainness, and in warmness, with no sign of leprosy — the expression of sin and rebellion.

verse.text: Whether it is in [note]1[/note]warp or [note]1[/note]woof, of linen or of wool, whether in a skin or in anything made of skin,
verse.note: The warp in the weave of a garment goes from top to bottom, and the woof, from left to right. Thus, the warp signifies our outward conduct toward God, our relationship with God, and the woof signifies our outward conduct toward others. Our conduct in our daily walk is an interweaving that involves both God and man. We need to be proper with both God and man; i.e., in our garments, our conduct, there should be no leprosy, rebellion, either in the warp or in the woof, either toward God or toward man.

verse.text: If the infection is [note]1[/note]greenish or reddish in the garment or in the skin, or in the warp or in the woof, or in anything of skin, it is the infection of leprosy and shall be [xref]a[/xref]shown to the priest.
verse.note: The greenish or reddish infection in the garment signifies the abnormal and strange change in one's living and conduct. The infection spreading in the garment, becoming a malignant leprosy ([link]v. 51[/link]) of the kind that spreads by eating the flesh, signifies sin that is spreading within a person by devouring the person, becoming worse and worse in its malignancy.

chapter.verse: And the priest shall look at the infection and isolate [i]the article which has[/i] the infection for seven days.

Then he shall look at the infection on the seventh day. If the infection has spread in the garment, either in the warp or in the woof, or in the skin, whatever the purpose the skin is used for, the infection is a malignant leprosy; it is unclean.

verse.text: And he shall [note]1[/note]burn the garment, whether the warp or the woof, in wool or in linen, or anything of skin in which the infection occurs, for it is a malignant leprosy; it shall be burned in the fire.
verse.note: Burning the garment in fire signifies eliminating the sinful and filthy living and conduct by dealing with it strongly by the cross of Christ ([link]Gal. 5:19-24[/link]).

chapter.verse: And if the priest shall look, and if the infection has not spread in the garment, either in the warp or in the woof, or in anything of skin,

verse.text: Then the priest shall command that they [note]1[/note]wash the thing in which the infection is; and he shall isolate it for seven more days.
verse.note: Washing the garment in which the infection has not spread signifies dealing with the suspected weakness in one's living and conduct by the washing Spirit of God, who is likened to water for washing ([link]1 Cor. 6:11[/link]; [link]Titus 3:5[/link]).

verse.text: And after [i]the article with[/i] the infection has been washed, the priest shall look at [i]it;[/i] and if the infection has not changed its appearance, even [i]though[/i] the infection has not spread, it is unclean. You shall burn it in the fire; it is a [note]1[/note]leprous decay, whether the bareness is on the inside or on the outside.
verse.note: A leprous decay is very serious; it signifies the corroding sin that is becoming worse and deeper, having no change in appearance through repentance and confession. This is the kind of sin that can take over a person, devouring and swallowing him up.

verse.text: And if the priest looks, and if the infection has faded after it was washed, then he shall [note]1[/note]tear it out of the garment or out of the skin, whether from the warp or from the woof.
verse.note: The tearing out of the faded infected part of a garment signifies the eliminating, through a thorough dealing, of the suspected weakness in one's living and conduct. The reappearing of the infection in the garment ([link]v. 57[/link]) signifies that one's weakness, after being dealt with and eliminated, has come out again.

chapter.verse: But if it appears again in the garment, whether in the warp or in the woof, or in anything of skin, it is spreading. You shall burn the article that the infection is in, in the fire.

verse.text: And the garment, whether the warp or the woof, or any article of skin, which you shall wash, if the infection has departed from them, shall be washed a [note]1[/note]second time and shall be clean.
verse.note: The washing of the garment a second time after the infection has departed through washing signifies that one's weakness, having been dealt with, should be dealt with further, a second time.

chapter.verse: This is the law of the infection of leprosy in a garment of wool or linen, either in the warp or in the woof, or anything of skin, for pronouncing it clean or for pronouncing it unclean.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: This shall be the law of the leper on the day of his [note]1[/note]cleansing: He shall be [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]brought to the priest,
verse.note: The cleansing of the leper in this chapter portrays the rich, complete, and extensive salvation God has prepared and accomplished for us in Christ. In this salvation Christ is the all-inclusive One who has passed through a number of processes and is everything we need for our cleansing.
The leper being brought to the priest signifies an unclean person, a sinner, being brought to the Lord.

verse.text: And the priest shall go forth [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]outside the camp. Then the priest shall look, and if the infection of leprosy has been [note]2[/note]healed in the leper,
