verse.note: The priest going forth outside the camp to examine the leper signifies the Lord Jesus leaving His original place in the heavens and humbling Himself to come to the earth in order to be near to the sinner (cf. [link]Matt. 8:1-4[/link] and notes).
The healing of sin (leprosy) is the issue of our repentance and the working of the divine life within us (see note [link]32[sup]1[/sup] in John 8[/link]).

verse.text: Then the priest shall command that two living clean [note]1[/note]birds and [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]cedar wood and [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]scarlet [i]strands[/i] and [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]hyssop be taken for the one who is to be [note]3[/note]cleansed.
verse.note: The two living clean birds are types of Christ, who is clean, without any defilement, and full of the life that is able to fly above the earth. The birds here signify that Christ came from the heavens and that He belongs to the heavens and transcends the earth. The bird that was killed ([link]v. 5[/link]) signifies the crucified Christ, who died for us that our filthiness might be taken away ([link]1 Pet. 2:24[/link]). The second bird, which was let go into the open field ([link]vv. 6-7[/link]), signifies the resurrected Christ, who rose from the dead for us that we might be delivered from our weakness by the power, strength, and energy of His resurrection life — the divine, eternal, uncreated life of God ([link]Rom. 8:2[/link]).

Cedar wood (cf. [link]1 Kings 4:33[/link]) signifies the honorable and uplifted humanity of Jesus, which enables Him to be our Savior. Hyssop, being one of the smallest of the plants, signifies here that the Lord Jesus was willing to become lowly in His "becoming in the likeness of men" ([link]Phil. 2:7[/link]) that He might be near to man and become man's Savior (cf. [link]Matt. 8:2-3[/link]). Scarlet, a dark red color, signifies the shedding of blood ([link]Josh. 2:18[/link] and note) and also implies kingship ([link]Matt. 27:28-29[/link]). All of this signifies that in order to cleanse us from our leprosy, the Lord lowered Himself to become a man of high standard but of low status that He might do the will of God and shed His blood on the cross for our redemption, thereby being glorified in His resurrection and becoming the honorable and high King ([link]Phil. 2:5-11[/link]).

The one who had been healed from leprosy ([link]v. 3[/link]) still needed to seek to be cleansed before God, signifying that the one who is sick of the sin of leprosy, although he has been healed by the divine life within, still needs to have his shortcomings and defilement dealt with before God that he might be cleansed. Our seeking to be cleansed is our cooperation with God's grace and love.

verse.text: And the priest shall command that one of the birds be slaughtered in an earthen vessel over [note]1[/note]running water.
verse.note: Lit., living. So throughout the book. The earthen vessel signifies the humanity of Jesus (cf. [link]2 Cor. 4:7[/link]), and the living water signifies the living and eternal Spirit of God ([link]John 7:37-39[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:1[/link]). The bird being killed in an earthen vessel over living water signifies that through His death in His humanity the Lord Jesus offered Himself to God through the eternal and living Spirit who was within Him ([link]Heb. 9:14[/link]).

verse.text: As for the [note]1[/note]living bird, he shall take it and the cedar wood and the scarlet [i]strands[/i] and the hyssop, and shall dip them and the living bird in the blood of the bird that was slaughtered over the running water.
verse.note: The things recorded in [link]vv. 6-7[/link] signify that the Lord's perfect redemption not only causes man to be cleansed objectively in his position but also causes man to experience subjectively, in the Holy Spirit, the Lord's suffering in the shedding of His blood in His honorable, uplifted, and yet lowly humanity and to experience His death, resurrection, ascension, and glorification ([link]Eph. 2:5-6[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:10[/link], [link]21[/link]; [link]Col. 3:1-4[/link]). These things are all implied in the significances of the two birds, the cedar wood, the hyssop, and the scarlet strands (see notes [link]4[sup]1[/sup][/link], [link]4[sup]2[/sup][/link], [link]7[sup]1[/sup][/link], and [link]7[sup]2[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: And he shall [note]1[/note]sprinkle [i]it[/i] on the one who is to be cleansed from the leprosy [xref]a[/xref]seven times and shall pronounce him clean. Then he shall [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]let the living bird go into the open field.
verse.note: The sprinkling of the blood of the slain bird on the leper who was to be cleansed signifies that the blood shed by Christ was sprinkled on us, the sinners ([link]1 Pet. 1:2[/link]), and this sprinkling connects us to Christ, the Redeemer (cf. note [link]22[sup]2[/sup] in Exo. 12[/link]). The sprinkling of the blood seven times signifies the completeness of the cleansing of the Lord's blood ([link]1 John 1:7[/link], [link]9[/link]).

Christ's ascension is signified by the living bird's soaring in the air. Letting the living bird go into the open field signifies that the living Christ causes the cleansed sinner to experience not only Christ's death and resurrection but also His ascension ([link]2 Cor. 5:14-15[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:5-6[/link]; [link]Col. 3:1-3[/link]). See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And the one who is to be cleansed shall [note]1[/note]wash his clothes and shave off all his hair and bathe in water, and he shall be clean. And after that he may come into the camp, but he shall [note]2[/note]dwell outside his tent [xref]a[/xref]seven days.
verse.note: The leper's washing his clothes, shaving off all his hair, and bathing himself in water signifies that in addition to experiencing Christ's death, resurrection, and ascension in his union with Christ through His redemption ([link]vv. 5-7[/link]), a sinner who is to be cleansed needs to bear the responsibility himself to deal with and cut off all that is of his old living and natural life.[br][br]For the significance of washing one's clothes, shaving off one's hair, and bathing oneself in water, see note [link]34[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 13[/link], note [link book="Lev." chapter="14"]9[sup]1[/sup][/link] in this chapter, and note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 15[/link], respectively.

The clean leper coming into the camp but dwelling outside his tent for seven days signifies that a sinner who is to be cleansed is still unable to recover the fellowship with the brothers; he needs to be watchful, to wait, and to be dealt with further. This indicates that dealing with our sin, our leprosy, our rebellion, which comes from Satan, is a serious matter with God.

verse.text: And on the seventh day he shall shave off all his [note]1[/note]hair; he shall shave his head and his beard and his eyebrows, even all his hair. Then he shall [note]2[/note]wash his clothes and bathe his flesh in water, and he shall be [xref]a[/xref]clean.
verse.note: The hair of the head signifies man's glory in self-display; the beard, man's self-assumed honor; the eyebrows, man's excellencies, merits, and virtues issuing from his natural birth; and all the hair of the body, man's natural strength and ability. The shaving off of all the hair and the bathing in water equal getting rid of the self with all its glory, honor, excellencies, merits, virtues, strength, and ability through the "razor" of the cross. When we have nothing and are nothing, we shall be clean (cf. [link]Phil. 3:7-11[/link]).

The leper's shaving of his entire body, washing his clothes, and bathing his flesh a second time after waiting and watching seven days signifies that a sinner who is to be cleansed needs to bear the responsibility for dealing with every part of his natural life and daily walk. This shows that if we deal with our sin and our sinful self seriously, in a definite, thorough, and absolute way, we shall be clean.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And on the [note]2[/note]eighth day he shall take two male lambs without blemish and one ewe lamb a year old without blemish and three-tenths [i]of an ephah[/i] of fine flour for a [xref]a[/xref]meal offering mingled with oil and one [note]3[/note]log of oil.
verse.note: As revealed in [link]vv. 10-32[/link], in addition to his cleansing ([link]v. 9[/link]), the leper who was to be cleansed still needed to solve the problem of his sin and sins before God by offering the trespass offering, the sin offering, the burnt offering, and the meal offering to make expiation for himself before God ([link]vv. 18-20[/link]). This signifies that a sinner who is to be cleansed, even though he has been cleansed, still needs to solve the problem of his sin and sins before God through Christ as the reality of the offerings to make propitiation for himself before God. Expiation (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 16[/link]) was needed in addition to healing ([link]v. 3[/link]) and cleansing ([link]vv. 4-9[/link]) in order to appease God and bring the leper (the sinner) back into fellowship with God.
Presenting the offerings before God on the eighth day ([link]vv. 10-11[/link]) signifies that man is freed in Christ in resurrection from the flesh of the old creation.
A liquid measure of approximately half a liter. Oil here typifies the Holy Spirit.

chapter.verse: And the priest who makes him clean shall set the man to be cleansed and those things before Jehovah at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting.

verse.text: And the priest shall take one of the male lambs and present it as a [xref]a[/xref]trespass offering and the log of oil, and wave them as a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]wave offering before Jehovah.
verse.note: See note [link]24[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 29[/link]. The offering of the male lamb for a trespass offering, with the log of oil, both of which were waved before Jehovah, signifies that the death of the Lord Jesus as the trespass offering deals with our sins, and His resurrection in the Holy Spirit frees us from our trespasses, that we, having died to sins, might live to righteousness ([link]1 Pet. 2:24[/link]).

verse.text: Then he shall slaughter the male lamb in the [note]1[/note]place where they [xref]a[/xref]slaughter the sin offering and the burnt offering, in the place of the sanctuary; for the trespass offering, like the sin offering, is the [note]2[/note]priest's; it is most holy.
verse.note: The slaughtering of the male lamb for the trespass offering in the place where the sin offering and the burnt offering were slaughtered signifies that the Lord Jesus' being able to deal with our sins as our trespass offering is based on His bearing our sin as our sin offering and on His living absolutely for God as our burnt offering.
Cf. note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 6[/link].

verse.text: And the priest shall take some of the blood of the trespass offering, and the priest shall [i]put[/i] it on the lobe of the [xref]a[/xref]right [note]1[/note]ear of the one who is to be cleansed and on the thumb of his right [note]1[/note]hand and on the big toe of his right [note]1[/note]foot.
verse.note: This signifies that man has trespasses because, first, his ears are wrong in not listening to God; second, his hands are wrong in not doing the things of God; and third, his feet are wrong in not taking the ways of God. Therefore, he needs to be cleansed with the blood of the Lord Jesus as his trespass offering in all these aspects. Cf. note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 29[/link].

chapter.verse: And the priest shall take some of the log of oil and pour [i]it[/i] into the palm of the priest's left [i]hand,[/i]
And the priest shall dip his right finger in the oil that is in the palm of his left [i]hand[/i] and sprinkle some of the oil with his finger seven times before Jehovah.

verse.text: And from the rest of the oil that is in the palm of his [i]hand[/i] the priest shall put [i]some[/i] on the lobe of the right [note]1[/note]ear of the one who is to be cleansed and [i]some[/i] on the thumb of his right [note]1[/note]hand and [i]some[/i] on the big toe of his right [note]1[/note]foot, upon the blood of the trespass offering.
verse.note: This signifies that man can solve the problem of his trespasses only by listening to the word of God, doing the things of God, and taking the ways of God in the Spirit of resurrection, based on the redemption by the blood of the Lord Jesus as the trespass offering ([link]v. 14[/link]).

verse.text: And the rest of the oil that is in the palm of the priest's [i]hand[/i] he shall put on the [note]1[/note]head of the one who is to be cleansed. Then the priest shall make [note]2[/note]expiation for him before Jehovah.
verse.note: Putting the oil on the head signifies that the authority of the headship, the thoughts of the mind, and the control of the entire being of the sinner who is to be cleansed are dealt with in the cleansing Spirit of resurrection.
See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 16[/link].

verse.text: And the priest shall offer the [note]1[/note]sin offering and make expiation for the one who is to be cleansed because of his uncleanness, and afterward he shall slaughter the burnt offering.
verse.note: This signifies that the Lord Jesus was offered as our sin offering to deal with our uncleanness at the root (the sinful nature) of our sins, which are dealt with by the Lord Jesus as the trespass offering.

verse.text: And the priest shall offer the [note]1[/note]burnt offering and the [note]1[/note]meal offering on the altar. Thus the priest shall make expiation for him, and he shall be clean.
verse.note: The offering of the burnt offering and the meal offering here signifies that the sinner who is to be cleansed, after having been cleansed from the uncleanness of sin and sins through Christ as His sin offering and trespass offering, offers himself in Christ as a burnt offering to God and lives and walks absolutely for God by the life of Christ as the meal offering. Thus the sinner who is to be cleansed, having been healed, cleansed, and expiated, is fully cleansed from his uncleanness.

verse.text: But if he is [note]1[/note]poor and cannot afford [i]so much,[/i] then he shall take one male lamb for a trespass offering to be waved to make expiation for him, and one-tenth [i]of an ephah[/i] of fine flour mingled with oil for a meal offering, and a log of oil,
verse.note: The regulations for the poor in [link]vv. 21-32[/link] signify that a sinner who is to be cleansed should partake of Christ at least at some minimum level, i.e., as much as he can. In principle he must take Christ as his sin offering, trespass offering, burnt offering, and meal offering, and he must take His mingling and cleansing Spirit.

verse.text: And two [xref]a[/xref]turtledoves or two young pigeons, such as he can afford; and the one shall be a sin offering and the other a burnt offering.

chapter.verse: And on the eighth day he shall bring them for his cleansing to the priest, to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, before Jehovah.
Then the priest shall take the lamb of the trespass offering and the log of oil, and the priest shall wave them as a wave offering before Jehovah;

And he shall slaughter the lamb of the trespass offering. Then the priest shall take some of the blood of the trespass offering and put [i]it[/i] on the lobe of the right ear of the one who is to be cleansed and on the thumb of his right hand and on the big toe of his right foot.
And the priest shall pour some of the oil into the palm of the priest's left [i]hand,[/i]
And the priest shall sprinkle with his right finger some of the oil that is in the palm of his left [i]hand[/i] seven times before Jehovah.

And the priest shall put some of the oil that is in the palm of his [i]hand[/i] on the lobe of the right ear of the one who is to be cleansed and on the thumb of his right hand and on the big toe of his right foot, upon the place of the blood of the trespass offering.
And the rest of the oil that is in the palm of the priest's [i]hand[/i] he shall put on the head of the one who is to be cleansed, to make expiation for him before Jehovah.

verse.text: And he shall offer one of the [xref]a[/xref]turtledoves or young pigeons, such as he can afford,

chapter.verse: Even such as he can afford, one for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering, with the meal offering; and the priest shall make expiation for the one who is to be cleansed before Jehovah.
This is the law for the one in whom there is the infection of leprosy, who cannot afford [i]what is prescribed[/i] for his cleansing.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses and to Aaron, saying,

verse.text: When you come into the land of Canaan, which I give you for a possession, and I put the infection of [note]1[/note]leprosy in a house in the land of your possession,
verse.note: The house typifies the church as our real home, and the leprosy in the house signifies sins and evils in the church. God's putting a leprous infection in a house in the land of Israel's possession signifies that when the condition of a church becomes abnormal, God causes the leprous sin to become manifest in the church, reminding and warning the believers that they no longer have a house to live in and are no longer able to enjoy all the blessings God promised in His salvation.

verse.text: Then he to whom the house belongs shall come and tell the [note]1[/note]priest, saying, It seems to me that [i]there is something[/i] like an infection in the house.
verse.note: The owner's coming and telling the priest signifies that the leading brothers or those who are concerned for the church approach the Lord or the apostle ([link]1 Cor. 1:11[/link]), the Lord's deputy, and tell the Lord or His deputy.

verse.text: And the priest shall command that they [note]1[/note]empty the house before the priest goes in to look at the infection, so that everything which is in the house does not become unclean; and afterward the [note]2[/note]priest shall go in to look at the house.
verse.note: This signifies to do one's best to prevent and eliminate the contagion.
This signifies that the Lord or the apostle comes to examine. This kind of examination is not for condemnation but is a grace for healing.

verse.text: And he shall look at the infection; and if the infection is on the walls of the house with greenish or reddish depressions, and its appearance is [note]1[/note]deeper than [i]the surface of[/i] the wall,
verse.note: This signifies that the problem of the church is not only on the surface but is deeper, beneath the surface. The communication and fellowship of such a church (the entrance of the house) should be kept under observation for a complete course of time (seven days — [link]v. 38[/link]).

verse.text: Then the priest shall come out of the house to the entrance of the house and shut up the house [xref]a[/xref]seven days.

chapter.verse: And the priest shall return on the seventh day and inspect [i]it.[/i] And if the infection has spread in the walls of the house,

verse.text: Then the priest shall command that they [note]1[/note]take out the stones on which the infection is and throw them away outside the city into an unclean place.
verse.note: The removing of the infected stones after seven days signifies that after the observation of a complete period of time, if the problem of the church is still spreading, the believer or believers involved in the problem should be removed from the fellowship of the church and be considered unclean, like the outsiders (cf. [link]1 Cor. 5:13[/link]; [link]Rom. 16:17[/link]; [link]Titus 3:10[/link]; [link]2 Thes. 3:6[/link], [link]14[/link]). This is done to stop the spread of the disease and to eliminate the disease.

verse.text: And he shall have the house [note]1[/note]scraped inside all around, and they shall dump the plaster that they scrape off outside the city into an unclean place.
verse.note: This signifies that because of a few believers, the whole church should be dealt with, and whatever is dealt with should be put out of the church as unclean.

verse.text: And they shall take other [note]1[/note]stones and put them in the place of those stones, and he shall take other plaster and [note]2[/note]replaster the house.
verse.note: Putting other stones in the place of the removed stones signifies using other believers ([link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link]) to fill in the gap.
The replastering of the house with other plaster signifies the renewing of the church with new experiences of the Lord's gracious works. This is needed for a new start in the church life.

chapter.verse: And if the infection returns and breaks out in the house after he has taken out the stones and after he has scraped the house and after it has been replastered,
Then the priest shall come in and look; and if the infection has spread in the house, it is a malignant leprosy in the house; it is unclean.

verse.text: And he shall [note]1[/note]break down the house, its stones and its timber and all the plaster of the house, and he shall bring [i]them[/i] outside the city into an unclean place.
verse.note: The breaking down of the house after the infection of leprosy returns signifies that if the situation of a church reaches the point where it cannot be cured, healed, that church should be terminated (cf. [link]Rev. 2:5[/link]).

verse.text: Moreover, whoever goes into the house all the while that it is shut up shall be unclean until the [note]1[/note]evening.
verse.note: This signifies that with him who touches the defiled things, the old day should be ended and there should be a new beginning.

verse.text: And whoever [note]1[/note]lies down in the house shall wash his clothes, and whoever [note]1[/note]eats in the house shall wash his clothes.
verse.note: This signifies that those who are not involved positively in the service in the church (those who lie down in the house) in which there is a problem, as well as those who only enjoy the supply in that church (those who eat in the house), should also be cleansed in their living and behavior.

verse.text: But if on the other hand the priest comes in and looks, and if the infection has [note]1[/note]not spread in the house after the house has been replastered, then the priest shall pronounce the house clean because the infection has been healed.
verse.note: This signifies that if no sin is spreading after the renewing of the church with the new experiences of the Lord's gracious works, the church is clean and has no problem.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And he shall take two birds and cedar wood and scarlet [i]strands[/i] and hyssop to purify the house,
verse.note: [link]Verses 49-51[/link] reveal that the leprosy in a house is cleansed in the same way as the cleansing of the leprosy in a man ([link]vv. 4-9[/link] and notes). This signifies that the whole church experiences once again the suffering, death, resurrection, ascension, and entering into glory with Christ.

chapter.verse: And he shall slaughter one of the birds in an earthen vessel over running water.

And he shall take the cedar wood and the hyssop and the scarlet [i]strands[/i] and the living bird, and dip them in the blood of the bird that was slaughtered and in the running water, and sprinkle the house seven times.

verse.text: And he shall [note]1[/note]purify the house with the blood of the bird and with the running water and with the living bird and with the cedar wood and with the hyssop and with the scarlet [i]strands.[/i]
verse.note: This signifies that the whole church needs to be cleansed with the eternally efficacious blood of Christ and His eternal and living Spirit. See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And he shall [note]1[/note]let the living bird go, outside the city into the open field. So he shall make expiation for the house, and it shall be [note]2[/note]clean.
verse.note: Letting the living bird go, outside the city into the open field signifies that the healed and cleansed church enters with Christ into the realm and experience of His resurrection and ascension. See note [link]7[sup]2[/sup][/link].
The house being clean signifies that the church is fully clean to be the mutual dwelling of God and man ([link]John 14:2[/link]).

verse.text: This is the law for any kind of infection of leprosy and for a [xref]a[/xref]scale
And for the leprosy of a [xref]a[/xref]garment and for a [xref]b[/xref]house
And for a [xref]a[/xref]swelling and for an eruption and for a bright spot,

chapter.verse: To teach when it is unclean and when it is clean. This is the law of leprosy.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses and to Aaron, saying,

verse.text: Speak to the children of Israel and say to them, When any man has a discharge from his [note]1[/note]body, his discharge is unclean.
verse.note: Lit., flesh. So throughout this chapter. Our body is our being, our constitution. Hence, the discharges from our body are the discharges from our being or from our constitution. The uncleanness of the discharges from man's body ([link]vv. 2-3[/link]) signifies that whatever issues from man's natural life, whether good or evil, is unclean (cf. [link]Matt. 16:21-24[/link]; [link]Rom. 7:18[/link]).

verse.text: And this shall be his uncleanness of his discharge: Whether [note]1[/note]there is a discharge from his body, or the discharge is blocked in his body, it is his uncleanness.
verse.note: Lit., his body runs with his discharge, or, his body is stopped from his discharge.

verse.text: Every [note]1[/note]bed on which he who has the discharge lies shall be unclean, and everything on which he sits shall be unclean.
verse.note: Everything and anyone who touches man's discharge is unclean ([link]vv. 4-11[/link]), signifying that anything touched by or that touches the issue of man's natural life is unclean. Because we were born in uncleanness ([link]12:1-8[/link]; [link]Psa. 51:5[/link]) and are a totality of uncleanness, whatever issues out of our natural being as a discharge is both unclean and contagious, causing everyone, everything, and every place to be defiled.

verse.text: And whoever touches his bed shall [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]wash his clothes and [note]1[/note]bathe in water and be unclean [note]2[/note]until the evening.
verse.note: Washing the clothes and bathing in water ([link]vv. 5-8[/link], [link]10-11[/link]) signify not only dealing with our outward living and behavior and all the media through which man's natural life is contacted but also dealing with ourselves by washing in the water of life, the cleansing Spirit of life ([link]John 7:37-39[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:2[/link]), in the word of God ([link]Eph. 5:26[/link] and notes), purging away anything that is affected by our natural life.

[i]Until the evening[/i] signifies coming to an end through death. Hence, the uncleanness being until the evening ([link]vv. 5-8[/link], [link]10-11[/link]) signifies that the uncleanness of the issue of man's natural life should come to an end through the death of the cross that there might be a new beginning in resurrection. The way to be clean is to die by taking the cross of Christ and thereby entering a new day in resurrection ([link]Rom. 6:3-4[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:14-15[/link]).

chapter.verse: And whoever sits on anything on which he who has the discharge sat shall wash his clothes and bathe in water and be unclean until the evening.
And whoever touches the flesh of the one who has the discharge shall wash his clothes and bathe in water and be unclean until the evening.
And if the one who has the discharge spits on someone who is clean, then he [i]who has been spat on[/i] shall wash his clothes and bathe in water and be unclean until the evening.
And every saddle on which the one who has the discharge rides shall be unclean.
And whoever touches anything that was under him shall be unclean until the evening, and whoever carries those things shall wash his clothes and bathe in water and be unclean until the evening.

verse.text: And whomever the one who has the discharge touches without having [note]1[/note]rinsed his hands in water, he shall wash his clothes and bathe in water and be unclean until the evening.
verse.note: Rinsing the hands in water signifies purging away our filthiness with the word of God and with the life and Spirit in the word of God ([link]Eph. 5:26[/link]; [link]John 6:63[/link]).

verse.text: And the earthen vessel that the one who has the discharge touches shall be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]broken, and every vessel of wood shall be [note]1[/note]rinsed in water.
verse.note: This signifies that the created and fallen man (earthen vessel) should be broken, whereas the God-created humanity (wooden vessel) should be kept but needs to be rinsed. See note [link]11[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And when one who has the discharge is cleansed of his discharge, then he shall count [note]1[/note]seven days for himself for his cleansing; then he shall [note]1[/note]wash his clothes and [note]1[/note]bathe his body in running water, and he shall be clean.
verse.note: This signifies that the dealing with our natural life should be to the extent that our natural life is fully terminated (seven days) and that we should be cleansed with the word of God in His Spirit.

verse.text: And on the [note]1[/note]eighth day he shall take for himself two [xref]a[/xref]turtledoves or two young pigeons and come before Jehovah at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting and give them to the priest.
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 14[/link].

verse.text: And the priest shall offer them, one for a [note]1[/note]sin offering and the other for a [note]1[/note]burnt offering; and the priest shall make expiation for him before Jehovah for his discharge.
verse.note: The offering of two birds, one for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering, signifies that man living by his natural life needs not only the redemption of Christ to deal with his sinful nature but also the life of Christ that he may live a life that is absolute for God. Through Christ as our sin offering and our burnt offering the problem of the issues of our natural life is solved.

chapter.verse: And if any man's seed of copulation goes out from him, then he shall bathe his entire body in water and be unclean until the evening.
And any garment and any [i]article made of[/i] skin on which the seed of copulation comes shall be washed with water and be unclean until the evening.
If there is a woman with whom a man lies [i]and there is a discharge of[/i] seed of copulation, both of them shall bathe in water and be unclean until the evening.
And if a woman has a discharge, [i]and[/i] her discharge in her body is blood, she shall be in her impurity seven days; and whoever touches her shall be unclean until the evening.
And everything that she lies on in her impurity shall be unclean; everything also that she sits on shall be unclean.
And whoever touches her bed shall wash his clothes and bathe in water and be unclean until the evening.
And whoever touches anything that she sits on shall wash his clothes and bathe in water and be unclean until the evening.
And if it is on the bed or on anything on which she sits, when anyone touches it, he shall be unclean until the evening.
And if any man actually lies with her and her impurity comes on him, he shall be unclean seven days; and every bed on which he lies shall be unclean.

verse.text: And if a woman has a [xref]a[/xref]discharge of her blood for many days not at the time of her impurity, or if she has a discharge beyond the time of her impurity, during all the days of the discharge of her uncleanness she shall be as if in the days of her impurity; she is unclean.

chapter.verse: Any bed on which she lies during all the days of her discharge shall be to her like the bed of her impurity; and everything on which she sits shall be unclean, as in the uncleanness of her impurity.
And whoever touches those things shall be unclean, and he shall wash his clothes and bathe in water and be unclean until the evening.
But if she is cleansed of her discharge, then she shall count seven days for herself; and afterward she shall be clean.

verse.text: And on the eighth day she shall take for herself two [xref]a[/xref]turtledoves or two young pigeons and bring them to the priest at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting.

chapter.verse: And the priest shall offer one for a sin offering and the other for a burnt offering, and the priest shall make expiation for her before Jehovah for the discharge of her uncleanness.

verse.text: Thus you shall separate the children of Israel from their uncleanness, so that they do not [note]1[/note]die in their uncleanness by their defiling My tabernacle that is in the midst of them.
verse.note: Not being separated from one's uncleanness but dying in one's uncleanness by defiling God's dwelling place signifies that once a man who has been defiled by any issue of his natural life and who has not yet been separated from his uncleanness touches the church, thereby defiling God's dwelling place, he will suffer death (mainly spiritual death). In order to keep from defiling the church by the uncleanness of our natural life, we need to remain in the death, resurrection, Spirit, life, and word of Christ.

chapter.verse: This is the law for the one who has a discharge and for the one whose seed of copulation goes out from him and becomes unclean by it,
And for the one who is sick with her impurity, and for anyone who has a discharge, male or female, and for a man who lies with a woman who is unclean.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Then Jehovah spoke to Moses after the [xref]a[/xref]death of the two sons of Aaron, when they drew near before Jehovah and died.
verse.note: Because of the negative situation of God's people, as portrayed in [link]chs. 11-15[/link], according to God's concept and in His divine economy there is the need of redemption. Because the Old Testament time was not the time for redemption to take place, a type, a shadow, of the coming redemption was needed. This shadow is the expiation in this chapter. The expiation accomplished through the animal sacrifices in the Old Testament is a type pointing to the redemption accomplished by Christ in the New Testament.[br][br]The root of the Hebrew word translated [i]expiation[/i] means [i]to cover.[/i] The noun form of this word is rendered [i]expiation cover[/i] in [link]v. 2[/link] and in [link]Exo. 25:17[/link]. The root of the Greek word used in the Septuagint and in the New Testament, translated [i]propitiation[/i] in [link]Rom. 3:25[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:17[/link]; and [link]1 John 2:2[/link] and [link]4:10[/link], means [i]to appease[/i] (the situation between two parties). On the Day of Expiation the blood of the sin offering was brought into the Holy of Holies and sprinkled on the expiation cover, the lid of the Ark ([link]vv. 14-15[/link]), which covered the Ten Commandments within the Ark ([link]Exo. 25:16[/link]), signifying that the sin of the ones coming to contact God had been covered but not yet removed (see note [link]3[sup]3[/sup] in Heb. 1[/link]). In this way the situation of fallen man in relation to God was appeased but was not fully settled, until Christ came to accomplish redemption by offering Himself as the propitiatory sacrifice to take away man's sin ([link]Heb. 9:12[/link]; [link]2:17[/link]; [link]1 John 2:2[/link]; [link]4:10[/link]; [link]John 1:29[/link]). See notes [link book="Rom." chapter="3"]25[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]25[sup]3[/sup] in Rom. 3[/link], [link]17[sup]4[/sup] in Heb. 2[/link], [link]12[sup]2[/sup] in Heb. 9[/link], and [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in 1 John 2[/link].

verse.text: And Jehovah said to Moses, Tell Aaron your brother that he shall [note]1[/note]not enter at just any time into the Holy [i]of Holies[/i] inside the veil before the expiation cover, which is upon the Ark, lest he die; for I will appear in the cloud over the expiation cover.
verse.note: This signifies that man, being sinful because of the fall, is unable to enter into God's presence in himself. Man's coming near to God must be through Christ as his sin offering and his burnt offering ([link]v. 3[/link]).

verse.text: In this way Aaron shall [xref]a[/xref]come into the Holy [i]of Holies:[/i] with a [xref]b[/xref]bull of the herd for a sin offering and a [xref]c[/xref]ram for a burnt offering.

He shall put on the [note]1[/note]holy [xref]a[/xref]linen tunic, and linen trousers shall be upon his body, and he shall gird himself with the linen girdle and be attired with the linen turban; these are the holy garments. And he shall [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]bathe his flesh in water and put them on.
verse.note: All the linen garments worn by Aaron are types of God's righteousness and holiness, both of which are Christ ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]; [link]Acts 3:14[/link]). Aaron's putting on the holy garments signifies that the one who comes near to God (cf. [link]Heb. 10:19-22[/link]) should take Christ as his righteousness and holiness in order that he may cover his entire being and express Christ (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 28[/link]).

Aaron's bathing his flesh in water before putting on the holy garments signifies that one should deal with himself first, and then put on Christ as his covering, righteousness, and holiness (cf. [link]Gal. 3:27[/link]).

verse.text: And he shall take from the [note]1[/note]assembly of the children of Israel two male goats for a sin offering and one ram for a burnt offering.
verse.note: The bull and the ram in [link]v. 3[/link] were for Aaron himself ([link]vv. 6[/link], [link]11[/link]), whereas the two male goats and the ram in this verse were for the people. This signifies that anyone who desires to enter into God's presence and serve Him must himself experience Christ as the sin offering and the burnt offering that he might minister to others the Christ whom he has experienced.

verse.text: And Aaron shall present the bull of the sin offering, which is for [xref]a[/xref]himself, and make [note]1[/note]expiation for himself and for his household.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup][/link]. Aaron's offering the bull of the sin offering for himself indicates that as a type of the believers as God's priests ([link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link], [link]9[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:6[/link]; [link]5:10[/link]), he needed expiation for the fulfillment of the priesthood. As a type of Christ, Aaron did not need expiation.

chapter.verse: And he shall take the two goats and set them before Jehovah at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting.

verse.text: And Aaron shall cast lots on the two goats: one lot for Jehovah and the other lot for [note]1[/note]Azazel.
verse.note: Azazel signifies Satan, the devil, the sinful one, the one who is the source, the origin, of sin ([link]John 8:44[/link]). The goat that was for Jehovah was to be killed ([link]v. 9[/link]), but the goat that was for Azazel was to be sent away into the wilderness to bear away all the iniquities of the children of Israel on itself ([link]vv. 10[/link], [link]20-22[/link]). This signifies that Christ as the sin offering for God's people, on the one hand, deals with our sin before God and, on the other hand, sends sin, through the efficacy of the cross, back to Satan, from whom sin came into man. Through the cross the Lord Jesus has the position and qualification with the power, strength, and authority to take sin away from the redeemed ones ([link]John 1:29[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:26[/link]) and send it back to its source, Satan, who will bear it in the lake of fire forever ([link]Rev. 20:10[/link]).

chapter.verse: And Aaron shall present the goat on which the lot for Jehovah fell, and offer it [i]as[/i] a sin offering.

verse.text: But the goat on which the lot for Azazel fell shall be made to stand alive before Jehovah to make expiation over it, that it may be sent away [note]1[/note]for Azazel into the [xref]a[/xref]wilderness.
verse.note: Or, to. So also in [link]v. 26[/link].

verse.text: And Aaron shall present the bull of the sin offering, which is for [xref]a[/xref]himself, and shall make expiation for himself and for his household, and shall slaughter the bull of the sin offering, which is for himself.
And he shall take a [xref]a[/xref]censer full of coals of fire from the altar before Jehovah, with his hands full of finely ground sweet [note]1[/note]incense, and bring [i]it[/i] inside the veil.
verse.note: The burning of the incense (see Exo. 30:34-38 and notes) after the slaughtering of the sin offering, so that Aaron would not die ([link]vv. 11-13[/link]), signifies that in His resurrection the Lord Jesus became a sweet fragrance to be the means and the protection for us to draw near to God with all boldness and be accepted by God without suffering death (cf. [link]Heb. 10:19-22[/link]). This is one of the results produced through the redemptive, blood-shedding death (signified by the coals of fire from the altar and the finely ground incense of spices) of the Lord Jesus on the cross.[br][br]The incense was burned with the fire from the altar in the outer court, signifying that Christ's being burned as the incense for our acceptance before God depends on His death on the cross for our sins. Christ first became the offerings to take away our sin; then, in His resurrection, with His death on the cross as the basis, He became the incense for our acceptance.

verse.text: And he shall put the [xref]a[/xref]incense upon the fire before Jehovah, that the cloud of the incense may cover the [xref]b[/xref]expiation cover that is over the Testimony, so that he does not die.

And he shall take some of the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]blood of the bull and [xref]b[/xref]sprinkle it with his finger upon the [note]2[/note]expiation cover toward the east, and before the expiation cover he shall sprinkle some of the blood with his finger seven times.
verse.note: The sprinkling of the blood of the sin offering on the expiation cover ([link]vv. 14-15[/link]) signifies that the redeeming blood of Christ was brought into the heavens, into the presence of God, and sprinkled before God to meet God's righteous requirements for our redemption ([link]Heb. 9:12[/link]).
See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 25[/link].

verse.text: Then he shall slaughter the goat of the sin offering, which is for the people, and bring its [xref]a[/xref]blood [xref]b[/xref]inside the veil, and do with its blood as he did with the blood of the bull, and sprinkle it upon the expiation cover and before the expiation cover.

And he shall make expiation for the [note]1[/note]Holy [i]of Holies[/i] because of the uncleannesses of the children of Israel and because of their transgressions, for all their sins. And so he shall do for the [note]1[/note]Tent of Meeting, which dwells with them in the midst of their uncleannesses.
verse.note: Making expiation for the Holy of Holies and for the Tent of Meeting because of the uncleanness and transgressions of the children of Israel signifies that although we have been redeemed and washed by the blood of Christ, because we are still in the old creation and still live in uncleanness, in our worship of God there is still the consciousness of sin and thus the need of the propitiation by the blood of Christ ([link]1 John 1:7-2:2[/link]). This consciousness of sin will continue until we are raptured and transfigured in our body ([link]Phil. 3:21[/link]).

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]no one shall be in the Tent of Meeting when he goes in to make expiation in the Holy [i]of Holies[/i] until he comes out and has made expiation for himself and for his household and for all the congregation of Israel.
verse.note: This signifies that the Lord Jesus alone can make propitiation for our sins ([link]Heb. 2:17[/link]).

verse.text: Then he shall go out to the altar that is before Jehovah and make expiation for it, and he shall take some of the blood of the bull and some of the blood of the goat, and [xref]a[/xref]put [i]it[/i] on and around the [note]1[/note]horns of the altar.
verse.note: Putting the blood of the sin offering on and around the four horns of the burnt offering altar signifies that the efficacy of the redemption accomplished on the cross is toward the four corners of the earth. According to [link]Exo. 30:10[/link] (cf. [link]4:7[/link], [link]18[/link]), blood was put also on the horns of the incense altar, signifying the efficacy of Christ's blood for us to be accepted by God in our prayer. See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].

verse.text: And he shall [note]1[/note]sprinkle some of the blood on it with his finger seven times; thus he will [note]2[/note]cleanse it and sanctify it from the uncleannesses of the children of Israel.
verse.note: The sprinkling of the blood on the altar seven times signifies that the full (signified by the number seven) efficacy of the blood shed on the cross by Christ is so that the sinner may be at peace in his heart (cf. [link]Heb. 9:14[/link]). The blood sprinkled on the expiation cover ([link]vv. 14-15[/link]) was for God's satisfaction, whereas the blood sprinkled on the altar of burnt offering was for the sinner's peace.

The cleansing and sanctifying of the altar from the uncleanness of the children of Israel signifies that all the world's sins were gathered upon the cross of Christ and were cleansed away ([link]1 Pet. 2:24a[/link]) so that God and His people may enjoy one another in a situation of cleanness.

verse.text: And when he has finished making [xref]a[/xref]expiation for the [note]1[/note]Holy [i]of Holies[/i] and the Tent of Meeting and the altar, he shall present the [note]2[/note]live goat.
verse.note: Even the Holy of Holies, the Tent of Meeting, and the altar, which are holy things, were contaminated by the uncleanness of God's redeemed people. That expiation was made for all these signifies that the sin offering is offered not only for the removal of our uncleanness but also for the perfecting of God's holiness, into which we have been brought (cf. [link]2 Cor. 7:1[/link]; [link]Heb. 13:12[/link]).
For [link]vv. 20-22[/link], see note [link]8[sup]1[/sup][/link].

chapter.verse: And Aaron shall lay both his hands on the head of the live goat and confess over it all the iniquities of the children of Israel and all their transgressions, even all their sins; and he shall put them on the head of the goat, and shall send [i]it[/i] away into the wilderness by means of the man who has been appointed.
Thus the goat shall bear away all their iniquities on itself to a solitary land, and he shall let the goat go in the wilderness.
And Aaron shall come into the Tent of Meeting and take off the linen garments, which he put on when he went into the Holy [i]of Holies,[/i] and leave them there.

verse.text: And he shall [note]1[/note]bathe his body in water in a holy place and put on his garments. Then he shall come out and [note]1[/note]offer his burnt offering and the burnt offering of the people, and make expiation for himself and for the people.
verse.note: Aaron's bathing his body and offering the burnt offering signifies that after we have received the redemption of the Lord Jesus and the problem of our sins has been solved, we need the cleansing of the Spirit that we may take Christ as our burnt offering to live for God by the life of Christ. The sin offering was offered ([link]v. 9[/link]) in view of the burnt offering, indicating that the purpose of Christ's complete redemption is that we, the redeemed ones, taking Christ as our life and life supply, might become those who in Christ live absolutely for God.

verse.text: And the fat of the sin offering he shall [note]1[/note]burn on the altar.
verse.note: I.e., burn as incense. The burning of the fat of the sin offering as incense signifies that the Lord Jesus' death on the cross is for our redemption and that His heart toward God and for God (signified by the fat as the tender part of the sin offering) is for God's acceptance. In this chapter both Christ as the incense burned on the incense altar ([link]vv. 12-13[/link]) and the heart of Christ, which is toward God and for God, are a sweet savor to God that is acceptable to God and that becomes God's acceptance of us.

verse.text: And he who lets the goat go for Azazel shall [note]1[/note]wash his clothes and [note]1[/note]bathe his body in water, and afterward he may come into the camp.
verse.note: This signifies that the one who is defiled by contacting anything related to sin must deal with his outward living (signified by the clothes) and with himself as well. So also for [link]v. 28[/link].

verse.text: And the bull of the sin offering and the goat of the sin offering, whose blood was brought in to make expiation in the Holy [i]of Holies,[/i] shall be carried forth [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]outside the camp; and they shall burn in the fire their skins and their flesh and their dung.
verse.note: The carrying of the sin offering outside the camp and the burning of its skin, its flesh, and its dung signify, first, that the Lord Jesus accomplished on the cross, once for all, the eternal and perfect redemption ([link]Heb. 9:12[/link]), and His serving ones have no participation in this matter ([link]6:30[/link] and note; [link]Heb. 13:10-11[/link] and note [link]10[sup]1[/sup][/link]). They signify, second, that the Lord who accomplished redemption was rejected by man; hence, whoever receives His redemption should go with Him outside the camp, bearing His reproach ([link]Heb. 13:12-13[/link] and notes).

chapter.verse: And he who burns them shall wash his clothes and bathe his body in water, and afterward he may come into the camp.

verse.text: And [i]this[/i] shall become a perpetual statute for you; in the seventh month on the [xref]a[/xref]tenth day of the month you shall [note]1[/note]afflict your souls and [note]2[/note]not do any work, neither the native nor the sojourner who sojourns among you.
verse.note: Here afflicting one's soul signifies mourning, repenting, and feeling sorrowful for sin.

The people not doing any work, for it was a Sabbath of complete rest for them ([link]v. 31[/link]), signifies that redemption has been completely finished by Christ. There is nothing left for man to do, and man should rest in the redemption of Christ.

chapter.verse: For on this day expiation shall be made for you, in order to cleanse you; from all your sins you shall be clean before Jehovah.
It is a Sabbath of complete rest for you, and you shall afflict your souls. It shall be a perpetual statute.
And the priest who is anointed and who is consecrated to serve as a priest in his father's place shall make expiation; thus he shall put on the linen garments, even the holy garments.

verse.text: And he shall make [xref]a[/xref]expiation for the [note]1[/note]holy sanctuary, and he shall make expiation for the Tent of Meeting and for the altar, and he shall make expiation for the priests and for all the people of the congregation.
verse.note: I.e., the Holy of Holies.

verse.text: And this shall become a perpetual statute for you, in order to make expiation for the children of Israel because of all their sins, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]once in the year. And just as Jehovah had commanded Moses, [i]so[/i] he did.
verse.note: The making of expiation once a year signifies that the offering was unable to make man perfect and that it was only a shadow of the "good things to come" ([link]Heb. 10:1[/link]), until the Son of God would come to complete the full redemption ([link]Heb. 9:1-10:18[/link]).

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,
Speak to Aaron and to his sons and to all the children of Israel, and say to them, This is what Jehovah has commanded, saying,
Anyone of the house of Israel who slaughters an ox or a sheep or a goat within the camp, or who slaughters [i]it[/i] outside the camp,

verse.text: And has not [xref]a[/xref]brought it to the [note]1[/note]entrance of the Tent of Meeting to present [i]it[/i] as an offering to Jehovah before the tabernacle of Jehovah, that man shall be accounted as guilty of bloodshed. He has shed blood, and that man shall be [note]2[/note]cut off from among his people.
verse.note: According to [link]vv. 3-9[/link], the sacrifices were to be offered to God only at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting before Jehovah, and their blood was to be shed on the altar. This signifies that our applying the Lord Jesus as our sacrifices offered to God and our participating in His redeeming blood must be at the entrance of God's dwelling place (the church) on earth and must be through the cross. In our worship of God, Christ as the unique sacrifice should be applied according to God's desire and economy, within the regulations, restrictions, and limitations set by Him. To apply Christ outside the church, i.e., in a place according to our preference and choice (cf. [link]Deut. 12:5-6[/link]), is to abuse Christ.
To be cut off from one's people ([link]vv. 4[/link], [link]9-10[/link], [link]14[/link]) signifies to be removed from the fellowship of God's people (cf. [link]1 Cor. 5:13[/link]).

verse.text: [i]This is[/i] so that the children of Israel will bring their sacrifices which they sacrifice in the open field, that they will bring them to Jehovah at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting to the priest and sacrifice them as sacrifices of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]peace offerings to Jehovah.
verse.note: The expiation in [link]ch. 16[/link] involved four of the five basic offerings: the sin offering, the trespass offering (implied in the sin offering — [link]5:6[/link]), the burnt offering, and the meal offering. The issue of these offerings is the peace offering, with the result that God's people enjoy peace with God and with one another. See note [link]37[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 7[/link].

verse.text: And the priest shall [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sprinkle the blood on the altar of Jehovah at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting and [note]1[/note]burn the fat for a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah.
verse.note: The sprinkling of the blood on the altar signifies that Christ's blood was shed on the cross. Burning the fat for a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah signifies that Christ's excellencies are offered up to God through God's holy fire for a fragrance to satisfy God.

verse.text: And they shall [note]1[/note]no more sacrifice their [xref]a[/xref]sacrifices to the goat demons, to whom they [note]2[/note]prostitute themselves. This shall become a perpetual statute for them throughout their generations.
verse.note: No longer sacrificing to goat demons signifies no longer having fellowship with demons so as to commit spiritual fornication ([link]1 Cor. 10:20-21[/link]).

The word [i]prostitute[/i] here indicates that for an Israelite (a believer) to abuse the sacrifices (Christ) by offering them in the place of his choice (outside the church) was to make himself a prostitute. This is a matter of spiritual prostitution, of spiritual fornication. See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup][/link].

chapter.verse: And you shall say to them, Anyone of the house of Israel or of the sojourners who sojourn among them, who offers a burnt offering or sacrifice

verse.text: And does not [xref]a[/xref]bring it to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting to sacrifice it to Jehovah, that man shall be cut off from his people.

And anyone of the house of Israel or of the sojourners who sojourn among them, who eats any [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]blood, I will set My face against that person who eats blood and cut him off from among his people.
verse.note: On not eating blood ([link]vv. 10[/link], [link]12[/link]), see note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link].

verse.text: For the [xref]a[/xref]life of the flesh is in the blood; and I have given it to you to make expiation for your souls on the altar, for it is the [xref]b[/xref]blood, by reason of the life, that makes expiation.
Therefore I said to the children of Israel, No person among you shall eat [xref]a[/xref]blood, nor shall any sojourner who sojourns among you eat blood.

And anyone of the children of Israel or of the sojourners who sojourn among them, who in hunting takes an animal or bird that may be eaten, shall pour out its blood and [note]1[/note]cover it with dust.
verse.note: This signifies that all the blood that man can obtain other than the blood of the Lord Jesus cannot redeem us from our sins and should be buried, i.e., given up, abandoned, rejected.

verse.text: For as to the life of all flesh, its blood is [note]1[/note]its very life; therefore I have said to the children of Israel, You shall not [xref]a[/xref]eat the blood of any flesh, for the life of all flesh is its blood; whoever eats it shall be cut off.
verse.note: Lit., with its life.

verse.text: And every person who eats that which [note]1[/note]dies of itself or is [note]2[/note]torn [i]by beasts,[/i] whether he is a native or a sojourner, shall [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]wash his clothes and [note]3[/note]bathe in water and be unclean until the [note]4[/note]evening; then he shall be clean.
verse.note: The blood of that which dies of itself signifies the blood of one who sacrifices himself for the good of others, which blood cannot redeem us from our sins. Only the blood of Jesus Christ, whom God bruised on the cross ([link]Isa. 53:10[/link]), can cleanse us from all sin ([link]1 John 1:7[/link]).

The blood of that which is torn by beasts signifies the blood of one who is martyred by wild people, who are like beasts, which blood also is unable to redeem us from our sins. Only the blood of Jesus Christ, whom God judged on the cross ([link]Isa. 53:8[/link]), is able to wash us from our sins ([link]Rev. 1:5[/link]).

This signifies that the one who takes any blood other than the blood of the Lord Jesus should deal with his former behavior and with what he was in the past concerning religion and should purge himself. Otherwise, he will be condemned.[br][br]To eat different bloods is equivalent to forming different religions based on beliefs in different persons. The one blood ordained by God is the blood of Jesus Christ shed on the cross ([link]John 6:53-55[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 10:16a[/link], [link]21a[/link]), and the one belief is the belief in the Christ who died on the cross for us (see note [link]5[sup]3[/sup] in Rom. 1[/link]).

Being unclean until the evening signifies that the one who takes any blood, i.e., any belief, other than the blood of the Lord Jesus is unclean until the matter is cleared up and brought to a complete ending.

verse.text: But if he does not wash [i]them[/i] or bathe his [note]1[/note]body, then he shall bear his iniquity.
verse.note: Lit., flesh.

verse.text: Then Jehovah [note]1[/note]spoke to Moses, saying,
verse.note: Chapters 18-20 of this book, on the holy living of God's holy people, correspond to [link]Eph. 4:17-5:14[/link], which charges the holy people of God to put off the old man and put on the new man, living a life that is holy, as God is holy.

chapter.verse: Speak to the children of Israel, and say to them, I am Jehovah your God.

verse.text: You shall not do as [i]they[/i] do in the land of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Egypt, in which you dwelt; and you shall not do as [i]they[/i] do in the land of [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Canaan, where I am bringing you, nor shall you walk in their statutes.
verse.note: The Israelites' not living in the manner of the Egyptians, among whom they once lived, signifies that the believers should put off, as regards their former old way of living, the old man ([link]Eph. 4:22[/link]). The Israelites' not living in the manner of the Canaanites, to whose land they were to be brought, signifies that, after being saved, the believers should not be conformed to the living and conduct of the worldly people ([link]Rom. 12:2[/link]). The Israelites' living a holy life according to God's holiness ([link]v. 4[/link]-[link]20:27[/link]) signifies that the believers should put on the new man, which was created according to God in righteousness and holiness of the truth ([link]Eph. 4:24[/link]).

verse.text: You shall observe My [note]1[/note]ordinances, and you shall keep My [note]1[/note]statutes to walk in them; I am Jehovah your God.
verse.note: See note [link]6[sup]4[/sup] in Luke 1[/link].

verse.text: So you shall keep My statutes and My ordinances, by which, [xref]a[/xref]if a man does [i]them,[/i] he will [note]1[/note]live; I am Jehovah.
verse.note: Cf. [link]Gal. 3:21[/link] and note 1.

verse.text: None of you shall approach to any of [note]1[/note]his [xref]a[/xref]close relatives to uncover [i]their[/i] nakedness; I am Jehovah.
verse.note: Lit., flesh of his flesh.

chapter.verse: The nakedness of your father, that is, the nakedness of your mother, you shall not uncover. She is your mother; you shall not uncover her nakedness.

verse.text: The nakedness of your [xref]a[/xref]father's wife you shall not uncover; it is your father's nakedness.

chapter.verse: The nakedness of your sister, your father's daughter, or your mother's daughter, whether born at home or born abroad, their nakedness you shall not uncover.
The nakedness of your son's daughter or of your daughter's daughter, their nakedness you shall not uncover; for their [i]nakedness[/i] is your own nakedness.
The nakedness of your father's wife's daughter, begotten of your father — she is your sister — you shall not uncover her nakedness.
You shall not uncover the nakedness of your father's sister; she is your father's flesh.
You shall not uncover the nakedness of your mother's sister, for she is your mother's flesh.
You shall not uncover the nakedness of your father's brother, [i]that is,[/i] you shall not approach his wife; she is your aunt.
You shall not uncover the nakedness of your daughter-in-law; she is your son's wife; you shall not uncover her nakedness.

verse.text: You shall not uncover the nakedness of your [xref]a[/xref]brother's wife; it is your brother's nakedness.

chapter.verse: You shall not uncover the nakedness of a woman and her daughter; you shall not take her son's daughter or her daughter's daughter to uncover her nakedness; they are [i]her[/i] flesh; it is wickedness.
And you shall not take [i]a woman as[/i] wife in addition to her sister, as a rival to uncover her nakedness while she is alive.
And you shall not approach a woman to uncover her nakedness while she is in her menstrual uncleanness.
And you shall not have sexual relations with the wife of your fellow countryman to become defiled with her.

verse.text: And you shall not give any of your offspring to pass through [i]the fire[/i] to [xref]a[/xref]Molech, and so profane the name of your God; I am Jehovah.
You shall not lie with a [xref]a[/xref]male as one lies with a woman; it is an abomination.

chapter.verse: And you shall not lie with any beast to defile yourself with it; neither shall any woman stand before a beast, to lie down with it; it is confusion.
Do not defile yourselves in any of these things, for by all these the nations which I am casting out before you have defiled themselves.

verse.text: Because the land has become defiled, I [note]1[/note]visited its iniquity upon it, and the [xref]a[/xref]land [note]2[/note]vomited out its inhabitants.
verse.note: Or, punished it for its iniquity.

The land, signifying Christ (see note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Deut. 8[/link]), is the supply for the existence and living of God's people and is also for their enjoyment. The good land vomiting out the defiled and unholy people ([link]vv. 25[/link], [link]28[/link]; [link]20:22[/link]) signifies that the all-inclusive Christ as our dwelling place and everything we need for our enjoyment will vomit us out of Himself and not allow us to enjoy Him any longer (cf. [link]Rev. 3:16[/link]) if we are not proper in relation to Him.

chapter.verse: You therefore shall keep My statutes and My ordinances, and shall not do any of these abominations, [i]neither[/i] the native nor the sojourner who sojourns among you
(For the men of the land who were before you have done all these abominations, and the land has become defiled);
That the land does not vomit you out when you defile it, as it vomited out the nation which was before you.
For all who do any of these abominations, those persons who do [i]them[/i] shall be cut off from among their people.
Therefore you shall keep My charge, so that you do not commit any of these abominable customs which were committed before you, and you do not defile yourselves by them; I am Jehovah your God.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Speak to all the assembly of the children of Israel, and say to them, You shall be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]holy, for I, Jehovah your God, am holy.
verse.note: Being holy because God is holy ([link]v. 2[/link]; [link]20:7[/link], [link]26[/link]) signifies walking according to God's holiness, living a holy life ([link]1 Pet. 1:15[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 3:11[/link]).

chapter.verse: Each one of you shall fear his mother and his father, and you shall keep My Sabbaths; I am Jehovah your God.

verse.text: Do not turn to [xref]a[/xref]idols or make for yourselves molten gods; I am Jehovah your God.
[xref]a[/xref]And when you offer a sacrifice of [note]1[/note]peace offerings to Jehovah, you shall sacrifice it so that you may be accepted.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link]. The offering of the peace offering in an acceptable way signifies that the breaking of bread for the remembrance of the Lord should be done in a way that is acceptable to the Lord (cf. [link]1 Cor. 11:17-21[/link]).[br][br]The mentioning of the peace offering here indicates that in the holy living of God's holy people, as portrayed in [link]chs. 18-20[/link], it is important that God's holy people have fellowship, communion, mutual enjoyment, in peace.

verse.text: It shall be eaten on the [note]1[/note]day you sacrifice [i]it,[/i] or on the next day, but what remains until the third day shall be burned with fire.
verse.note: The word in [link]vv. 6-8[/link] signifies that the believers' enjoyment of Christ as the peace offering for their fellowship with God and with one another should be kept fresh. Stale fellowship with one another and with God is not acceptable but is abhorrent to God ([link]v. 7[/link]). The one who participates in stale fellowship is guilty of having despised the holy things of God and will lose the fellowship among God's people ([link]v. 8[/link]).

chapter.verse: But if it is eaten at all on the third day, it is an abomination; it will not be accepted.
And whoever eats it will bear his own iniquity, because he has profaned what is holy to Jehovah; and that person shall be cut off from his people.

verse.text: And when you [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]reap the harvest of your land, you shall not wholly reap the corners of your field, nor shall you gather the gleaning of your harvest.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 9-10[/link], see notes on [link]Ruth 2:2[/link].

chapter.verse: And you shall not glean your vineyard nor shall you gather the fallen fruit of your vineyard. You shall leave them for the poor and for the sojourner; I am Jehovah your God.
You shall not steal; neither shall you deceive nor deal falsely with one another.

verse.text: And you shall not [xref]a[/xref]swear falsely by My name, thus profaning the name of your God; I am Jehovah.
You shall not oppress your neighbor nor rob him. The [xref]a[/xref]wages of a hired servant shall not remain with you all night until the morning.

chapter.verse: You shall not curse the deaf nor put a stumbling block before the blind, but you shall fear your God; I am Jehovah.
You shall do no unrighteousness in judgment; you shall not respect the person of the poor nor honor the person of the great, but in righteousness you shall judge your fellow countryman.

verse.text: You shall not go around as a slanderer among your people, nor shall you [note]1[/note]profit by the blood of your neighbor; I am Jehovah.
verse.note: Lit., stand against the blood.

verse.text: You shall not hate your brother in your heart; [i]but[/i] you shall surely [xref]a[/xref]reprove your fellow countryman, so that you do not bring sin [i]upon yourself[/i] because of him.
You shall not take vengeance nor bear any grudge against the children of your people, but you shall [xref]a[/xref]love your neighbor as yourself; I am Jehovah.

You shall keep My statutes. You shall not let your [note]1[/note]cattle breed with a different kind; you shall not sow your field with two kinds of [note]1[/note]seed, nor shall a [note]1[/note]garment made of two kinds of material come upon you.
verse.note: The fact that no mixture was allowed indicates that God wants everything to be after its kind (cf. [link]Gen. 1:11[/link], [link]21[/link], [link]24-25[/link]), without any kind of mixture. Breeding cattle without mixture signifies that life is not allowed to be mixed: those living by the life of God must not live by the flesh (cf. [link]Gal. 5:16[/link]). Sowing seed without mixture signifies that the ministry of the word is not allowed to be mixed: the word of God that is ministered should not be mixed with the word of the world (cf. [link]1 Cor. 2:13[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 1:3-4[/link]). Making a garment without mixing materials signifies that our conduct is not allowed to be mixed: those living in the life of the New Testament should not live by the ordinances of the Old Testament ([link]Gal. 2:19-20[/link]; [link]5:1-6[/link]), and those who belong to the Lord should not live according to the customs of the Gentiles ([link]20:23[/link]; cf. [link]Eph. 4:17[/link]; [link]Rom. 12:2a[/link]). See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 18[/link].

chapter.verse: And if a man lies down [i]and has[/i] sexual relations with a woman who is a slave designated for [i]another[/i] man, but not at all redeemed nor given her freedom, there shall be an inquiry; they shall not be put to death, because she was not freed.
And he shall bring his trespass offering to Jehovah, to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting, a ram for a trespass offering.
And the priest shall make expiation for him before Jehovah with the ram of the trespass offering for his sin which he has committed; and the sin which he has committed will be forgiven him.

verse.text: And when you come into the land and plant all kinds of trees for food, then you shall count their fruit as [note]1[/note]unharvestable. Three years it shall be [note]1[/note]unharvestable to you; it shall not be eaten.
verse.note: Lit., their uncircumcision...uncircumcisions.

chapter.verse: But in the fourth year all their fruit shall be holy, for giving praise to Jehovah.
And in the fifth year you may eat of their fruit, that their produce may increase for you; I am Jehovah your God.
You shall not eat [i]anything[/i] with blood, nor shall you practice divination or soothsaying.
You shall not round the corners of your heads, nor shall you mar the edges of your beard.
You shall not make any cuttings in your flesh for the dead, nor inscribe any marks upon you; I am Jehovah.
Do not profane your daughter by making her a harlot, so that the land does not fall to harlotry, and the land become full of wickedness.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]You shall keep My Sabbaths and revere My sanctuary; I am Jehovah.
Do not turn to [xref]a[/xref]mediums or to spiritists; do not seek after them to be defiled by them; I am Jehovah your God.
You shall [xref]a[/xref]rise up before the grayheaded and honor the face of the old man. And you shall fear your God; I am Jehovah.

chapter.verse: And if a sojourner sojourns with you in your land, you shall not do him wrong.

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]sojourner who sojourns with you shall be to you as the native among you, and you shall love him as yourself; for you were sojourners in the land of Egypt; I am Jehovah your God.

chapter.verse: You shall do no unrighteousness in judgment, in measures of length, of weight, or of quantity.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]You shall have just [xref]b[/xref]balances, just weights, a just ephah, and a just hin; I am Jehovah your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt.

chapter.verse: And you shall observe all My statutes and all My ordinances, and do them; I am Jehovah.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Moreover you shall say to the children of Israel, Anyone of the children of Israel or of the sojourners who sojourn in Israel who gives any of his offspring to [xref]a[/xref]Molech shall surely be put to death; the people of the land shall stone him with stones.

chapter.verse: I will also set My face against that man and will cut him off from among his people because he has given one of his offspring to Molech, so as to defile My sanctuary and profane My holy name.
And if the people of the land ever hide their eyes from that man when he gives some of his offspring to Molech, and do not put him to death,
Then I will set My face against that man and against his family, and I will cut off from among their people him and all who prostitute themselves after him, to prostitute themselves after Molech.
And the person who turns to mediums and to spiritists to prostitute himself after them, I will even set My face against that person and will cut him off from among his people.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Sanctify yourselves therefore, and be [note]1[/note]holy; for I am Jehovah your God.
verse.note: See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 19[/link].

chapter.verse: And you shall keep My statutes and do them; I am Jehovah who sanctifies you.

verse.text: If there is anyone who [xref]a[/xref]curses his father or his mother, he shall surely be put to death. He has cursed his father or his mother; his [xref]b[/xref]blood is upon him.
If there is a man who commits [xref]a[/xref]adultery with another man's wife, even one who commits adultery with his neighbor's wife, the adulterer and the adulteress shall surely be put to death.
If there is a man who [xref]a[/xref]lies with his father's wife, he has uncovered his father's nakedness. Both of them shall surely be put to death; their blood shall be upon them.

chapter.verse: If there is a man who lies with his daughter-in-law, both of them shall surely be put to death. They have brought about confusion; their blood shall be upon them.
If there is a man who lies with a male as with a woman, both of them have committed an abomination. They shall surely be put to death; their blood is upon them.
If there is a man who takes a wife and her mother, it is wickedness. They shall be burnt with fire, both he and they, that there be no wickedness among you.
If there is a man who lies with a beast, he shall surely be put to death; and you shall slaughter the beast.

verse.text: If there is a woman who approaches any beast to lie down with it, you shall kill the woman and the beast. They shall surely be put to death; their [xref]a[/xref]blood shall be upon them.

chapter.verse: If there is a man who takes his sister, his father's daughter or his mother's daughter, and he sees her nakedness and she sees his nakedness, it is a reproach, and they shall be cut off in the sight of the children of their people. He has uncovered his sister's nakedness; he shall bear his iniquity.

If there is a man who lies with a woman having her sickness, and he uncovers her nakedness, he has laid bare her flow, and she has uncovered the flow of her blood; and both of them shall be cut off from among their people.
And you shall not uncover the nakedness of your mother's sister nor of your father's sister, for he has made naked his flesh; they shall bear their iniquity.
If there is a man who lies with his aunt, he has uncovered his uncle's nakedness. They shall bear their sin; they shall die childless.

verse.text: If there is a man who takes his [xref]a[/xref]brother's wife, it is impurity. He has uncovered his brother's nakedness; they shall be childless.
You shall therefore keep all My statutes and all My ordinances, and do them, so that the [xref]a[/xref]land into which I am bringing you to dwell in does not [note]1[/note]vomit you out.
verse.note: See note [link]25[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 18[/link].

verse.text: And you shall not walk in the [xref]a[/xref]customs of the nation, which I am about to send away before you. Because they did all these things, so I abhorred them.

But I have said to you, You shall inherit their land, and I will give it to you to possess it, a [note]1[/note]land flowing with [xref]a[/xref]milk and honey. I am Jehovah your God, who has separated you from the peoples.
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Deut. 8[/link].

verse.text: You shall therefore make a distinction between the [note]1[/note]clean beast and the [note]1[/note]unclean, and between the unclean bird and the clean, and you shall not make your souls abominable by any beast or by any bird or by anything that creeps on the ground, which I have separated for you as unclean.
verse.note: See notes [link chapter="11"]2[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]47[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 11[/link].

verse.text: And you shall be [xref]a[/xref]holy to Me, because I Jehovah am holy, and I have set you apart from the peoples to be Mine.
If there is a man or a woman who is a [xref]a[/xref]medium or a spiritist, they shall surely be put to death. They shall stone them with stones; their [xref]b[/xref]blood shall be upon them.
And Jehovah said to Moses, Speak to the priests, the sons of Aaron, and say to them, [xref]a[/xref]No one shall [note]1[/note]defile himself for a [i]dead[/i] person among his people,
verse.note: The priests not being allowed to defile and profane themselves for a dead person among their people, except for their relatives ([link]vv. 1-4[/link]), signifies that we, the New Testament believers, being priests of God ([link]Rev. 1:5-6[/link]; [link]5:10[/link]), should not behave ourselves like the common people and thereby defile and profane ourselves.

chapter.verse: Except for his relative who is near to him, for his mother and for his father and for his son and for his daughter and for his brother
And for his virgin sister, who is near to him, who has had no husband; for her he may defile himself.

verse.text: He shall not defile himself, [i]as[/i] a [note]1[/note]leader among his people, so as to profane himself.
verse.note: Or, husband.

verse.text: They shall not make any [note]1[/note]baldness on their head or [note]1[/note]shave off the edges of their beard or make any [note]1[/note]cuttings in their flesh.
verse.note: To make our head bald indicates that we do not subject ourselves to God's headship, that we do not accept God's authority over us (cf. [link]1 Cor. 11:5[/link]), and to shave off the corners of the beard or to make cuttings in the flesh indicates that we are engaging in human labor to have some change in our body, which was designed and created by God. Instead of making such changes, we should accept what God has ordained for us and subject ourselves to God's authority, not making any change or any display or performance by our human labor, but remaining natural.

verse.text: They shall be [note]1[/note]holy to their God, and they shall not profane the name of their God, for they present Jehovah's offerings by fire, the food of their God; therefore they shall be holy.
verse.note: This signifies that we, the ones who minister Christ to God as food for God's enjoyment, should separate ourselves to be holy unto God. So also for [link]v. 8[/link].

verse.text: They shall not take a [note]1[/note]woman who is a harlot or profaned, nor shall they take a woman put away from her husband; for the [note]2[/note]priest is holy to his God.
