verse.note: [link]Verses 7[/link], [link chapter="21"]9[/link], and [link]13-15[/link] speak of purity in marriage, even concerning the high priest's offspring. This signifies that we who serve God as priests and who bear the highest responsibility in God's service should be pure in our closest human relationship, for ourselves and even for our offspring.
Lit., he.

verse.text: You shall sanctify him therefore, for he presents the food of your God. He shall be [xref]a[/xref]holy to you, for I Jehovah, who sanctifies you, am holy.

chapter.verse: And the daughter of any priest, if she profanes herself through prostitution, she profanes her father; she shall be burnt with fire.

verse.text: And he who is the high priest among his brothers, on whose head the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]anointing oil has been poured and who has been consecrated to [note]1[/note]put on the garments, shall not let the hair of his head go [note]1[/note]loose nor [note]1[/note]tear his clothes.
verse.note: The anointing oil being poured on the head of the high priest (who typifies Christ — see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 28[/link]) signifies that we, the New Testament priests as Christ's Body, have the anointing Spirit upon us for our priestly service ([link]2 Cor. 1:21[/link]; [link]Psa. 133:2[/link]). To put on the priestly garments signifies that we should live a life that befits our priestly service. Not letting the hair go loose signifies that we submit to God's authority and are not disobedient, unrestrained, or disorderly in our actions. Not tearing one's clothes (signifying one's behavior — [link]Rev. 19:8[/link]) signifies that we should not make ourselves bankrupt in morality.

verse.text: Neither shall he approach any dead person nor [note]1[/note]defile himself [i]even[/i] for his father or for his mother.
verse.note: The high priest not being defiled even by the death of his father or his mother signifies that when we bear the highest priesthood, having the closest fellowship with God, we should restrain our natural affection, not defiling ourselves even by our affection for our parents (cf. [link]Matt. 10:37[/link]; [link]12:46-50[/link]).

verse.text: Neither shall he go out of the sanctuary nor profane the sanctuary of his God, for the [note]1[/note]consecration of the anointing oil of his God is upon him; I am Jehovah.
verse.note: Heb. [i]nezer;[/i] from the same root from which the word [i]Nazarite[/i] comes. The word can also be translated [i]separation.[/i]

chapter.verse: And he shall take a wife in her virginity.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]A widow or a divorced woman or a profaned woman, a harlot, these he shall not take; but rather a virgin of his own people he shall take as wife.

chapter.verse: And he shall not profane his seed among his people, for I am Jehovah who sanctifies him.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Speak to Aaron, saying, No one of your seed throughout their generations who has a [note]1[/note]defect shall approach to present the food of his God.
verse.note: Being disqualified from the priesthood because of a defect signifies that anyone who is deficient in Christ is not able to minister Christ as food to God.

verse.text: For no one who has a [note]1[/note]defect shall approach: one who is blind or lame or with a disfigured nose or with an extended [i]limb,[/i]
verse.note: The various defects listed in [link]vv. 18-20[/link] have the following significances: Blindness signifies a lack of sight for seeing because of the shortage of Christ as the enlightening light (cf. [link]John 8:12[/link]). Lameness signifies the lack of strength for acting because of the shortage of the strengthening Christ (cf. [link]Phil. 4:13[/link]). A disfigured nose signifies the lack of Christ as the sensing ability in our service to God (cf. [link]S.S. 7:4b[/link]). Having one limb longer than the other signifies overstepping and overtouching outside of Christ (cf. [link]2 Cor. 10:13[/link]). A broken foot or hand signifies some part of our being that is not complete in Christ (cf. [link]2 Tim. 3:16-17[/link]). Being a hunchback signifies having the sight that is able to see only the things on earth, not the things in heaven, because of the lack of the experience of the heavenly Christ (cf. [link]Col. 3:1-3[/link]). Being a dwarf signifies the lack of the stature of Christ in the growth in life (cf. [link]Eph. 4:13[/link]). A defect in the eye signifies the sight in spiritual things that is not perfect because of the lack of a full view of Christ (cf. [link]Acts 18:24-28[/link]). Eczema signifies some expression that is abnormal in life, making oneself feel uneasy and making others feel bad, because of the lack of the Spirit of Christ (cf. [link]Phil. 1:19-20[/link]). Scales signify something that causes oneself to be uncomfortable and in its appearance bothers others, because of a lack in living Christ (cf. [link]Phil. 1:21a[/link]). Crushed testicles signify that the spiritual reproductive function is damaged because of the serious lack of the experience of Christ as life (cf. [link]John 15:5[/link]).

chapter.verse: Or one who has a broken foot or a broken hand,
Or a hunchback or a dwarf, or one who has a defect in his eye or eczema or scale or crushed testicles.
No one of the seed of Aaron the priest who has a defect shall come near to present Jehovah's offerings by fire. He has a defect; he shall not come near to present the food of his God.

verse.text: He may [note]1[/note]eat the food of his God, both of the [xref]a[/xref]most holy and of the [xref]b[/xref]holy,
verse.note: The word in [link]vv. 22-23[/link] signifies that although the defective believers can enjoy Christ, the food of God, as their food, they are not qualified to serve God in the church, God's sanctuary, or around the cross of Christ, typified by the altar, lest they profane the holy things of God.

verse.text: But he shall not go in unto the [xref]a[/xref]veil or come near to the altar, because he has a defect, so that he does not profane My holy places; for I am Jehovah who sanctifies them.

chapter.verse: So Moses spoke to Aaron and to his sons and to all the children of Israel.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Tell Aaron and his sons to [note]1[/note]be careful with the [note]2[/note]holy things of the children of Israel, which they sanctify to Me, so that they do not profane My holy name; I am Jehovah.
verse.note: Lit., separate themselves from; Heb. [i]nazar,[/i] the root from which the word [i]Nazarite[/i] comes.
The holy things, the things offered to God by His people, signify Christ, whom God gives to His serving ones for their enjoyment.

verse.text: Say to them, If anyone among all your seed throughout your generations approaches the holy things, which the children of Israel sanctify to Jehovah, and his [note]1[/note]uncleanness is upon him, that person shall be cut off from before Me; I am Jehovah.
verse.note: The regulations in [link]vv. 3-9[/link] concerning the priests' not eating the holy things in their uncleanness, unless they bathe their flesh in water, that they might not sin and die, signify that we should not enjoy Christ while we are defiled with unclean things until we deal thoroughly with the defilement, mainly by washing ourselves in the Holy Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 6:11[/link]), that we may not be condemned and suffer spiritual death.

verse.text: No one of the seed of Aaron who is a [xref]a[/xref]leper or who has a [xref]b[/xref]discharge may eat of the holy things until he is clean. And whoever touches anything that is unclean because of [i]contact[/i] with a [xref]c[/xref]dead person, or a man whose seed of copulation has gone from him,
Or whoever touches any [xref]a[/xref]creeping thing by which he may be made unclean, or a man by whom he may be made unclean, whatever his uncleanness,
The person who touches any such thing shall be unclean until the evening and shall not eat of the holy things unless he has [xref]a[/xref]bathed his [note]1[/note]body in water.
verse.note: Lit., flesh.

verse.text: And when the sun sets, he shall be clean; and afterward he may eat of the holy things, because it is his [xref]a[/xref]food.

chapter.verse: He shall not eat [i]an animal[/i] which has died or is torn [i]by beasts[/i] to become unclean by it; I am Jehovah.
They shall therefore keep My charge, so that they do not bring sin [i]upon themselves[/i] because of it and die by it because they profane it; I am Jehovah who sanctifies them.

verse.text: No [note]1[/note]stranger may [xref]a[/xref]eat any holy thing; a sojourner with a priest or a hired servant shall not eat any holy thing.
verse.note: A stranger, a sojourner, or a hired servant being forbidden to eat any holy thing signifies that an unsaved person or one who has no share in God's service may not enjoy Christ. A purchased slave or one born in a priest's house being permitted to eat ([link]v. 11[/link]) signifies that the ones purchased by Christ with His precious blood and born of God in His house may enjoy Christ.
verse.xref: cf. Lev. 24:9; 1 Sam. 21:6; Matt. 12:4; Mark 2:26; Luke 6:4

verse.text: But if a priest acquires anyone [i]through[/i] a purchase with his money, that one may eat of it; and those who are born in his house may [xref]a[/xref]eat of his food.
And if a priest's [note]1[/note]daughter is [i]married[/i] to a stranger, she shall not eat of the heave offering of the holy things.
verse.note: The word in [link]vv. 12-13[/link] signifies that a believer (a priest's daughter) who is attracted away by an outsider may not enjoy the ascended Christ (the heave offering). But if he cuts off his relationship with the outsider without leaving any connection and returns to the church, he may recover his enjoyment of Christ.

verse.text: But if a priest's daughter becomes a widow or divorced and has no child, and she returns to her [xref]a[/xref]father's house as in her youth, she may eat of her father's food; but no stranger may eat of it.
And if a man eats the holy thing in ignorance, then he shall add [xref]a[/xref]one-fifth of its [i]value[/i] to it and shall give the holy thing to the priest.

chapter.verse: And they shall not profane the holy things of the children of Israel that they offer to Jehovah,
And [i]so[/i] cause them to bear the iniquity that brings guilt when they eat their holy things; for I am Jehovah who sanctifies them.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Speak to Aaron and to his sons and to all the children of Israel, and say to them, When anyone of the house of Israel or of the sojourners in Israel presents his [xref]a[/xref]offering, whether it is any of their [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]vows or any of their [note]1[/note]freewill offerings which they present to Jehovah for a burnt offering;
verse.note: A vow is an oath made with God that cannot be retracted, whereas a freewill offering is a consecration that is not stable or sure. Hence, the offerings for a vow are stronger than those for a freewill offering (cf. [link]v. 23[/link]).

verse.text: [i]It shall be[/i] a male without [xref]a[/xref]blemish from the cattle, from the sheep, or from the goats, for you to be accepted.

chapter.verse: But whatever has a blemish, you shall not present, for it will not be acceptable for you.

verse.text: And whoever presents a sacrifice of peace offerings to Jehovah to [note]1[/note]make a special [xref]a[/xref]vow or for a freewill offering, from the herd or from the flock, it shall be perfect to be accepted; there shall be no blemish in it.
verse.note: Lit., be wonderful [i]to make[/i] a vow. So also in [link]27:2[/link].

chapter.verse: You shall not present these to Jehovah: [i]anything[/i] blind or injured or maimed or having a suppuration or eczema or scale; nor shall you make an offering by fire from them on the altar to Jehovah.

verse.text: An ox or a lamb that has anything [note]1[/note]superfluous or lacking in its parts, that you may offer for a freewill offering; but it shall not be accepted for a vow.
verse.note: [i]Superfluous[/i] means exceeding the limit, and [i]lacking[/i] means being under the proper measure. The word in this verse signifies that we may, in a general way (as a freewill offering), offer to God as food the Christ whom we experience too much or too little, but if we offer in a stronger way (as a vow), our offering will not be accepted.

chapter.verse: And anything [i]with its testicles[/i] bruised or crushed or broken or cut, you shall not present to Jehovah; you shall not do this in your land.

verse.text: And from the hand of a [note]1[/note]foreigner you shall not present the food of your God from any of these, because their corruption is in them. There is a blemish in them; they shall not be accepted for you.
verse.note: The offering from the hand of a foreigner not being accepted by God signifies that the offering of Christ to God in a way that is according to the unbelievers will be rejected by God.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: When an ox or a sheep or a goat is born, it shall remain seven days with its mother; and from the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]eighth day and onward it shall be accepted for the offering of an offering by fire to Jehovah.
verse.note: This signifies that our experience of Christ must grow to the level of resurrection (the eighth day, the beginning of a new week — [link]John 20:1[/link]) before it will be accepted as an offering to God for His food. This requires us to learn how to reject our natural life and live by the divine life in resurrection ([link]Gal. 2:20[/link]).

chapter.verse: But whether cow or sheep, you shall not slaughter both it and its young on one day.
And when you sacrifice a sacrifice of thanksgiving to Jehovah, you shall sacrifice [i]it[/i] so that you may be accepted.

verse.text: On the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]same day it shall be eaten; you shall leave none of it until the [xref]b[/xref]morning; I am Jehovah.
verse.note: Eating the sacrifice of thanksgiving ([link]v. 29[/link]) on the same day and leaving none of it until the morning signify that our offering of Christ as a thanksgiving to God must be fresh and new, with nothing left to become stale ([link]Heb. 13:15[/link]).

chapter.verse: Therefore you shall keep My commandments and do them; I am Jehovah.
And you shall not profane My holy name, but I will be sanctified among the children of Israel; I am Jehovah who sanctifies you,

verse.text: Who brought you out of the land of Egypt to be your [xref]a[/xref]God; I am Jehovah.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Speak to the children of Israel, and say to them, [i]As to[/i] the appointed [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]feasts of Jehovah, which you shall proclaim as holy [note]2[/note]convocations, these are My appointed feasts.
verse.note: The feasts are for rest and enjoyment, both of which are types of Christ as our rest and enjoyment. The mentioning of the feasts in this book, a book of God's priesthood for God's service in the fellowship of God, indicates that our priestly service to God issues in Christ as the rest and enjoyment that we have with God and with one another. God ordained the feasts that His people might rest with Him and be joyful with Him, that they might enjoy with Him and with one another all that He has provided for His redeemed people. The rest and enjoyment were not individual but corporate.

The feasts appointed by Jehovah were holy convocations, special assemblies of God's people called for a special and particular purpose. These signify the gathering of the believers as the church (see note [link]22[sup]4[/sup] in Eph. 1[/link]) to have a corporate rest and enjoyment of Christ before God, with God, and with one another.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Six days work shall be done, but on the seventh day there is a [note]1[/note]Sabbath of complete rest, a holy convocation. You shall do no work; it is a Sabbath to Jehovah in all your dwelling places.
verse.note: The weekly feast, the Sabbath, signifies the rest that God's redeemed people enjoy with God and with one another. This Sabbath, this rest, was "to Jehovah," signifying a rest for God's joy and enjoyment, participated in by His redeemed people. This is also the principal denotation of each of the seven annual feasts ([link]vv. 7-8[/link], [link]21[/link], [link]25[/link], [link]28[/link], [link]31-32[/link], [link]35-36[/link], [link]39[/link]).

verse.text: These are the appointed [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]feasts of Jehovah, even the holy convocations, which you shall proclaim at their appointed time:
verse.note: There were seven annual feasts. Seven is the number of fullness, signifying that the seven annual feasts were in the fullness of God's riches. Christ is the reality of the Sabbath ([link]v. 3[/link]) and of all the annual feasts ([link]Col. 2:16-17[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]In the first month, on the fourteenth [i]day[/i] of the month [note]1[/note]at twilight, is Jehovah's [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Passover,
verse.note: Lit., between the two evenings; referring to the time interval between sunset and darkness.
For the Feast of Passover ([link]v. 5[/link]) and the Feast of Unleavened Bread ([link]vv. 6-8[/link]), see notes in [link]Exo. 12[/link].

verse.text: And on the fifteenth day of this month is the [xref]a[/xref]Feast of Unleavened Bread to Jehovah; seven days you shall eat unleavened bread.
[xref]a[/xref]On the [note]1[/note]first day you shall have a holy convocation; you shall do no work of labor.
verse.note: Having a holy convocation on the first day and on the last day ([link]v. 8[/link]) of the Feast of Unleavened Bread, with no work of labor, signifies that we enjoy Christ corporately, without our human labor, from the first day until the last day of the course of our Christian life.

verse.text: But you shall present an offering by fire to Jehovah [note]1[/note]seven days. On the seventh day there shall be a holy convocation; you shall do no work of labor.
verse.note: The presenting of an offering by fire to Jehovah for seven days (a full course of time) signifies that we offer Christ as food to God continually through the full course of our Christian life. At the Lord's table we make a display to the entire universe that each day of the week we take Christ as our unleavened food, as our life supply apart from sin ([link]1 Cor. 5:7-8[/link]), and that we come to the table with Him. Then we offer to God for His satisfaction the One whom we have been enjoying as our food.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Speak to the children of Israel, and say to them, When you come into the land which I am giving you, and reap its harvest, then you shall bring the [note]1[/note]sheaf of the [xref]a[/xref]firstfruits of your harvest to the priest;
verse.note: The third annual feast, the Feast of Firstfruits, signifies the resurrected Christ as the firstfruits ([link]1 Cor. 15:20[/link]) for our enjoyment as a feast in His resurrection (see notes [link]20[sup]2[/sup] in 1 Cor. 15[/link] and [link]53[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 27[/link]). Christ was crucified at the time of the Feast of the Passover ([link]Mark 14:12[/link] and note 2), and then on the third day ([link]1 Cor. 15:4[/link]), the day after the Sabbath ([link]v. 11[/link]; [link]John 20:1[/link]), He was resurrected. Christ's resurrection was the fulfillment of the Feast of Firstfruits and is the reality of that feast.

verse.text: And he shall [xref]a[/xref]wave the sheaf before Jehovah for your [note]1[/note]acceptance; on the [xref]b[/xref]day after the Sabbath the priest shall wave it.
verse.note: The waving of the sheaf of firstfruits before Jehovah for acceptance signifies that Christ was resurrected that we might be justified before God and accepted by God ([link]Rom. 4:25b[/link]).

verse.text: And on the day when you wave the sheaf, you shall offer a male lamb a year old without blemish as a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]burnt offering to Jehovah.
verse.note: The offering of a male lamb a year old without blemish as a burnt offering on the day of the wave offering signifies that the resurrected Christ, being fresh, tender, meek, strong, and without blemish, is offered to God as a burnt offering that is absolutely for God. This offering implies not only Christ Himself but also all His believers, who were resurrected in Him and with Him ([link]Eph. 2:6[/link]). Having been offered to God as a burnt offering in Christ and with Christ, the believers may live a life that is absolutely for God.

verse.text: And its [note]1[/note]meal offering shall be two-tenths [i]of an ephah[/i] of fine flour mingled with oil, an offering by fire to Jehovah for a satisfying fragrance. And its [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]drink offering shall be of wine, a fourth of a hin.
verse.note: The meal offering here signifies the resurrected Christ as our meal offering mingled with the anointing Spirit, offered to God as food in Christ's resurrection as a fragrance for God's satisfaction.

The five basic offerings in [link]1:1-6:7[/link] are types of various aspects of what Christ is to God on our behalf. The drink offering was in addition to the basic offerings and was poured out on one of the basic offerings ([link]Num. 15:1-10[/link]; [link]28:7-10[/link]). The drink offering offered with the burnt offering ([link]v. 12[/link]) and the meal offering at the Feast of Firstfruits signifies the resurrected Christ in His human life (in His living absolutely for God and His being poured out on the cross — [link]Isa. 53:12b[/link]; [link]Phil. 2:5-8[/link]), offered to God in His resurrection for God's enjoyment. Cf. [link]Phil. 2:17[/link] and note 1; [link]2 Tim. 4:6[/link] and note 1.

verse.text: And you shall eat [note]1[/note]no bread or parched grain or fresh ears until that same day, until you have brought the offering of your God. It shall be a perpetual statute throughout your generations in all your dwelling places.
verse.note: This signifies that the resurrected Christ ascended to the heavens and was offered to God with all the fruit in His resurrection as God's food for God's satisfaction first ([link]John 20:17[/link] and note 1); then, He became man's supply for man's satisfaction.

verse.text: And you shall count for yourselves from the day after the Sabbath; from the day that you brought the [xref]a[/xref]sheaf of the wave offering there shall be [xref]b[/xref]seven complete [note]1[/note]Sabbaths.
verse.note: Or, weeks. The Feast of Firstfruits was followed by the Feast of Pentecost, also called the Feast of Weeks ([link]Deut. 16:10[/link]) and the Feast of Harvest ([link]Exo. 23:16[/link]).

verse.text: You shall count [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fifty days until the day after the seventh Sabbath; then you shall present a [xref]b[/xref]new meal offering to Jehovah.
verse.note: See [link]Acts 2:1[/link] and note. The Feast of Pentecost was the feast of the fiftieth day, counting from the day after the Sabbath, the day on which the sheaf of the wave offering was brought to God ([link]v. 11[/link]), to the day after the seventh Sabbath ([link]v. 15[/link]). This signifies the resurrection of Christ in its sevenfold fullness reaching the realm of the complete fullness, bearing the full responsibility, signified by the number fifty (composed of ten times five, ten signifying fullness and five, responsibility), for the testimony of resurrection.[br][br]On the day of Pentecost in the New Testament, the consummation of the Triune God — the all-inclusive, life-giving, compound Spirit of the processed Triune God, who is the totality of the Triune God — was poured out upon the one hundred twenty disciples as representatives of the Body of Christ. As a result of such an outpouring of the economical Spirit of God, the Body of Christ came into existence as the increase, the enlargement, of the unlimited, individual Christ, making Him the universal, corporate Christ ([link]1 Cor. 12:12-13[/link]), the mingling of the processed and consummated Triune God with His chosen and redeemed people, which will ultimately consummate in the New Jerusalem.

verse.text: You shall bring out of your dwelling places [note]1[/note]two loaves as a wave offering; they shall be of two tenths [i]of an ephah[/i] of fine flour, baked with [xref]a[/xref]leaven, as firstfruits to Jehovah.
verse.note: The offering of a new meal offering to Jehovah ([link]v. 16[/link]) of two loaves of bread baked with leaven as firstfruits to Jehovah signifies that Christ at the stage of the firstfruits (the unleavened fine flour) has become the church as the Body of Christ in two sections at the stage of Pentecost (the two loaves — [link]1 Cor. 10:17[/link]), offered to God as the new meal offering for God's satisfaction. One of the sections is composed of the Jewish believers ([link]Acts 2:1-4[/link]) and the other, of the Gentile believers ([link]Acts 10:34-48[/link]). Both sections had sins (signified by the leaven) within them (cf. [link]Acts 5:1-11[/link]; [link]6:1[/link]).[br][br]That the two loaves also were firstfruits to Jehovah indicates that not only Christ but also the church are the firstfruits. Christ the firstfruits, as the fine flour, was the firstfruits on the day of resurrection ([link]1 Cor. 15:20[/link]; [link]John 20:17[/link]). Eventually, this fine flour became the two loaves on the day of Pentecost. In type, this indicates that Christ has become the church, that the church is the enlargement of Christ ([link]John 3:29-30[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 12:12[/link]; [link]Col. 3:10-11[/link]).

verse.text: And you shall present with the bread seven lambs, a year old without blemish, and one bull of the herd and two rams; they shall be a [note]1[/note]burnt offering to Jehovah with their [note]1[/note]meal offering and their [note]1[/note]drink offerings, an offering by fire for a satisfying fragrance to Jehovah.
verse.note: The presenting of the burnt offering, the meal offering, and the drink offering with the bread signifies that the church on the day of Pentecost was a corporate man offered to God as a burnt offering to live absolutely for God, with a living as a meal offering mixed with leaven — sins — and as a drink offering (pouring out its life for God by being martyred — [link]Phil. 2:17[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:6[/link]) to be an offering by fire accepted by God by being consumed for the satisfaction of both God and man.

verse.text: And you shall offer one male goat for a [note]1[/note]sin offering and two male lambs, a year old, for a sacrifice of [note]1[/note]peace offerings.
verse.note: The offering of the sin offering and the peace offering as a wave offering ([link]v. 20[/link]) with the bread signifies that because of its sins (cf. [link]Acts 5:1-11[/link]), the church on the day of Pentecost needed Christ as its sin offering, and for the sake of the fellowship of man with God and man with man, it needed Christ as its peace offering. At the same time, it enjoyed Christ as its wave offering, as the One resurrected (waved) to God for the church's enjoyment.

chapter.verse: And the priest shall wave them with the bread of the firstfruits as a wave offering before Jehovah with the two lambs; they shall be holy to Jehovah for the priest.

verse.text: And you shall make a proclamation on that same day; you shall have a holy convocation; you shall do [note]1[/note]no work of labor. It shall be a perpetual statute in all your dwelling places throughout your generations.
verse.note: This signifies God's redeemed people as the church enjoying Christ with God without any need of human labor to add anything.

verse.text: And when you reap the harvest of your land, you shall not completely reap the corners of your field, nor shall you [xref]a[/xref]gather the gleaning of your harvest; you shall leave them for the [note]1[/note]poor and for the [note]1[/note]sojourner; I am Jehovah your God.
verse.note: The harvest remaining at the corners of the fields and the gleanings being left for the poor and the sojourners signify that the grace of Christ in His resurrection at the Feast of Pentecost has a remainder in which the Gentiles may participate. See [link]Ruth 2:2-3[/link] and notes; cf. [link]Matt. 15:21-28[/link] and notes.

chapter.verse: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Speak to the children of Israel, saying, [xref]a[/xref]In the seventh month, on the first day of the month, you shall have a complete rest, a memorial [i]commemorated by[/i] the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]blowing [i]of trumpets,[/i] a holy convocation.
verse.note: The Feast of the Blowing of Trumpets signifies God's calling together of His scattered people (the dispersed Israelites) and His reminding them that He will issue such a call to them ([link]Matt. 24:31[/link]; cf. [link]Isa. 27:13[/link]; [link]Psa. 81:3[/link]). This feast was on the first day of the seventh month, the beginning of the second half of the year, signifying the second half of God's redemption, which is to be accomplished on Israel, the first half having been accomplished on the church. The interval between the Feast of Pentecost and the Feast of the Blowing of Trumpets signifies the church age, the age of mystery, which lasts from the day of Pentecost, when the church came into being, until the Lord's coming back, when God will call the scattered Jews to come back to the land of their fathers. God's calling His people back together from their dispersion will cause them to have a holy convocation, signifying their returning to God (repentance) and becoming a corporate people. This will be a memorial and a rest to God's gathered people, in which they will be able to offer Christ to God as food for the satisfaction of both God and man ([link]v. 25[/link]).

chapter.verse: You shall do no work of labor, but you shall present an offering by fire to Jehovah.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And on the tenth day of this seventh month is the Day of [note]1[/note]Expiation; you shall have a holy convocation, and you shall [note]2[/note]afflict your souls and present an offering by fire to Jehovah.
verse.note: Spiritually, the blowing of the trumpets signifies the proclaiming of the gospel to call sinners to repentance and salvation (cf. note [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 25[/link]), and the expiation signifies Christ's redemption (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 16[/link]). The Feast of Expiation closely followed the Feast of the Blowing of Trumpets, which involves Israel's repentance and return to God. This signifies that the day of man's redemption follows the trumpeting of the gospel and man's repentance as a reaction to it. The Feast of Expiation has a double application. Spiritually, this feast has been applied to the New Testament believers, and literally it will be applied in the future to the Jews.

The people's afflicting their souls and bringing an offering by fire to Jehovah ([link]vv. 27c[/link], [link]29[/link]) signify their mourning, repenting, and feeling sorrowful for sin, and offering Christ as food to God for the satisfaction of both God and man. This is what the Jews will do when the Lord Jesus comes back ([link]Zech. 12:10-14[/link]; [link]Matt. 24:30[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:7[/link]).

verse.text: And you shall do [note]1[/note]no work on that same day, because it is a Day of Expiation, to make expiation on your behalf before Jehovah your God.
verse.note: That the people were not to do any work but were to have a Sabbath of complete rest ([link]vv. 28[/link], [link]30-32a[/link]) signifies that God's redeemed people do not need to do any work for their redemption but should rest in the redemption God has accomplished for them, that God too may rest in His redeemed.

chapter.verse: If there is any person who does not afflict himself on that same day, he shall be cut off from his people.
And if any person does any work on that same day, I will destroy that person from among his people.
You shall do no work; it shall be a perpetual statute throughout your generations in all your dwelling places.
It shall be to you a Sabbath of complete rest, and you shall afflict your souls; on the ninth day of the month in the evening, from evening to evening, you shall keep your Sabbath.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Speak to the children of Israel, saying, [xref]a[/xref]On the fifteenth day of this seventh month is the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Feast of [note]2[/note]Tabernacles for [note]3[/note]seven days to Jehovah.
verse.note: The Feast of Ingathering ([link]Exo. 23:16b[/link]). See note [link]16[sup]2[/sup] in Exo. 23[/link].
Lit., Booths.
The seven days here signify a complete course of days, the one thousand years of the millennium.

chapter.verse: On the first day shall be a holy convocation; you shall do no work of labor.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Seven days you shall present an offering by fire to Jehovah. On the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]eighth day you shall have a holy convocation, and you shall present an offering by fire to Jehovah. It is a solemn assembly; you shall do no work of labor.
verse.note: The presenting of an offering by fire to Jehovah for seven days signifies the offering of Christ day after day as food to God for the satisfaction of both God and man. According to this type, in the millennium every day an offering will be presented to God to signify that Christ is God's food in our experiences, which is offered to God for His satisfaction so that we and God may enjoy mutual rest.

This signifies that God's people as a sacred congregation offer Christ in resurrection (signified by the eighth day — [link]John 20:1[/link]) as food to God for the satisfaction of both God and man, not needing to do any work but resting. This indicates that the entire one thousand years of the millennium will be a rest for God and for God's redeemed people. See note [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 4[/link].

chapter.verse: These are the appointed feasts of Jehovah, which you shall proclaim as holy convocations, to present an offering by fire to Jehovah, burnt offerings and meal offerings, sacrifices and drink offerings, each on its own day,
Besides the Sabbaths of Jehovah and besides your gifts and besides all your vows and besides all your freewill offerings which you give to Jehovah.

verse.text: Then on the fifteenth day of the seventh month, when you have [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]gathered in the produce of the land, you shall keep the feast of Jehovah seven days; on the first day shall be a complete rest, and on the eighth day shall be a complete rest.
verse.note: This signifies that the millennium will come after the harvest of what God desires to obtain on earth through the three dispensations before the millennium — the dispensation before the law (from Adam to Moses — [link]Rom. 5:14[/link]), the dispensation of the law (from Moses to Christ's first coming — [link]John 1:17[/link]), and the dispensation of the church (from Pentecost to Christ's second coming — [link]Acts 1:11[/link]). The millennium, the age of the kingdom ([link]Rev. 20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]), will be the fourth and final dispensation of the old heaven and the old earth. It will usher in the new heaven and new earth with the New Jerusalem for eternity ([link]Rev. 21:1-3[/link]).

verse.text: And on the first day you shall take for yourselves the [note]1[/note]product of stately trees, branches of [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]palm trees and boughs of leafy trees and willows of the brook; and you shall rejoice before Jehovah your God for seven days.
verse.note: Or, fruit. Trees signify Christ's humanity (see note [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Kings 6[/link]). The trees in this verse portray the evergreen, nourishing, beautiful, and rich scenery of the different aspects of Christ's humanity being lived out from the overcomers among God's redeemed people in the millennium.
See note [link]9[sup]4[/sup] in Rev. 7[/link].

chapter.verse: And you shall keep it as a feast to Jehovah seven days in the year. It shall be a perpetual statute throughout your generations; you shall keep it in the seventh month.

verse.text: You shall dwell in [note]1[/note]booths seven days — all who are native in Israel shall dwell in [xref]a[/xref]booths —
verse.note: The coming millennium will be a conclusion of all that God has done with His redeemed people in the full course of the ages, the dispensations, in His old creation. The people dwelling in booths indicates that in the four dispensations of the old creation man cannot have a solid dwelling place. Eventually, for God's redeemed people the present, portable tabernacles will become a solid one — the New Jerusalem with twelve foundations ([link]Heb. 11:8-10[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:2-3[/link], [link]14[/link]). See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup], par. 3, in John 7[/link].

verse.text: So that your [note]1[/note]descendants may know that I made the children of Israel to dwell in booths when I brought them out of the land of Egypt; I am Jehovah your God.
verse.note: Lit., generations.

verse.text: And Moses declared to the children of Israel the appointed [note]1[/note]feasts of Jehovah.
verse.note: The seven feasts in this chapter are in two groups, with four in the first group and three in the second. The four feasts in the first group all took place in the first half of the year, signifying the time when Christ died, resurrected, and ascended to pour out the Holy Spirit. The three feasts in the second group took place in the seventh month of the year, signifying the time of Christ's second coming. According to their dispensational fulfillment, the first four have taken place already, and the last three will take place in the future. The Feast of the Passover was fulfilled on the day of Christ's death ([link]Matt. 26:2[/link], [link]17-19[/link], [link]26-28[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 5:7[/link]). The Feast of Unleavened Bread is being fulfilled in the church age ([link]1 Cor. 5:7-8[/link]). The Feast of Firstfruits was fulfilled on the day of Christ's resurrection ([link]1 Cor. 15:20[/link]), when the members of Christ were produced for the formation of the church ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:6[/link]). The Feast of Pentecost was fulfilled fifty days after Christ's resurrection, on the day of the pouring out of the Holy Spirit ([link]Acts 2:1-4[/link]; cf. [link]Acts 1:3[/link]), when the resurrected and ascended Christ as the consummated, all-inclusive, life-giving Spirit poured Himself out on His members to form the church. The Feast of the Blowing of Trumpets will be fulfilled at Christ's second coming ([link]Matt. 24:31[/link]). The Feast of Expiation will be fulfilled on the day of Israel's return to God, after they have been gathered back to their fathers' land ([link]Rom. 11:26-27[/link]; [link]Zech. 12:10-14[/link]). The Feast of Tabernacles will be fulfilled in the coming millennium for a thousand years ([link]Rev. 20:4-6[/link]) as a conclusion of all the ages of God's old creation, for the coming of the new heaven and the new earth with the New Jerusalem as their center ([link]Rev. 21:1-2[/link]).

verse.text: Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, [note]1[/note]saying,
verse.note: [link]Verses 1-9[/link] unveil that for us, the holy people of God, to live a holy life, we need the arranging afresh of Christ as the divine light to shine over us and as the divine food to nourish us.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Command the children of Israel to bring to you [note]1[/note]pure oil of beaten olives for the light, to [note]2[/note]make the lamps burn continually.
verse.note: The pure oil of beaten olives for the light signifies the pure Holy Spirit coming out of the crucified Christ (cf. [link]John 19:34[/link]), typified by the beaten olives, for the shining of Christ as the lampstand in God's dwelling place. See note [link]36[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 26[/link] and note [link]31[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in Exo. 25[/link].
Lit., cause [i]the light[/i] of a lamp to ascend.

verse.text: Outside the veil of the Testimony in the Tent of Meeting Aaron shall [note]1[/note]set it in order from evening to morning before Jehovah continually. It shall be a perpetual statute throughout your generations.
verse.note: Or, tend it. So also in [link]v. 4[/link]. The burning of the lamps continually ([link]v. 2[/link]) signifies that Christ as the divine light ([link]John 1:4[/link]; [link]8:12[/link]) shines continually in the house of God. The tending of the lamps continually ([link]vv. 3-4[/link]) by Aaron, the high priest, signifies that Christ as our High Priest continually takes care of His divine light, causing it to shine for God continually.

verse.text: He shall keep the lamps in order on the pure [xref]a[/xref]lampstand before Jehovah continually.
And you shall take fine flour and bake twelve [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]cakes with it; two-tenths [i]of an ephah[/i] shall be [i]in[/i] each cake.
verse.note: This signifies that the resurrected Christ, the Christ who produced the church (typified by the two-tenths of an ephah of fine flour — [link]23:13[/link], [link]17[/link]), is the element that constitutes the food in full (the number twelve signifies fullness — [link]Matt. 14:20[/link] and note) for all God's people (represented by the twelve tribes, who are referred to in the twelve cakes) and for God to enjoy.

verse.text: And you shall set them in two rows, six in a row, on the [xref]a[/xref]table of pure [i]gold[/i] before Jehovah.
And you shall put pure [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]frankincense on each row, so that it may be a memorial for the bread, an [note]2[/note]offering by fire to Jehovah.
verse.note: It is with the fragrance of His resurrection (frankincense) as a memorial portion that Christ becomes food to both God and us.

That the bread of the Presence was food for both God and the priests ([link]v. 9[/link]) indicates that God's priests are one with Him in His service; what they eat is what God eats, and what they enjoy is what God enjoys.

verse.text: Every [note]1[/note]Sabbath day continually he shall set it in order before Jehovah; it is an everlasting covenant for the children of Israel.
verse.note: The word [i]Sabbath[/i] brings in the thought of rest. This signifies that our enjoyment of Christ as our food should be set in order afresh that we may have rest with God continually.

verse.text: And it shall be for Aaron and his sons, and they shall [xref]a[/xref]eat it in a [note]1[/note]holy place, for it is most holy to him of Jehovah's offerings by fire, a perpetual statute.
verse.note: This signifies that we, God's serving ones, should enjoy Christ as a most holy portion of the food offered to God, in the church as the holy place.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Now the son of an Israelite woman, who was also the son of an Egyptian man, went out among the children of Israel; and the son of the Israelite woman and a certain Israelite struggled together in the camp.
verse.note: This story signifies that the joining of a man of God with a man of the world brings forth a result that will profane God, causing the profaning one to be cut off ([link]v. 16[/link]) from the enjoyment of Christ in His fullness as the shining light and nourishing food.

verse.text: And the son of the Israelite woman [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]blasphemed the Name and cursed, and they brought him to Moses. (Now his mother's name was Shelomith, the daughter of Dibri, of the tribe of Dan.)
verse.note: That the story of the blaspheming of the holy Name is recorded after the record concerning the arranging of the bread of the Presence signifies that in order to enjoy Christ in His fullness as our light and as our food ([link]vv. 1-9[/link]), we need to sanctify the holy Name and not profane it (cf. [link]Matt. 6:9[/link]). To sanctify the Lord's name is to honor and respect the holy Name by separating it as something unique, not putting it with other, common names.

chapter.verse: And they put him in custody so that it might be declared to them by the mouth of Jehovah.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,
Bring forth the one who has cursed outside the camp; and let all who heard [i]him[/i] lay their hands on his head, and let all the assembly stone him.
And you shall speak to the children of Israel, saying, Anyone who curses his God shall bear his sin.

verse.text: And the one who blasphemes the name of Jehovah shall surely be put to [xref]a[/xref]death; all the assembly shall surely stone him. The sojourner as well as the native, when he blasphemes the Name, shall be put to death.
And anyone who [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]takes the life of any human being shall surely be put to death.
verse.note: This chapter also reveals that we need to care for both the human life and the animal life ([link]vv. 17-22[/link]). The human life is for the expression of God ([link]Gen. 1:26[/link]), and the animal life is mainly for offering to God in the worship of God.

verse.text: And the one who [note]1[/note]takes the life of a beast shall make restitution for it, [note]2[/note]life for life.
verse.note: Lit., strikes the soul of a beast.
Lit., soul for soul.

chapter.verse: And anyone who causes an injury to his fellow countryman, as he has done, so shall it be done to him:

verse.text: A fracture for a fracture, an [xref]a[/xref]eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth; just as he has caused an injury to a man, so it will be inflicted on him.

chapter.verse: And one who kills a beast shall make restitution for it, but one who kills a human being shall be put to death.
You shall have one judgment for the sojourner as well as for the native, for I am Jehovah your God.

And Moses spoke to the children of Israel, and they brought forth the one who had cursed outside the camp and stoned him with stones. So the children of Israel did just as Jehovah had commanded Moses.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses on Mount Sinai, saying,

verse.text: Speak to the children of Israel, and say to them, When you come into the land which I am giving you, the land shall observe a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Sabbath to Jehovah.
verse.note: The Sabbath year was a rest for God, for man, and for the land. Both the Sabbath day and the Sabbath year refer to Christ. The Sabbath year denotes Christ in His fullness as our rest. The Sabbath day being for man, one day out of every week, and the Sabbath year being for the land, one whole year out of every seven years, signify that Christ is the realm of the full rest that we may enjoy Him as our rest to the fullest. See note [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 4[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Six years you shall sow your field, and six years you shall prune your vineyard and gather in its produce;
But in the seventh year the land shall have a Sabbath of complete rest, a Sabbath to Jehovah; you shall [note]1[/note]not sow your field nor prune your vineyard.
verse.note: Not sowing, pruning, reaping, or gathering ([link]vv. 4b-5[/link]) signifies that rest is purely and wholly of grace and that all human labor should cease absolutely ([link]Matt. 11:28-30[/link]).

chapter.verse: The aftergrowth of your harvest you shall not reap, and the grapes of your unpruned vine you shall not gather; the land shall have a year of complete rest.

verse.text: And the Sabbath [i]produce[/i] of the land shall be for [note]1[/note]food for you; for you and for your male slaves and for your female slaves, and for your hired servant and for your stranger, who sojourns with you,
verse.note: In the seventh year the produce of the land became common to all. The Sabbath produce of the land being food for every kind of person and even for the cattle and the animals ([link]vv. 6-7[/link]) signifies that it is all a matter of grace toward anyone, regardless of his status.

chapter.verse: And for your cattle and for the animals that are in your land, shall all its produce be for food.

verse.text: And you shall count off [note]1[/note]seven Sabbaths of years to yourself, seven times seven years, so that you have the time of seven Sabbaths of years, that is, forty-nine years.
verse.note: The fifty years that consummated in the jubilee comprised eight Sabbath years (the year of jubilee was also a Sabbath year — [link]vv. 11-12[/link]), being Sabbath upon Sabbath to be an eightfold Sabbath, signifying the superabundance of the fullness of God's rest with satisfaction to us. Moreover, the first and last years of this fifty-year period were eighth years, and in between there were six eighth years, making a total of eight eighth years. Since the number eight signifies resurrection ([link]John 20:1[/link]), this indicates that the jubilee is something that is altogether from resurrection, to resurrection, in resurrection, and with resurrection.

verse.text: Then you shall sound aloud the ram's horn in the seventh month on the tenth day of the month; on the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Day of Expiation you shall sound the [xref]b[/xref]trumpet throughout all your land.
verse.note: The sounding of the ram's horn in the forty-ninth year on the Day of Expiation signifies that the jubilee is based on the expiation for sin (see [link]ch. 16[/link]), that the full liberty might be proclaimed to all the people ([link]v. 10[/link]). This type was fulfilled by the full redemption of Christ as the basis for the proclamation of the full freedom to all the human race (cf. [link]Mark 16:15[/link]; [link]Luke 24:47[/link]).

verse.text: And you shall sanctify the [note]1[/note]fiftieth year, and proclaim [note]2[/note]liberty throughout the land to all its inhabitants. It shall be a [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]jubilee for you; and each of you shall return to his [note]2[/note]possession, and each of you shall return to his [note]2[/note]family.
verse.note: That the jubilee was in the fiftieth year ([link]vv. 10-11[/link]) signifies that the full responsibility (typified by the number fifty) to meet all the requirements of God has been fulfilled so that man does not need to bear any responsibility. Fifty years also signifies the entire course of fallen human life. Thus, the year of jubilee, the fiftieth year, signifies the conclusion of our fallen human life.[br][br]The year of jubilee is the acceptable year of the Lord prophesied in [link]Isa. 61:1-2[/link] and fulfilled by the Lord's coming in [link]Luke 4:16-22[/link]. In the Old Testament type the jubilee lasted for one year, but in the fulfillment it refers to the entire New Testament age, the age of grace, as the time when God accepts the returned captives of sin ([link]Isa. 49:8[/link]; [link]Luke 15:17-24[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 6:2[/link]) and when those oppressed under the bondage of sin enjoy the release of God's salvation ([link]Rom. 7:14-8:2[/link]). The believers' enjoyment of the jubilee in the age of grace, i.e., their enjoyment of Christ as God's grace to them, will issue in the full enjoyment of the jubilee in the millennium and in the fullest enjoyment in the New Jerusalem in the new heaven and new earth.

In the year of jubilee everyone who had sold his possession, his allotted portion of the good land, was returned to it without paying anything to redeem it ([link]vv. 10[/link], [link]13[/link], [link]28[/link]), and everyone who had sold himself into slavery regained his freedom and returned to his family ([link]vv. 39-41[/link]). Returning to one's possession and being freed and returning to one's family signify that in the New Testament jubilee the believers have returned to God as their lost divine possession, have been released from all bondage, and have returned to the church as their divine family.[br][br]Each family of the Israelites was allotted a portion of the good land. After the children of Israel received their portions of the land, some became poor and sold their allotment ([link]v. 25a[/link]), thus losing their possession, their inheritance. Others became so poor that they even sold themselves into slavery ([link]v. 39a[/link]), thus losing their freedom and becoming separated from their families. The good land of Canaan typifies the Triune God embodied in Christ ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]) and realized as the all-inclusive life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:17[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:14[/link]) as the allotted portion of the saints (see note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Deut. 8[/link]). When God created man, He intended to give Himself in Christ to man as man's possession, man's inheritance ([link]Gen. 2:9[/link]; [link]13:12-15[/link]; [link]Psa. 16:5[/link]; [link]90:1[/link]). However, man became fallen, and in the fall man lost God as his possession ([link]Gen. 3:24[/link]; [link]4:16[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:12[/link]) and sold himself into slavery under sin, Satan, and the world ([link]John 8:34[/link]; [link]Rom. 7:14b[/link]; [link]Gal. 4:8[/link]; [link]Titus 3:3[/link]; [link]1 John 5:19b[/link]). God's New Testament salvation, accomplished by God's grace based on His redemption in Christ ([link]Rom. 3:24[/link]; [link]5:1-2[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:8[/link]), brings fallen man back to God as His divine possession ([link]Acts 26:18[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:14[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:14[/link]; [link]Col. 1:12[/link]; [link]Luke 15:12-24[/link]), releases man from slavery under sin, Satan, and the world ([link]John 8:32[/link]; [link]Rom. 6:6[/link], [link]14[/link]; [link]8:2[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:14-15[/link]; [link]John 12:31[/link]), and restores man to his divine family, the household of God ([link]Gal. 6:10[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:19[/link]), that he may enjoy fellowship in God's grace ([link]2 Cor. 13:14[/link]).[br][br]In the present age the whole race of Israel has become poor and has lost the land of Canaan. At the Lord's second coming, the millennium will be a jubilee to them, in which they will regain ownership of their God-allotted portion ([link]Isa. 61:1-2[/link] and notes).

Perhaps related to the word [i]ram;[/i] meaning [i]a time of shouting,[/i] or [i]a time of the trumpeting of the ram's horn.[/i] The trumpeting of the ram's horn signifies the preaching of the gospel as the proclaiming of liberty in the New Testament jubilee to all the sinners sold under sin ([link]Luke 4:18-19[/link]; [link]Acts 26:17b-18[/link]) that they may return to God and God's family and may rejoice with shouting in the enjoyment of God's salvation.

verse.text: The fiftieth year shall be a jubilee for you; you shall [note]1[/note]not sow nor reap its aftergrowth nor gather from its unpruned vines.
verse.note: Not sowing, reaping, or gathering in the year of jubilee ([link]vv. 11-12[/link]) signifies that in God's jubilee no human work is needed. It is altogether a rest to man, and God bears all the responsibility.

chapter.verse: For it is a jubilee; it shall be holy to you. You shall eat its produce out of the field.
In this year of jubilee each one of you shall return to his possession.
And if you sell anything to your fellow countryman or buy from the hand of your fellow countryman, you shall not wrong one another.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]According to the number of years after the jubilee you shall buy from your fellow countryman; according to the number of crop years [i]remaining[/i] he shall sell to you.

chapter.verse: According to the extent of the years you shall increase its price, and according to the fewness of the years you shall diminish its price; for it is the number of crop [i]years[/i] that he sells to you.
And you shall not wrong one another, but you shall fear your God; for I am Jehovah your God.
Thus you shall observe My statutes, and you shall keep My ordinances and observe them, so that you dwell securely in the land.
Then the land will yield its fruit, and you will eat to be satisfied and dwell securely in it.
And if you should say, What shall we eat the seventh year if we do not sow or gather in our produce?

verse.text: Then I will command My blessing for you in the sixth year, and it shall bring forth produce for [note]1[/note]three years.
verse.note: This signifies that the sufficient grace of God surpasses our need threefold. In the Sabbath year the produce of the land, but not the possession of the land, was common for the purpose of enjoyment ([link]vv. 6-7[/link]). For this purpose God blessed the land to produce food threefold. This practice of keeping the Sabbath year ushers God's people into the jubilee ([link]vv. 8-17[/link]).

chapter.verse: When you sow in the eighth year you will eat of the old produce until the ninth year; until its produce comes in, you shall eat the old [i]produce.[/i]

verse.text: And the land shall not be sold in perpetuity, because the [xref]a[/xref]land is [note]1[/note]Mine; for you are [xref]b[/xref]strangers and sojourners with Me.
verse.note: If we become weak or backslidden after we are saved, we will temporarily lose the enjoyment of Christ as our divine possession and may again become enslaved to sin, Satan, and the world. That the land belonged to God and could not be sold in perpetuity signifies that our divine possession belongs to God, and we cannot lose it forever. It is safeguarded by God's grace (cf. [link]Rom. 11[/link]). We may become defeated and may even be disciplined during the millennium, but our spiritual ownership of the divine possession cannot be lost permanently (cf. [link]1 Cor. 3:15[/link]). After the millennium, the disciplined believers will be restored to the ownership of their divine possession, especially in the new heaven and the new earth, to enjoy the blessing of the New Jerusalem. It is of the grace of God that we will be restored to our divine possession for eternity.

verse.text: And in all the land of your possession you shall provide for the [note]1[/note]redemption of the land.
verse.note: [link]Verses 24-28[/link] speak of the redemption of the land that has been sold. The redeeming of the land by the nearest relative ([link]v. 25[/link]) signifies that in Adam we became poor and sold our possession, and the Lord Jesus, our nearest relative, has come as our Redeemer to redeem for us what we sold (cf. [link]Ruth 3-4[/link]). The redeeming of the land by the person who sold it, he not having anyone to redeem it for him ([link]vv. 26-27[/link]), signifies that the children of Israel, not recognizing the Lord Jesus as their nearest relative ([link]John 1:11[/link]), have put themselves in the position of having to bear the responsibility for their redemption until they become able to redeem themselves. However, to this day they are still unable to do it, and actually they will never be able to do it. When the Lord Jesus comes back, they will recognize Him as their relative ([link]Zech. 12:10[/link]), and then they will be redeemed by Him. Not having sufficient means to redeem the possession and waiting for the year of jubilee, when the one who sold the land would return to his possession ([link]v. 28[/link]), signifies that we were unable to redeem what we had lost until the coming of the New Testament jubilee, in which all that we had lost is released to us to be our possession. See note [link]10[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: If your brother becomes poor and sells some of his possession, then his redeemer, the nearest [xref]a[/xref]relative, shall come and [xref]b[/xref]redeem what his brother has sold.

chapter.verse: But if a man does not have anyone to redeem [i]it,[/i] but he obtains the means and finds [i]it[/i] sufficient to redeem it,

verse.text: Then let him calculate the [xref]a[/xref]years since its sale and restore the excess to the man to whom he sold [i]it,[/i] and return to his possession.

But if he has not found sufficient means to restore [i]it[/i] for himself, then what he has sold shall remain in the hand of the one who has purchased it until the year of [xref]a[/xref]jubilee; and in the jubilee it shall go out, and he shall return to his possession.
And if anyone sells a dwelling [note]1[/note]house in a walled city, then he may redeem it until the end of a year from its sale; for a full year he shall have the right of redemption.
verse.note: The houses built on the land and within the walled cities typify the church built on Christ and expressed as local churches in many cities ([link]Matt. 16:18[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:11[/link]). The limiting of the time of the redemption of such houses to one year after the sale ([link]vv. 29-30[/link]) signifies that if a believer has lost the enjoyment of the church life, it can be restored only within a short limit of God's grace, as indicated by the one year. If the lost enjoyment of the church life is not restored in the church age, the age of grace, it will still be lost in the millennium, the age of the kingdom. This is according to the principle of taking away from him who has not ([link]Matt. 25:29[/link]). Ultimately, in the New Jerusalem the enjoyment of the Body life of Christ will be restored to the defeated believers after they have been disciplined during the millennium. See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup][/link].[br][br]Losing the enjoyment of the church life is more serious than losing the enjoyment of Christ. Because the Lord is gracious, it is easy for us to recover our enjoyment of Him. However, it is more difficult and requires a longer time to recover the lost church life. We should be warned by this not to "sell" the church life.

chapter.verse: But if it is not redeemed within the space of a full year, then the house that is in the walled city shall pass in perpetuity to the one who purchased it throughout his generations; it shall not go out in the jubilee.

verse.text: But the [note]1[/note]houses of the villages which have no wall all around them shall be reckoned with the fields of the country; they may be redeemed, and they shall go out in the jubilee.
verse.note: This signifies that in a place in which there are some believers who cannot be considered a church, the lost enjoyment of Christ can be restored.

verse.text: As for the [xref]a[/xref]cities of the Levites, [i]that is,[/i] the [note]1[/note]houses of the cities of their possession, the Levites shall have the permanent right of redemption.
verse.note: The Levites (serving ones) having the permanent right of redemption over their houses ([link]vv. 32-33[/link]) signifies that if any loss of the enjoyment of the church life occurs to the believers who are adequately engaged in the service of God in a church, it can be restored to them without any limitation of time.

chapter.verse: And what can be redeemed from the Levites, that is, a house that was sold [i]in[/i] a city of his possession, shall go out in the jubilee, for the houses of the cities of the Levites are their possession among the children of Israel.

verse.text: But the [note]1[/note]field of the suburbs of their cities may not be sold, for it is their perpetual possession.
verse.note: The fields of the suburbs of the Levites being their permanent possession and not being sold signifies that the believers who are adequately engaged in the service of God in a church will not lose the enjoyment of Christ permanently. Cf. note [link]23[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And if your [note]1[/note]brother becomes [xref]a[/xref]poor, and [note]2[/note]he is unable to support himself [i]as he lives[/i] beside you, then you shall support him, like a stranger and a sojourner, so that he may live beside you.
verse.note: The regulations related to the jubilee in [link]vv. 35-55[/link] can be applied to the relationships among the saints, the brothers, in the church life. To live together in the church life for the building up of the Body of Christ, we need to have the proper care for all the saints.

Lit., his hand fails. A brother of the Israelites becoming poor and unable to support himself signifies a believing brother becoming spiritually poor and unable to take care of himself. According to the type in [link]vv. 35-37[/link], we should help the brother who becomes weak in spirit, without taking any advantage of him. We should care for him in love so that he may live before the Lord as we do (cf. [link]Gal. 6:1[/link]; [link]James 5:19-20[/link]).

chapter.verse: Do not take any interest or gain from him, but fear your God, so that your brother may live beside you.
You shall not give him your money at interest nor give him your food for gain.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]I am Jehovah your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt to give you the land of Canaan, to be your God.
And if your brother beside you becomes poor, and he [note]1[/note]sells himself to you, you shall not make him serve as a slave.
verse.note: The regulation in [link]vv. 39-43[/link] signifies that if a brother becomes poor spiritually and is in debt to us, we should not treat him harshly and should consider him not as our slave but as our helper until he is revived by the grace of God (the jubilee comes), at which time he will be released from us. In rendering spiritual care to others, our motive, our spirit, and our attitude must be proper (cf. [link]Matt. 20:28[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 4:5[/link]; [link]Gal. 6:1[/link]).

chapter.verse: He shall be beside you as a hired servant, as a sojourner; he shall serve beside you until the year of jubilee.
Then he shall go out from you, he and his children with him, and return to his own family, and he shall return to the possession of his forefathers.

verse.text: For they are My [xref]a[/xref]servants, whom I brought out of the land of Egypt; they shall not be sold as slaves are sold.
You shall not rule over him with [xref]a[/xref]severity, but you shall fear your God.
And as for your male slaves and female slaves whom you may have, [i]they shall come[/i] from the [note]1[/note]nations that are around you; from them you may buy male slaves and female slaves.
verse.note: According to [link]vv. 44-46[/link], God's people could purchase male and female slaves from the nations and from the sojourners and consider them as their possessions, but they were not to take slaves from among the Israelites. This signifies that we should not treat the believers, who are our spiritual relatives, our brothers, like the outsiders.

chapter.verse: Moreover from the children of the strangers who sojourn among you, from them you may buy, and from their families who are with you, which they have begotten in your land; they also may be your possession.

And you shall make them an inheritance for your children after you, to receive as a possession; you may use them as permanent slaves. But you shall not rule over your brothers the children of Israel, one over another, with severity.

verse.text: And if a stranger or sojourner with you can afford [i]it,[/i] and your [note]1[/note]brother beside him becomes poor and sells himself to the stranger [i]or[/i] sojourner with you, or to the descendants of the stranger's family;
verse.note: In [link]vv. 47-49[/link], an Israelite brother who sold himself to a stranger or a sojourner being redeemed by his brother, by his uncle, or by any of his blood relatives, or by himself if he could afford it, signifies that we should help a brother who (through some offense) is spiritually in debt to outsiders so that he may be released from his indebtedness or so that he may become able to release himself by his own means. The selling price and the amount of the refund for redemption being calculated according to the number of years relative to the jubilee ([link]vv. 50-53[/link]) signifies that our release from slavery is related to and based on God's grace. The sold one who was not redeemed by these means being released in the year of jubilee ([link]v. 54[/link]) signifies that we can be released from our slavery wholly by the grace of God. We do not need any other means.

verse.text: After he has sold himself, he may be redeemed; one of his [xref]a[/xref]brothers may redeem him,

chapter.verse: Or his uncle or his uncle's son may redeem him, or any of his close relatives of his family may redeem him; or if he can afford [i]it,[/i] he may redeem himself.

And he shall reckon with the one who bought him from the year that he sold himself to him until the year of jubilee, and the price of his sale shall be according to the number of years. [i]The time[/i] he shall be with him shall be [i]calculated[/i] like the time of a hired servant.
If there are still many years, in proportion to them he shall give back [i]the amount for[/i] his redemption out of the money that he was bought for.
And if there are only a few years remaining until the year of jubilee, so he shall reckon with him. In proportion to his years he shall give back [i]the amount for[/i] his redemption.
Like a servant hired year by year he shall be with him; he shall not rule with severity over him in your sight.
And if he is not redeemed by these [i]means,[/i] then he shall go out in the year of jubilee, he and his children with him.

verse.text: For the children of Israel are My servants; they are My [xref]a[/xref]servants whom I brought out of the land of Egypt; I am Jehovah your God.

You shall not make for yourselves [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]idols, nor shall you raise up for yourselves a graven image or a pillar, nor shall you place a stone figure in your land to bow down to it; for I am Jehovah your God.
verse.note: Not making idols or bowing down to them signifies that besides the processed Triune God, we have no other goals that we are seeking after, that we may not lose the position to enjoy our divine possession. See note [link]21[sup]3[/sup], par. 1, in 1 John 5[/link].

verse.text: You shall keep My [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Sabbaths and reverence My [note]2[/note]sanctuary; I am Jehovah.
verse.note: Keeping God's Sabbath signifies that we know that the work of God was done entirely by Him that we might enjoy it and that there is no need for us to do any work (see note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 20[/link]).

Revering God's sanctuary signifies that we regard with reverence all that God is and has accomplished in Christ as His dwelling, embodiment, and expression ([link]John 1:14[/link]; [link]Col. 2:9[/link]) and in the church as the enlargement of Christ for God's dwelling and eternal manifestation ([link]1 Tim. 3:15-16[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:10[/link]).

verse.text: If you [note]1[/note]walk in My statutes and keep My commandments and do them,
verse.note: In [link]vv. 1-2[/link] the basis for our obedience to God is (1) the processed and consummated Triune God Himself as our unique goal (no idols), (2) God's work accomplished for our enjoyment and our rest (His Sabbaths), and (3) the issue of God's work — the church as the Body of Christ, the mingling of the processed Triune God and His chosen and redeemed people as one entity, to be the enlargement of the consummated Christ as God's dwelling, God's embodiment, God's expression, and God's eternal manifestation (His sanctuary). To obey God is to honor Him as the processed Triune God, to agree with all that He is and with all that He has accomplished. By obeying Him we receive His rich blessing ([link]vv. 4-13[/link]).

verse.text: Then I will give [i]you[/i] your [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]rains in their season, and the land will yield its produce, and the trees of the field will yield their fruit.
verse.note: That those who obeyed God's commandments would be blessed signifies that we, the New Testament believers, are blessed by walking according to the Spirit ([link]Rom. 8:4[/link]), with six issues: (1) Rains in their season ([link]v. 4a[/link]) signify that the Spirit, typified by rain ([link]Deut. 11:14[/link]; [link]Jer. 5:24[/link]; [link]Joel 2:23[/link]), is given to the church or to the individual believers in due time. (2) The land yielding its rich produce that the people may eat the new food always and dwell securely in the land ([link]vv. 4b-5[/link], [link]10[/link]) signifies that we dwell in Christ as our good land and enjoy the riches of Christ for our satisfaction and security ([link]Eph. 3:8[/link]; [link]Col. 1:12[/link]). (3) Peace being given in the land without threats, wild beasts, and the sword ([link]v. 6[/link]) signifies that the church is normally in a peaceful situation, having no "wild beasts" (cf. [link]Acts 20:29[/link]) or fightings among the saints ([link]James 4:1[/link]). (4) Chasing the enemies, five chasing a hundred and a hundred chasing ten thousand ([link]vv. 7-8[/link]), signifies that the church will chase the enemies ([link]Eph. 6:12[/link]) in the coordination of the Body. (5) Fruitfulness in multiplication ([link]v. 9[/link]) signifies that the church will be fruitful and multiply ([link]John 15:8[/link], [link]16[/link]). (6) God setting His tabernacle among the people ([link]v. 11[/link]) signifies that God's dwelling will be built up in the church for God's delight that He may dwell among His people (cf. [link]2 Cor. 6:16-18[/link]).

chapter.verse: Indeed your threshing will overtake the vintage, and the vintage will overtake the sowing time. Thus you will eat your bread unto satisfaction and dwell securely in your land.

And I will give [i]you[/i] peace in the land, so that you will lie down and no one will make you afraid; and I will cause wild beasts to cease out of the land, and no sword will pass through your land.
And you will chase your enemies, and they will fall by the sword before you.

verse.text: And five of you will chase a hundred, and a hundred of you will [xref]a[/xref]chase ten thousand; and your enemies will fall by the sword before you.
And I will turn My face toward you and make you fruitful and [xref]a[/xref]multiply you, and I will establish My [xref]b[/xref]covenant with you.

chapter.verse: And you will eat the old supply long stored and will have to clear out the old because of the new.

verse.text: And I will set My [xref]a[/xref]tabernacle among you; and My soul will not abhor you.
And I will walk [xref]a[/xref]among you and be your [xref]b[/xref]God, and you will be My people.
I am Jehovah your God, who brought you [xref]a[/xref]out of the land of Egypt so that [i]you[/i] should not be their slaves; and I have broken the bars of your yoke and made you walk upright.
[xref]a[/xref]But if you will not [note]1[/note]listen to Me and will not do all these commandments,
verse.note: Those who disobeyed God's commandments ([link]vv. 14-15[/link]) would be chastised, disciplined, on five levels that they might repent (see [link]vv. 16-39[/link] and notes). This signifies that the believers who do not walk according to the Spirit but according to the flesh (cf. [link]Rom. 8:7-8[/link]) will suffer chastisement, not just once but on many levels with a number of punishments, that they may be forced to repent.

verse.text: And if you reject My statutes, and if your soul abhors My ordinances so that you will not do all My commandments, so as to break My [xref]a[/xref]covenant;

I also will do this to you: I will appoint [note]1[/note]sudden terror over you, even consumption and fever, that will cause the eyes to fail and make the soul to pine away; and you will sow your seed in vain, for your enemies will eat it.
verse.note: The chastisement on the first level ([link]vv. 16-17[/link]) signifies that we will be sick in the spirit and even in the body (cf. [link]1 Cor. 11:29-32[/link]; [link]James 5:14-16[/link]; [link]1 John 5:16[/link]) so that we lose our eyesight and our life (cf. [link]Rev. 3:1[/link], [link]17[/link]), and the enemy will enjoy what we in vain have done. Furthermore, we will become so weak that we will not be able to stand before the enemies but will flee from them.

chapter.verse: And I will set My face against you, and you will be struck down before your enemies; and those who hate you will rule over you, and you will flee when no one pursues you.

verse.text: And if after these things you will not listen to Me, then I will [note]1[/note]chastise you [xref]a[/xref]seven times more for your sins.
verse.note: The chastisement on the second level is sevenfold, i.e., intensified. The sky being made like iron and the earth like bronze, yielding no produce ([link]vv. 19-20[/link]), signifies that the Spirit will not come to us from the heavens, and we will have no spiritual produce for our spiritual food.

chapter.verse: And I will break the pride of your power, and I will make your sky like iron and your land like bronze,

verse.text: And your strength will be spent in vain, for your land will [xref]a[/xref]not yield its produce, nor will the trees of the land yield their fruit.
And if you walk contrary to Me and will not listen to Me, I will bring [xref]a[/xref]seven times more [note]1[/note]plagues upon you according to your sins.
verse.note: The chastisement on the third level brings in plagues sevenfold ([link]vv. 21-22[/link]). These plagues signify troubles among the believers in the church ([link]1 Cor. 1:11[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 12:20[/link]).

verse.text: And I will send [note]1[/note]wild animals among you, which will bereave you of your children and destroy your cattle and make you few in number, so that your roads will be deserted.
verse.note: Wild animals bereaving people of their children and destroying their cattle, reducing their number and making their roads desolate, signifies that in the church fierce people ([link]Acts 20:29[/link]) will rise up to bereave the believers of their life produce, to destroy their spiritual possessions, to reduce their number, and to desolate their communications.

chapter.verse: And if by these things you will not be corrected by Me, but walk contrary to Me,

verse.text: Then I also will walk contrary to you; and I will [note]1[/note]strike you, I Myself, [xref]a[/xref]seven times for your sins.
verse.note: The chastisement on the fourth level is a matter of striking sevenfold ([link]vv. 24-26[/link]).

verse.text: And I will bring a [note]1[/note]sword upon you that will execute the vengeance of the covenant. And when you gather together within your cities, I will send [note]1[/note]pestilence among you, and you will be [note]1[/note]delivered into the hand of the enemy.
verse.note: Bringing a sword signifies that in the church there will be fightings among the brothers ([link]Gal. 5:15[/link]; [link]James 4:1[/link]). Sending pestilence signifies that in the church there will be some kind of contagious spiritual disease (cf. [link]1 Tim. 6:4[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 2:17[/link]). Delivering the people into the hand of the enemy signifies that the believers in the church will be taken over by the enemy (cf. [link]1 Pet. 5:8[/link]).

verse.text: When I [note]1[/note]cut off your supply of bread, ten women will bake your bread in one oven; and they will return your bread [note]2[/note]by [xref]a[/xref]weight, and you will eat and not be satisfied.
verse.note: Lit., break your staff. Cutting off the supply of bread so that it will be returned by weight and people will not be satisfied signifies that in the church the spiritual supply will be cut off to a greatly reduced amount, so that there will be no satisfaction for the believers.
I.e., in rationed amounts.

chapter.verse: And if in spite of this you will not listen to Me, but walk contrary to Me,

verse.text: Then I will walk contrary to you in wrath; and I will [note]1[/note]chastise you, I Myself, [xref]a[/xref]seven times for your sins.
verse.note: In the chastisement on the fifth level the people are disciplined sevenfold again ([link]vv. 27-39[/link]).

verse.text: And you will [note]1[/note]eat the flesh of your sons, and the flesh of your daughters you will eat.
