verse.note: The people eating the flesh of their children signifies that the church becomes so poor that it is unable to satisfy its members but bereaves them of their food supply, there being nothing to eat except the "children," i.e., what the church members produced in the past.

verse.text: And I will destroy your [xref]a[/xref]high places and cut down your altars to the sun and heap up your [note]1[/note]dead bodies upon the bodies of your idols, and My soul will abhor you.
verse.note: The heaping of the dead bodies upon the bodies of the destroyed idols signifies that the fleshly churches place themselves as carcasses upon goals that are other than God, which they sought as idols and which God destroyed.

verse.text: And I will make your [xref]a[/xref]cities a [note]1[/note]waste and will make your [xref]b[/xref]holy places desolate, and I will not smell the savor of your satisfying fragrances.
verse.note: The chastisement in this verse signifies that the churches are laid waste and their worship is desolated, and there is no satisfaction as a fragrance to God.

verse.text: And I will make the land [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]desolate, so that your enemies who dwell in it will be astonished at it.
verse.note: The land being made desolate and being inhabited by the enemies signifies that the church's enjoyment of Christ as the rich land is made desolate and is stolen by the enemies.

verse.text: You however I will [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]scatter among the nations, and I will unsheathe the sword after you; and your land will become a desolation, and your cities will become a waste.
verse.note: The people being scattered among the nations and chased by the unsheathed sword signifies that the church is scattered among the Gentiles and driven by the death judgment of God.

verse.text: Then the land will enjoy its [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Sabbaths during all the days of desolation while you are in your enemies' land; then the land will rest and enjoy its Sabbaths.
verse.note: The land enjoying its Sabbaths during the people's captivity ([link]vv. 34-35[/link]) signifies that the church's enjoyment of Christ as the rich land lies waste after the believers are scattered among the Gentiles.

chapter.verse: During all the days of desolation it will have the rest, which it did not have on your Sabbaths when you were dwelling upon it.

verse.text: And as for those who remain among you, I will send faintness into their heart in the lands of their enemies; and the sound of a driven leaf will [note]1[/note]put them to flight; and they will flee as one flees from the sword; and they will fall though [xref]a[/xref]no one pursues.
verse.note: The chastisements in [link]vv. 36-39[/link] signify that the church in its captivity is under suffering and is eventually consumed by the enemies.

chapter.verse: And they will stumble over one another, as if [i]fleeing[/i] before the sword, though no one pursues; and you will not be able to stand before your enemies.
And you will perish among the nations, and the land of your enemies will consume you.
And those who are remaining among you will rot away because of their iniquity in your enemies' lands; and also because of the iniquities of their fathers they will rot away with them.

verse.text: But if they [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]confess their iniquity and the iniquity of their fathers, in their unfaithfulness which they committed against Me, and also that they walked contrary to Me,
verse.note: God's people confessing their iniquity, humbling their uncircumcised heart, and accepting the punishment of their iniquity ([link]vv. 40-41[/link]) signifies that the church in its captivity under the enemies repents, confesses its sins, and accepts God's punishment for its sins.

verse.text: [i]So that[/i] I also walked contrary to them and brought them into the land of their enemies; if then their [xref]a[/xref]uncircumcised heart is humbled, and then they accept the punishment of their iniquity;
Then I will [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]remember My covenant with Jacob, and I will remember also My covenant with Isaac and also My covenant with Abraham, and I will remember the land.
verse.note: God remembering His covenants and the land signifies that for the church in captivity God remembers His new covenant ([link]Heb. 8:10-12[/link]) and Christ as the rich land ([link]Col. 1:12[/link]).

verse.text: For the land will be abandoned by them and will enjoy its [xref]a[/xref]Sabbaths while it is desolate without them. And they will accept the punishment of their iniquity because, even because, they rejected My ordinances, and their soul abhorred My statutes.

And yet in spite of this, when they are in the land of their enemies, I will [xref]a[/xref]not [note]1[/note]reject them, nor will I abhor them so as to destroy them utterly and to break My covenant with them; for I am Jehovah their God.
verse.note: That God would not reject the people nor destroy them utterly and break His covenant with them signifies that God, having chastised the church severely, will not reject it, nor will He destroy it utterly and break His covenant with it.[br][br]The spiritual principle in this chapter is that if we are wrong, we should repent; then we will receive back the blessing for our enjoyment. In the case of Israel, this word will be fulfilled at the time of the Lord's coming back ([link]Zech. 12:10[/link]; [link]Rom. 11:25-27[/link]).

verse.text: But for their sakes I will [xref]a[/xref]remember the covenant with their ancestors, whom I brought out of the land of Egypt in the sight of the nations so that I might be their God; I am Jehovah.

chapter.verse: These are the statutes and ordinances and laws which Jehovah made between Himself and the children of Israel at Mount Sinai through Moses.
Then Jehovah spoke to Moses, saying,

verse.text: Speak to the children of Israel and say to them, When a man [note]1[/note]makes a special [xref]a[/xref]vow to Jehovah, it shall be according to your [note]2[/note]valuation of persons.
verse.note: Lit., shall be wonderful [i]to make[/i] a vow. The book of Leviticus concludes with a vow of four kinds of devotions, showing that the totality of all the things in this book is a vow, which becomes our life, our living, as God's priesthood.

In the devotion of a person to God, the value of the person is set by God, i.e., in the eyes of God, "according to the shekel of the sanctuary" ([link]vv. 3[/link], [link]25[/link]), i.e., according to the holy scale of God's dwelling, the spiritual scale of the church, which is God's dwelling today ([link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]). The valuation was done in order to redeem the devoted thing ([link]vv. 13[/link], [link]14[/link], [link]19[/link]).

verse.text: If your valuation is for the [note]1[/note]male from twenty years old even to sixty years old, then your valuation shall be fifty shekels of silver according to the [xref]a[/xref]shekel of the sanctuary.
verse.note: Males in this category, the most valuable, signify those who are spiritually strong, mature, experienced, and able to serve at war in the church ([link]Num. 1:2-3[/link]). Their being valued at fifty shekels — fifty is composed of ten (fullness) times five (responsibility) — signifies that they are required to bear the greatest responsibility.

verse.text: And if it is for a [note]1[/note]female, then your valuation shall be thirty shekels.
verse.note: The female signifies those who are spiritually weaker than those categorized as males ([link]1 Pet. 3:7[/link]).

verse.text: And if it is for [i]one aged[/i] from [note]1[/note]five years old even to twenty years old, then your valuation for the male shall be twenty shekels and for the female ten shekels.
verse.note: Those in this category, the third most valuable, signify those who are spiritually young in the church (cf. [link]1 John 2:13-14[/link]).

verse.text: And if it is for [i]one aged[/i] from a [note]1[/note]month old even to five years old, then your valuation for the male shall be [xref]a[/xref]five shekels of silver, and for the female your valuation shall be three shekels of silver.
verse.note: Those in this category are the least valuable and signify those who are spiritually the young children (cf. [link]1 John 2:13[/link]).

verse.text: And if it is for [i]one aged[/i] from [note]1[/note]sixty years old and upward, if it is for a male, then your valuation shall be fifteen shekels, and for the female ten shekels.
verse.note: Those in this category signify those who are spiritually deteriorated.

verse.text: But if it is for him who is poorer than your valuation, then he shall be set before the priest, and the priest shall value him; according to the [note]1[/note]means of the one who vowed, the priest shall value him.
verse.note: The valuation of the one who was poorer being according to his means signifies that actually we are not valued according to our spiritual age but according to our spiritual ability, not according to what we should do spiritually but according to what we can do spiritually.

verse.text: And if it is for an animal which may be presented to Jehovah as an offering, anything which may be given to Jehovah shall be [note]1[/note]holy.
verse.note: To be holy is to be sanctified to God and thus to belong to God, becoming His possession. The devoted animal not being able to be exchanged or substituted ([link]v. 10a[/link]) indicates that once we have devoted ourselves to God, our status cannot be changed. Once something has been devoted to God, being placed on the altar, it cannot be returned. If an exchange were made, both animals would be holy ([link]v. 10b[/link]); i.e., both would belong to God. This indicates that God earnestly desires our devotion.

verse.text: He may not exchange it or [xref]a[/xref]substitute it, either a good one for a bad one or a bad one for a good one; but if he does indeed substitute animal for animal, then both it and its substitute shall be holy.
And if [i]his vow[/i] is for any [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]unclean animal, which may not be presented as an offering to Jehovah, then he shall set the animal before the priest,
verse.note: That the unclean animal devoted to Jehovah was valued by the priest ([link]vv. 11-12[/link]) signifies that even though what we devote to God is unclean, through the valuation of our Mediator, the Lord Jesus ([link]1 Tim. 2:5[/link]), the motive of our devotion is still valuable to some degree before God.

chapter.verse: And the priest shall value it, whether it is good or bad; as you, the priest, value it, so shall it be.

verse.text: But if he ever redeems it, then he shall add [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]one-fifth of it to your valuation.
verse.note: The adding of one-fifth to the valuation signifies that we should be careful, not owing anything to God in our devotion.

verse.text: And if anyone [note]1[/note]consecrates his house to be holy to Jehovah, then the [note]2[/note]priest shall value it, whether it is good or bad; just as the priest values it, so shall it stand.
verse.note: Or, dedicates. So throughout this chapter.
The valuing of the devoted house by the priest signifies that our devotion related to the church ([link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]) should be valued by our Mediator, the Lord Jesus ([link]1 Tim. 2:5[/link]).

verse.text: And if the one who consecrated [i]it[/i] redeems his house, then he shall add [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]one-fifth of the money of your valuation to it, and it shall become his.
verse.note: The adding of one-fifth of the valuation to redeem the house signifies that we should not take advantage of our devotion related to the church life, that we may keep the enjoyment of the church life. Otherwise, we will be churchless persons.

verse.text: And if a man consecrates to Jehovah part of a [note]1[/note]field of his possession, then your valuation shall be according to the [note]2[/note]seed needed for it: a homer of barley seed at fifty shekels of silver.
verse.note: Spiritually, the devoting of a field, a part of the land, is related to the enjoyment of Christ as the rich land (see note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Deut. 8[/link]). The more we devote ourselves and our possessions to God, the more we will enjoy Christ. All our devotions consummate in the enjoyment of Christ.

This signifies that our devotion related to the enjoyment of Christ as the rich land should be valued according to the seed of the divine life required for our spiritual increase. In the type, the more seed required, the higher was the value of the land. Seed is for multiplication, for life increase ([link]John 12:24[/link]). If our devotion related to the enjoyment of Christ will afford a greater prospect for the increase of the church, this devotion will be more valuable.

verse.text: If he consecrates his field from the [note]1[/note]year of jubilee, according to your valuation it shall stand.
verse.note: The longer the time until the jubilee, the greater was the value of the devoted land ([link]vv. 17-18[/link]). This signifies that our devotion related to the enjoyment of Christ should be valued also according to the measure of God's grace from the jubilee. The amount of seed needed for the devoted land, and hence the value of the land ([link]v. 16[/link]), depended on the number of years before the jubilee. If we devote ourselves to the Lord early in life, we will have more years to bring sinners to the Lord and thus to contribute to the increase of the church. The greater the increase we bring in, the greater the grace we will enjoy (cf. [link]John 15:2[/link], [link]6[/link]).

verse.text: But if he consecrates his field after the jubilee, then the priest shall calculate the money [note]1[/note]for him according to the [xref]a[/xref]years which remain until the year of jubilee, and it shall be deducted from your valuation.
verse.note: Or, for it. So also in [link]v. 23[/link].

verse.text: And if the one who consecrated the field ever redeems it, then he shall [xref]a[/xref]add one-fifth of the money of your valuation to it, and it shall revert to him.

chapter.verse: But if he does not redeem the field, or if he has sold the field to another man, it shall not be redeemed anymore.

verse.text: But the [note]1[/note]field, when it goes out in the [xref]a[/xref]jubilee, shall be holy to Jehovah as a [xref]b[/xref]devoted field; its possession shall be the priest's.
verse.note: The regulations in [link]vv. 21-24[/link] signify that in our devotion related to the enjoyment of Christ as the rich land, we cannot take advantage of others and we must be fair with God.

chapter.verse: And if he consecrates to Jehovah a field which he has bought that is not part of the field of his possession,
Then the priest shall calculate for him the amount of your valuation until the year of jubilee, and on that day he shall give your valuation as holy to Jehovah.
In the year of jubilee the field shall return to the one from whom he bought it, even to the one to whom the possession of the land belongs.

verse.text: And every valuation of yours shall be according to the [xref]a[/xref]shekel of the sanctuary. The shekel shall be twenty gerahs.
However no one shall consecrate the [note]1[/note]firstborn among animals, which as a [xref]a[/xref]firstborn [i]already[/i] belongs to Jehovah; whether it is an ox or a sheep, it is Jehovah's.
verse.note: Not consecrating the firstborn, which already belonged to Jehovah, signifies that we may not devote anything that is owned by God.

verse.text: But if [i]it is consecrated from[/i] among [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]unclean animals, then he shall ransom it according to your valuation and shall add to it [xref]b[/xref]one-fifth of it. And if it is not redeemed, then it shall be sold according to your valuation.
verse.note: See note [link]11[sup]1[/sup][/link].

verse.text: Nevertheless anything which someone devotes to Jehovah out of all that he has, whether a human or an animal or a field of his possession, it shall not be sold or redeemed. Every devoted thing is [note]1[/note]most holy to Jehovah.
verse.note: This signifies that our devotion must be so strong that it cannot be altered.

chapter.verse: No human beings who are devoted to destruction shall be ransomed; they shall surely be put to death.

verse.text: And all the [xref]a[/xref]tithe of the land, whether of the seed of the land or of the fruit of the tree, is [note]1[/note]Jehovah's; it is holy to Jehovah.
verse.note: The regulations in [link]vv. 30-33[/link] signify that we have no right over anything that belongs to God, and we may not dispose of it or change its ownership in any way.[br][br]Leviticus, a book on what God has done for our enjoyment, ends with God's aspiration that we vow to devote ourselves to Him. God has done everything for us, and now He needs us to enjoy Him. At the end of Leviticus God expresses His aspiration and expectation that we vow to devote to Him whatever we are, whatever we have, and whatever we can do. The purpose of this devotion is that we would enjoy the Lord in all that He has prepared for us.

verse.text: And if anyone redeems any of his tithe, he shall add to it [xref]a[/xref]one-fifth of it.

chapter.verse: And all the tithe of the herd or the flock, whatever passes under the shepherd's rod, the tenth one shall be holy to Jehovah.

verse.text: He shall not search whether it is good or bad, nor shall he [xref]a[/xref]substitute it; but if he does substitute it at all, then both it and that for which it is substituted shall be holy; it shall not be redeemed.

chapter.verse: These are the commandments which Jehovah commanded Moses on Mount Sinai for the children of Israel.
